Record 390 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Predation on eggs of codling moth (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae) in mating
  disrupted and conventional orchards in Washington.
AU: Knight-AL; Turner-JE; Brachula-B
AD: USDA, ARS, 5230 Konnowac Pass Road, Wapato, WA 98951, USA.
SO: Journal-of-the-Entomological-Society-of-British-Columbia. 1997, 94: 67-=
74;
  45 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: Predation on eggs of the codling moth, Cydia pomonella, was assessed in
  Washington in June and August 1995 in eight apple orchards treated with
  organophosphate insecticides (OPs), four orchards treated with mating
  disruption (MD) and some OPs, and four treated with MD but not with OPs.
  Sentinel codling moth eggs oviposited by caged moths on 10 shoots in each
  orchard were scored as alive, dead, or missing after 7 days, and beating =
tray
  samples of arthropod predators were collected at the beginning and end of=
 each
  trial. Levels of egg predation (dead + missing eggs) did not differ
  significantly among orchard types in June but varied among orchard types =
in
  August (MD alone > MD + OPs > OPs). The percentage of dead eggs in August=
 was
  significantly higher in orchards receiving only MD than in orchards treat=
ed
  only with OPs. The percentage of missing eggs was significantly lower bot=
h
  months in orchards not treated with MD. Densities of spiders [Araneae] an=
d all
  predators on both sample dates, and earwigs [Dermaptera] in August, were
  significantly higher in orchards not treated with OPs. Densities of
  heteropteran predators did not vary significantly by orchard type. No
  significant correlations were found among predator densities and egg mort=
ality
  within an orchard type. However, the percentages of dead eggs and dead pl=
us
  missing eggs were significantly and positively correlated with densities =
of
  earwigs, spiders, and all predators in tray samples across the 16 orchard=
s.
DE: insect-pests; plant-pests; natural-enemies; beneficial-insects; predato=
rs-;
  predatory-insects; predatory-arthropods; apples-; insect-control; chemica=
l
  -control; mating-disruption; nontarget-effects; organophosphorus-insectic=
ides;
  fruit-crops; pest-control; control-; agricultural-entomology
OD: Malus-pumila; Araneae-; Dermaptera-; Heteroptera-; Cydia-pomonella;
  arthropods-; Malus-
GE: USA-; Washington-
BT: Malus; Rosaceae; Rosales; dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta; pla=
nts;
  Arachnida; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; insects; Hemiptera; Cydia;
  Tortricidae; Lepidoptera; Developed-Countries; North-America; America; OE=
CD
  -Countries; Pacific-Northwest-States-of-USA; Pacific-States-of-USA; Weste=
rn
  -States-of-USA; USA
CC: HH100; FF600; HH400; HH500
CD: Biological-Control; Pests,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Plants;
  Control-by-Chemicals-and-Drugs; Repellents-and-Attractants

Record 391 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Evaluation of Shin-Etsu twist-tie rope dispensers by the mating table
  technique for disrupting mating of the cotton bollworm, Helicoverpa armig=
era
  (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae), and the pink bollworm, Pectinophora gossypiella
  (Lepidoptera: Gelechiidae).
AU: Kehat-M; Anshelevich-L; Gordon-D; Harel-M; Dunkelblum-E
AD: Institute of Plant Protection, Agricultural Research Organization, The
  Volcani Center, Bet Dagan 50250, Israel.
SO: Bulletin-of-Entomological-Research. 1998, 88: 2, 141-148; 21 ref.
PY: 1998
LA: English
AB: Different Shin-Etsu twist-tie rope formulations, containing the pheromo=
ne of
  either Helicoverpa armigera or Pectinophora gossypiella, or both, in the =
same
  rope, were tested in Israel for mating disruption. The success of mating
  disruption in cotton was evaluated by the mating table technique, compari=
ng the
  percentage of mating of virgin sentinel females in pheromone-treated and
  control plots. Two variants of this technique were evaluated, one with tw=
o
  mating tables per plot, each containing 5-7 females, and the other with 6=
-8
  mating tables per plot, with only one female per table. The latter method=
 was
  more sensitive than the former, particularly at low population densities.=
 Two
  tests were conducted in 1995 in order to compare a blend of five componen=
ts of
  H. armigera pheromone with a blend of two components for mating disruptio=
n. The
  application consisted of 2000 ropes/ha, each with 80 mg pheromone. Evalua=
tion
  by the two mating table methods showed clearly that the formulation conta=
ining
  two components was superior to the five-component blend for mating disrup=
tion,
  suppressing mating almost completely for 49 days. A new combined formulat=
ion,
  HPROPE, containing 175 mg of the H. armigera two-component blend and 65 m=
g of
  P. gossypiella pheromone, was tested in 1996 for mating disruption of bot=
h
  pests. Application of 625 ropes/ha caused a high level of suppression of =
mating
  of H. armigera females for at least 94 days and that of P. gossypiella fe=
males
  for 161 days. The pheromone release rates were ca. 625 mg/day per ha for =
H.
  armigera and 162 mg/day per ha for P. gossypiella. A 'long-life' formulat=
ion of
  P. gossypiella pheromone, PBW rope L, applied at 125 ropes/ha, releasing =
137
  mg/day per ha, achieved complete suppression of mating over 75 days. This
  release rate of P. gossypiella pheromone was much lower than that current=
ly
  used in Israel (275 mg/day per ha). These results indicate that mating of
  females of two moth pests with different pheromones can be disrupted by o=
ne
  combined formulation.
DE: evaluation-; dispensers-; mating-; cotton-; formulations-; mating
  -disruption; sex-pheromones; suppression-; fibre-plants; techniques-; pes=
t
  -control; control-; agricultural-entomology
OD: Helicoverpa-armigera; Pectinophora-gossypiella; Noctuidae-; Lepidoptera=
-;
  Gelechiidae-; Gossypium-; Helicoverpa-; Pectinophora-
GE: Israel-
BT: Helicoverpa; Noctuidae; Lepidoptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates=
;
  animals; Pectinophora; Gelechiidae; Malvaceae; Malvales; dicotyledons;
  angiosperms; Spermatophyta; plants; West-Asia; Asia; Developed-Countries;
  Mediterranean-Region; Middle-East
CC: FF600; HH500; LL300

Record 392 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Pesticide waste water management in Champagne.
AU: Rochard-J; Moncomble-D
AD: ITV-France, 2 esplanade Roland Garros, B.P. 235, 51686 Reims, France.
SO: Managing pesticide waste and packaging. Proceedings of a symposium held=
 at
  The University of Canterbury, Kent, UK, 30 March-1 April, 1998. 1998, 129=
-136;
  BCPC Symposium Proceedings No. 70; 9 ref.
PB: British Crop Protection Council; Farnham; UK
PY: 1998
LA: English
AB: Cleaning pesticide application equipment can cause pollution in ground =
and
  surface water. An experiment was performed in Champagne, France, in 1993 =
and
  1995 with the aim of investigating a collective area for pesticide waste =
water
  collection and studying two water treatment devices. The two tested syste=
ms,
  Sentinel and Epu-Mobil, provided some good treatment performances. Howeve=
r, the
  design of the collective area needs to be optimised. Control of water
  consumption and a separation of waste waters are required. Furthermore, a=
s in
  any environmental approach, pollution reduction has to be considered upst=
ream,
  by making wine-growers aware of the problem and adjusting pesticide appli=
cation
  equipment in order to avoid excess waste.
DE: wastes-; waste-water; water-management; application-equipment; surface
  -water; pesticides-; waste-disposal; fungicides-; chemical-control; plant
  -disease-control; environment-; herbicides-; agricultural-entomology; pla=
nt
  -pathology
GE: France-
ID: Managing-pesticide-waste-and-packaging
BT: Western-Europe; Europe; Developed-Countries; European-Union-Countries;
  Mediterranean-Region; OECD-Countries
CC: PP600; ZZ900; HH400
CD: Pollution-and-Degradation; Techniques-and-Methodology; Control-by-Chemi=
cals
  -and-Drugs
PT: Conference-paper

UD: 980716
AN: 981105598

Record 393 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Tissue-level biomarkers in sentinel slugs as cost-effective tools to as=
sess
  metal pollution in soils.
AU: Marigomez-I; Kortabitarte-M; Dussart-GBJ
AD: Biologia Zelularra Atala, Zoologia eta Animali Zelulen Dinamika Saila,
  Zientzi Fakultatea, Euskal Herriko Unibertsitatea, 644 PK E-48080 Bilbo, =
Spain.
SO: Archives-of-Environmental-Contamination-and-Toxicology. 1998, 34: 2, 16=
7
  -176; 44 ref.
PY: 1998
LA: English
AB: An investigation was carried out to validate previous laboratory result=
s in
  a field study. Slugs were collected from an abandoned Cu mine (Parys moun=
tain
  top, PMT), from a site 7 km away from the mine (Parys mountain bottom, PM=
B),
  and from a clean site (Snowdonia Cwm Idwal, SCI) in Wales (UK) in early J=
uly
  1994. Whole soft body and digestive gland Cd, Cu, and Zn concentrations w=
ere
  measured by means of atomic absorption spectrophotometry (AAS). The diges=
tive
  gland was the main tissue for metal accumulation, with significant differ=
ences
  in tissue metal levels between samples from different sites. PMB presente=
d the
  highest Cd and Zn levels and the highest Cu levels were found at PMT. In
  addition, metals were demonstrated in situ by autometallography as black =
silver
  deposits (BSD) on histological sections of digestive gland tissue. The ex=
tent
  of BSD within lysosomes of digestive cells was closely related to metal l=
evels
  determined by AAS. Histochemistry showed that Ca metabolism and structura=
l and
  reserve connective tissues might be altered in slugs living in metal-poll=
uted
  soils. Finally, tissue-level biomarkers of biological effect [mean epithe=
lial
  thickness (MET), mean diverticular radius (MDR), mean luminal radius (MLR=
),
  MET/MDR and MLR/MET] were quantified by image analysis of digestive gland
  histological sections stained with haematoxylin-eosin. MET and MDR values=
 of
  slugs collected from SCI were high, while slugs from PMB presented low ML=
R/MET
  associated with environmental stress induced by metal exposure. It was
  concluded that exposure and effect biomarkers recorded in sentinel slugs =
could
  be sensitive, quick, and cheap indices of metal pollution in soils. A Slu=
g
  Watch monitoring programme could be developed similar to the Mussel Watch
  programme, which is currently applied to assess environmental quality in
  coastal and estuarine areas.
DE: pollution-; heavy-metals; copper-; cadmium-; zinc-; atomic-absorption
  -spectroscopy; mining-; histology-; monitoring-; soil-; bioassays-; mine-=
spoil
OD: slugs-; Gastropoda-; Mollusca-
GE: Wales-; UK-
RN: 7440-50-8; 7440-43-9; 7440-66-6
BT: Gastropoda; Mollusca; invertebrates; animals; Great-Britain; UK; Europe=
an
  -Union-Countries; British-Isles; Western-Europe; Europe; Commonwealth-of
  -Nations; Developed-Countries; OECD-Countries
CC: JJ100; PP600
CD: Soil-Biology; Pollution-and-Degradation
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0090-4341
UD: 980716
AN: 981905870

=3DArchive

Record 394 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: The sentinel method and its application to environmental pollution prob=
lems.
AU: Kernevez-J-P
SO: 1997, ix + 204 pp.; CRC Mathematical Modelling Series; Many ref.
PB: CRC Press Inc.; Boca Raton; USA
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: Many environmental problems contain incomplete data in the initial or
  boundary conditions. How do we solve problems for which some of the initi=
al
  and/or boundary conditions are unknown? Using a new technique, the sentin=
el
  method, this book answers these questions and others as they pertain to i=
nverse
  problems in environmental pollution, such as pollution of underground and
  surface waters, thermal pollution, and air pollution. This guide explains=
 how
  to solve inverse problems, where incomplete data causes difficulties, by
  measuring pollution concentration at a few points and, using the sentinel
  method, locate and identify pollutants, calculate the quantity of polluta=
nt
  discharged, detect crises early, and more. This book also explains how to
  extend the method to other situations. Describes effective and efficient
  methods of solving important environmental problems. Explains how to appl=
y the
  sentinel method to a wide range of situations. Emphasizes real-world
  applications, particularly identification of pollutants in aquatic system=
s.
  Includes numerous problems and examples.
DE: pollution-; water-pollution; statistical-analysis; methodology-
CC: PP600; ZZ100; PP210
CD: Pollution-and-Degradation; Mathematics-and-Statistics; Freshwater-and
  -Brackish-Water
PT: Book
IB: 0-8493-9630-1
UD: 980716
AN: 981908431
WEBLH: Check for Holdings
  http://sladmin.silverplatter.com:4416/lpascripts/holdlink.pl?lpa.holdlink=

Record 395 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Control and eradication of Aujeszky's disease in a production system on
  three sites.
OT: Control y erradicacion de la enfermedad de aujeszky en un sistema multi=
ple
  de tres sitios de produccion.
AU: Maria-Vargas-A; Doporto-Diaz-JM; Trujillo-Ortega-ME; Ramirez-Mendoza-H;
  Carreon-Napoles-R
AD: Facultad de Medicina Veterinaria y Zootecnia, Universidad Nacional Auto=
noma
  de Mexico, 04510, D.F Mexico.
SO: Veterinaria-Mexico. 1997, 28: 2, 147-155; 38 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: Spanish
LS: English
AB: Control and eradication was by vaccination of the breeding herd and
  segregated rearing, and monitoring by sentinel animals free of AD. The ti=
tre of
  antibodies was evaluated with the serum virus neutralization test and the
  competitive g1 + ELISA. Positivity in all sites was 93.67%. The breeding =
herd
  was medicated with antibiotics in the feed to prevent the presentation of
  opportunistic infections. To control the outbreak, the breeding herd was
  vaccinated with a killed virus vaccine with a glycoprotein gl deletion ag=
ainst
  AD. This vaccination was repeated 21 days later, and the following year. =
Every
  pig in the breeding herd was vaccinated every three months. The second ye=
ar
  after the outbreak, vaccination was applied to all animals in the breedin=
g herd
  every four months. To control and eliminate AD, gilts and boars were plac=
ed in
  site 1 for a 6-month period. During the outbreak, piglets were weaned (21=
 days
  of age) and sent to a facility outside the system. When signs of AD
  disappeared, the piglets were weaned at 18 days of age and segregated to =
site
  2. Methods applied to site 1 (vaccination, segregation rearing, closing t=
he
  site and medication) were effective to control and eradicate AD in the sy=
stem.
  There has not been any case of the disease in sites 2 and 3 since the pro=
gramme
  started and no clinical signs of AD has been reported on site 1.
DE: Aujeszky's-disease; disease-control; ELISA-; neutralization-tests; dise=
ase
  -prevention; viral-diseases
OD: pigs-
GE: Mexico-
BT: Sus-scrofa; Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Developing-Countries; Latin-America; North-America; Am=
erica;
  Threshold-Countries
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
UD: 980716
AN: 982206219

Record 396 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Congenital malformations in calves associated with Aino virus prevalenc=
e in
  Fukuoka Prefecture in 1995 to 1996.
AU: Uchinuno-Y; Noda-Y; Shirakawa-H; Nagasue-S; Nagano-M; Ohe-R
AD: Chuo Livestock Hygiene Service Centre, Fukuoka Prefecture, Hakata-ku,
  Fukuoka 816, Japan.
SO: Journal-of-the-Japan-Veterinary-Medical-Association. 1997, 50: 12, 709-=
712;
  19 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: Japanese
LS: English
AB: In the period September 1995 to April 1996, 82 abnormal parturitions an=
d 47
  cases of congenital malformation (kyphoscreliosis, arthrogryposis,
  hydranencephaly and cerebellar hypoplasia) occurred in Fukuoka Prefecture=
. Most
  serum samples and body fluids from the dams and affected calves had
  neutralizing antibody to Aino virus; high antibody titres were detected i=
n
  precolostral serum from affected calves and in fetal fluids. When serum s=
amples
  were collected in 1995 from 100 sentinel calves on 50 farms and examined =
for
  antibody to Aino virus, seroconversion occurred in one case in September,=
 25
  cases in October, and 3 cases in November. It is suggested that Aino viru=
s
  infection might play an aetiological role in abnormal parturitions and th=
at the
  in-utero infection occurred at 120-150 days of gestation.

  -abnormalities; viral-diseases; cattle-diseases

Record 397 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Serologic survey for antibodies to Borrelia burgdorferi in white-tailed=
 deer
  in Ontario.
AU: Gallivan-GJ; Barker-IK; Artsob-H; Magnarelli-LA; Robinson-JT; Voigt-DR
AD: 119 Guelph Street, Apartment 5, Guelph, Ontario N1H 5Z2, Canada.
SO: Journal-of-Wildlife-Diseases. 1998, 34: 2, 411-414; 20 ref.
PY: 1998
LA: English
AB: Serum samples collected from 623 white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginia=
nus)
  in southern Ontario (Canada) from 1985 to 1989 were tested for antibodies=
 to B.
  burgdorferi using an indirect fluorescent antibody (IFA) staining method.
  Samples from 150 of the deer were also tested using an ELISA. At IFA titr=
es of
  1:64 and 1:128 deer with antibodies to B. burgdorferi appeared to be wide=
spread
  throughout southern Ontario, with an apparent prevalence ranging from 3 t=
o 47%.
  At IFA titres _1:256 and ELISA titres _1:160 deer with antibodies to B.
  burgdorferi were only present on Long Point which is the only known endem=
ic
  focus of Ixodes scapularis, the primary vector for B. burgdorferi, in sou=
thern
  Ontario. At these titres the apparent prevalence of antibodies to B.
  burgdorferi on Long Point was only 5 to 7%, even though the mean intensit=
y of
  infestation of adult I. scapularis on deer was >180, and 60% of the adult=
 ticks
  are infected with B. burgdorferi. It is concluded that white-tailed deer =
do not
  appear to be a good sentinel species for the distribution of B. burgdorfe=
ri.
DE: Lyme-disease; seroprevalence-; antibodies-; ELISA-; tickborne-diseases;
  sentinel-surveillance; immunofluorescence-
OD: Borrelia-burgdorferi; Odocoileus-virginianus; Ixodes-scapularis
GE: Canada-; Ontario-
BT: Borrelia; Spirochaetaceae; Spirochaetales; Gracilicutes; bacteria;
  prokaryotes; Odocoileus; Cervidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals;
  vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Ixodes; Ixodidae; Metastigmata; Acari;
  Arachnida; arthropods; invertebrates; OECD-Countries; Commonwealth-of-Nat=
ions;
  Developed-Countries; North-America; America; Canada
CC: LL820; PP710
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Biologi=
cal
  -Resources-Animal

Record 398 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Surveillance of St. Louis, eastern and western equine encephalitis viru=
s in
  the province of Ciego de Avila.
OT: Vigilancia de las encefalitis de San Luis, equina del este y equina del
  oeste en la provincia Ciego de Avila.
AU: Pelegrino-JL; Suarez-M; Guzman-MG; Vazquez-S; Benitez-NR
AD: Instituto de Medicina Tropical "Pedro Kouri", Marianao 13, Ciudad de La
  Habana, Cuba.
SO: Revista-Cubana-de-Medicina-Tropical. 1996, 48: 2, 109-113; 14 ref.
PY: 1996
LA: Spanish
LS: English
AB: Serological studies were performed using haemagglutination inhibition a=
nd
  neutralization tests to study the circulation dynamics of western and eas=
tern
  encephalomyelitis virus antigens in human serum from symptomatic and
  asymptomatic individuals and also from birds, in the province of Ciego de
  Avila, Cuba, during 1987-91 and 1994. 1.7% of the asymptomatic subjects t=
ested
  showed neutralizing antibodies to eastern equine and 4.8% to St. Louis
  encephalomyelitis virus. 16 patients with seroconversion by haemagglutina=
tion
  inhibition to St. Louis virus were detected. Surveillance of sentinel bir=
ds
  showed that during 1988, 1989 and 1994, St. Louis virus circulated in the
  municipalities of Moron, Bolivia and Chambas, while in Chambas eastern
  encephalomyelitis virus circulated in 1988 and 1989. Antibodies to wester=
n
  equine encephalomyelitis virus were detected in healthy individuals by
  haemagglutination inhibition due to apparently heterologous antibodies, s=
ince
  no neutralizing antibodies to this virus were detected.
DE: St-Louis-encephalitis; brain-diseases; infections-; serology-; human
  -diseases; disease-transmission; seroprevalence-; epidemiology-; serologi=
cal
  -surveys
OD: equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; man-; birds-; St-Louis-encephalitis-vir=

  arboviruses-
GE: Cuba-; Caribbean-

  -Countries; Latin-America

TI: Bluetongue reactors in quarantine.

PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: Bluetongue was demonstrated in 1 of 5 cattle from New South Wales,
  Australia, and a calf born in Victoria, Australia, when tested in a New Z=
ealand
  medium security quarantine facility in 1996.

Record 400 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Rift Valley fever in Nigeria: infections in domestic animals.
AU: Olaleye-OD; Tomori-O; Schmitz-H
AD: Department of Virology, College of Medicine, University College Hospita=
l,
  University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria.
SO: Revue-Scientifique-et-Technique -Office-International-des-Epizooties. 1=
996,
  15: 3, 937-946; 23 ref.
PY: 1996
LA: English
LS: French, Spanish
AB: In 1986-89, 2255 sera collected from sheep, cattle, horses, camels
  [dromedaries], goats and pigs in Nigeria were tested for antibodies to Ri=
ft
  Valley fever (RVF) virus. In addition, a longitudinal study was carried o=
ut
  from July 1987 to December 1988, using 10 sentinel flocks on 4 farms at I=
badan
  and Ile-Ife, to determine the activity of RVF virus (RVFV). All samples w=
ere
  tested for haemagglutination-inhibiting antibodies and positive sera were
  further screened, using the plaque reduction neutralisation test. Of 2255
  samples, 259 (11.5%) had haemagglutination-inhibiting and neutralising
  antibodies, as follows: pigs (0%), sheep (18.7%), goats (10.4%), cattle
  (10.2%), horses (9.8%) and dromedaries (3.3%). The highest prevalence of =
RVFV
  antibody was found in the plateau area (18.4%). Animals aged 3 years or m=
ore
  had a higher prevalence of antibodies to RVFV. Longitudinal studies showe=
d
  seroconversion to RVFV in 10 of 210 animals which were kept under observa=
tion
  (4.8%). All seroconversions occurred during the wet season. The results o=
f this
  study indicate that the infection of animals with RVFV is widespread in N=
igeria.
DE: domestic-animals; disease-surveys; disease-prevalence; viral-diseases
OD: Rift-Valley-fever-virus; arboviruses-; sheep-; cattle-; horses-; dromed=
aries
  -; goats-; pigs-
GE: Nigeria-
BT: Phlebovirus; arboviruses; viruses; Bunyaviridae; Ovis; Bovidae; ruminan=
ts;
  Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Bos; Equus; Equida=
e;
  Perissodactyla; Camelus; Camelidae; Tylopoda; Capra; Sus-scrofa; Sus; Sui=
dae;
  Suiformes; ACP-Countries; Anglophone-Africa; Commonwealth-of-Nations;
  Developing-Countries; West-Africa; Africa-South-of-Sahara; Africa

Record 402 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Assessment of vector microfilarial uptake as a comparatively non-invasi=
ve
  technique for monitoring onchocerciasis treatment campaigns in the Americ=
as.
AU: Davies-JB; Lujan-R; Lopez-Martinez-LA; Paniagua-Alvarez-AJ; Morales
  -Hernandez-BE; Sherlock-K
AD: Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, Pembroke Place, Liverpool L3 5QA=
, UK.
SO: Tropical-Medicine-and-International-Health. 1997, 2: 4, 348-355; 13 ref=
.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: Since 1992, efforts have been made to combat onchocerciasis in Guatemal=
a
  through mass distribution of ivermectin. The impact of the campaign is as=
sessed
  by taking skin-snips from sentinel groups within selected communities. Th=
is
  method gives an estimate of the prevalence and intensity of infection, an=
d thus
  the efficacy of the treatment. In some communities people are becoming
  reluctant to volunteer for skin-snipping, and so there is a need for an
  alternative technique that will give quantitative results. In most hypere=
ndemic
  communities in Guatemala, biting blackflies are so ubiquitous that few pe=
ople
  object to allowing 10 to 20 flies to engorge upon them. Data on the
  quantitative uptake of Onchocerca volvulus microfilariae by Simulium ochr=
aceum
  were examined before and after ivermectin distribution to see whether res=
ults
  similar to skin-snip data could be obtained. Counts of microfilariae inge=
sted
  by S. ochraceum were compared to the numbers found in skin-snips from the=
 same
  volunteers. In a group of 31 untreated infected persons, a skin-snip surv=
ey was
  positive in 20 (64.5%), whereas feeding flies (vector microfilarial uptak=
e,
  VmfU) was positive in 30 (96.8%). Post-treatment, in a sample of 58 of wh=
om 52
  (89.7%) had a history of infection, both skin-snips and VmfU were positiv=
e in
  31 (54.2%). Vector blood meals contained more microfilariae than did one =
mg of
  skin before treatment, but both recorded about equal numbers after treatm=
ent.
  When the data set was subdivided to compare samples taken at 2-3, 6-8 and=
 14-17
  months post-treatment, the effect of ivermectin was still apparent at 6-8
  months, but had virtually disappeared by 14 months post-treatment. The fl=
ies
  ingested fewer microfilariae from treated persons than was expected from =
the
  skin densities estimated by skin-snip. This effect lasted for over 8 mont=
hs,
  and it is suggested that it may indicate that ivermectin has a greater ef=
fect
  on transmission than previously suspected. It is concluded that VmfU coul=
d be
  used as an alternative to skin-snipping; the ethical implications are dis=
cussed.
DE: disease-control; techniques-; monitoring-; anthelmintics-; ivermectin-;
  detection-; parasites-; helminths-
OD: Onchocerca-volvulus; Simulium-ochraceum; man-
GE: Guatemala-
RN: 70288-86-7
BT: Onchocerca; Onchocercidae; Nematoda; invertebrates; animals; Simulium;
  Simuliidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; Homo; Hominidae; Primates; mamm=
als;
  vertebrates; Chordata; CACM; Central-America; America; Developing-Countri=
es;
  Latin-America
CC: VV200; HH400
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Control-=
by
  -Chemicals-and-Drugs
PT: Journal-article
UD: 980416
AN: 980800013

Record 403 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Assessment of the sentinel surveillance system for chemosensitivity of
  antimalarial drugs in Cote d'Ivoire.
OT: Evaluation du systeme ivoirien de surveillance sentinelle de la
  chimiosensibilite des antipaludiques.
AU: Diawara-B; Muynck-A-de; Coulibaly-A; Niangue-J; Stuyft-P-van-der; de-Mu=
ynck
  -A; van-der-Stuyft-P
AD: Institut National de Sante Publique, Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire.
SO: Medecine-Tropicale. 1996, 56: 4, 352-356; 18 ref.
PY: 1996
LA: French
LS: English
AB: This study used a new method to assess the sentinel surveillance system=
 for
  malaria drug resistance in Cote d'Ivoire. Overall, the surveillance syste=
m was
  considered to be satisfactory, and the strong points were found to includ=
e
  relevance, sustainabililty and data quality. The weak points were poor
  planning, over centralization and underuse of information. It is suggeste=
d that
  correction of these weaknesses will require effort by all parties at the
  national level. It is concluded that the evaluation method used was simpl=
e,
  cheap and reproducible, and thus could serve as an alternative approach f=
or
  evaluation of sentinel surveillance systems in areas with scarce resource=
s.
DE: sentinel-surveillance; assessment-; antiprotozoal-agents; drug-therapy;
  malaria-; human-diseases; drug-resistance; evaluation-; parasites-
OD: man-; Plasmodium-; protozoa-

  -Africa; Africa-South-of-Sahara; Africa; ACP-Countries; Developing-Countr=
ies;
  Francophone-Africa

Record 404 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Response of bell pepper cultivars to bacterial spot pathogen races that
  individually overcome major resistance genes.
AU: Kousik-CS; Ritchie-DF
AD: Department of Plant Pathology, North Carolina State University, Raleigh
  27695-7616, USA.
SO: Plant-Disease. 1998, 82: 2, 181-186; 28 ref.
PY: 1998
LA: English
AB: The effect of major resistance genes (Bs1, Bs2 and Bs3) or gene combina=
tions
  on resistance to bacterial spot of bell peppers (Capsicum) (Xanthomonas
  campestris pv. vesicatoria) [X. vesicatoria] in 15 commercial cultivars w=
ere
  studied during 1995 and 1996. Reaction of cultivars to specific races (ra=
ces 1,
  2 or 3) of the pathogen corresponded with seed company claims for resista=
nce
  against these races. Races 1 to 4 were used as initial inoculum in 1995, =
and
  races 1 to 6 in 1996 field experiments which were conducted at Sandhills
  Research Station, Jackson Springs, North Carolina, USA. Cultivars with no=
 known
  resistance genes to bacterial spot (e.g., Camelot, Jupiter and Valiant), =
a
  single resistance gene (X3R Camelot, King Arthur) or a combination of Bs1=
 and
  Bs3 genes (Guardian, Sentinel and Admiral) were severely diseased. Yields=
 were
  reduced in all inoculated cultivars compared to non-inoculated cultivars =
used
  as controls. Although races 4 and 6 caused significant disease in cultiva=
rs
  with only Bs1 (King Arthur) or Bs2 (X3R Camelot) genes, cultivars with a
  combination of Bs1 and Bs2 (Boynton Bell, PR9300-8) had much lower levels=
 of
  bacterial spot. Roger 4178, a hybrid with a combination of Bs1, Bs2, Bs3 =
genes,
  had the lowest disease ratings. Overall, race 3 was predominant during 19=
95,
  whereas races 3 and 6 were recovered most frequently in 1996.
DE: plant-diseases; plant-pathogens; plant-pathogenic-bacteria; cultivars-;
  races-; resistance-; genes-; disease-resistance; varietal-reactions; vege=
tables
  -; plant-pathology
OD: Capsicum-; bacteria-
GE: USA-; North-Carolina
ID: Xanthomonas-vesicatoria

of

Record 405 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Evaluation of systemically treated squash trap plants and attracticidal
  baits for early-season control of striped and spotted cucumber beetles
  (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae) and squash bug (Hemiptera: Coreidae) in cucur=
bit
  crops.
AU: Pair-SD
AD: South Central Agricultural Research Laboratory, USDA-ARS, Lane, OK 7455=
5,
  USA.
SO: Journal-of-Economic-Entomology. 1997, 90: 5, 1307-1314; 21 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: In 1992, sentinel squash plants treated with carbofuran successfully
  attracted and killed Anasa tristis and Acalymma vittatum emerging from
  overwintering at 5 locations in Atoka County, Oklahoma. In 1993, response=
s of
  the pests to carbofuran-treated squash trap plants and to Adios or Adios-=
AG
  attracticidal baits were compared in <1.0-ha plots of seedling cantaloupe=
,
  squash and watermelon at Lane, Oklahoma. Regardless of crop, pest populat=
ions
  were highly attracted to 'Lemondrop' squash trap plants that amounted to =
<1% of
  the total crop area. Squash trap-plants attracted an estimated 39.7, 32.4=
 and
  66.3% of the A. vittatum population, respectively, observed in fields of
  cantaloupe, squash and watermelon seedlings. In cantaloupe and watermelon=
,
  squash trap-plants attracted >90% of the estimated Anasa tristis populati=
on but
  were less effective in squash. In all cases, squash trap plants treated w=
ith
  carbofuran killed >90 and 16-37%, respectively, of the Acalymma vittatum =
and
  Anasa tristis found on the plants. Single applications of attracticidal b=
aits
  provided up to 70% Acalymma vittatum mortality for 3-5 days post treatmen=
t.
  Studies conducted in 1994 showed that significantly greater numbers of
  Coleoptera, primarily Diabrotica undecimpunctata howardii, were attracted=
 to
  'Blue Hubbard' than Lemondrop squash trap plants that were treated with
  systemic insecticides, carbofuran at 0.15 g a.i. or imidacloprid at 0.04 =
g
  a.i., and positioned in a field of watermelon. Imidacloprid was as effect=
ive as
  carbofuran, each causing >90% beetle mortality. In this study, an estimat=
ed
  46.7% of the total beetle population was attracted to the squash trap pla=
nts.
  Results from these studies suggest that minimal plantings of systemically
  treated squash can be used effectively to suppress early-season populatio=
ns of
  A. vittatum and Anasa tristis in seedling cantaloupe, squash and watermel=
on.
DE: pest-management; baits-; chemical-control; insect-pests; plant-pests;
  insecticides-; carbofuran-; imidacloprid-; squashes-; watermelons-; melon=
s-;
  vegetables-; tropical-fruits; fruit-crops; pest-control; control-; agricu=
ltural
  -entomology
OD: Coleoptera-; Acalymma-vittatum; Diabrotica-undecimpunctata-howardi; Ana=
sa
  -tristis; Cucurbitaceae-; Cucurbita-; Citrullus-lanatus; Cucumis-melo;
  arthropods-
GE: USA-; Oklahoma-
RN: 1563-66-2
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; Acalymma; Chrysomelidae;
  Coleoptera; Diabrotica-undecimpunctata; Diabrotica; Anasa; Coreidae;
  Heteroptera; Hemiptera; Violales; dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyt=
a;
  plants; Cucurbitaceae; Citrullus; Cucumis; Developed-Countries; North-Ame=

Record 406 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Chloroquine resistance in Pakistan and the upsurge of falciparum malari=
a in
  Pakistani and Afghan refugee populations.
AU: Shah-I; Rowland-M; Mehmood-P; Mujahid-C; Razique-F; Hewitt-S; Durrani-N
AD: National Institute of Malaria Research and Training, Lahore, Pakistan.
SO: Annals-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Parasitology. 1997, 91: 6, 591-602; 14 =
ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: In Pakistan, the spread of chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium falciparum =
has
  been recorded by in vivo surveys carried out each year since 1977. Survey=
s
  conducted during the last decade show that P. falciparum malaria has beco=
me
  resistant to chloroquine in Pakistani and Afghan refugee populations thro=
ughout
  the country. Although RI resistance is common everywhere (with a frequenc=
y of
  30-84%), RII is less common (2-36%), and RIII resistance has yet to be
  detected. A repeated in-vivo survey in a sentinel village indicated that
  prescription of chloroquine could lead to a 15% increase in the frequency=
 of
  resistance in a single year, and similar trends were observed in other
  districts. Coinciding with the spread of resistance was a 6-fold increase=
 in
  the number of P. falciparum cases recorded nationally between 1982 and 19=
92,
  and a parallel, 5-fold increase in the number of cases recorded in the Af=
ghan
  refugee population. In the sentinel village, where resistance was measure=
d at
  71%, recrudescent infections increased the genuine incidence of new infec=
tions
  recorded at the health centre by 66%. It is suggested that ineffective
  treatment could lead to resistant infections remaining patent during the =
post
  -transmission season. There was evidence that the vector-control programm=
e
  among the refugees was still able to reduce the incidence of P. falciparu=
m
  malaria to a level that existed before the advent of resistance.
DE: malaria-; chloroquine-; drug-resistance; drug-therapy; populations-; hu=
man
  -diseases; antiprotozoal-agents; antimalarials-; epidemiology-; refugees-=
;
  parasites-
OD: Plasmodium-falciparum; man-; protozoa-
GE: Pakistan-
RN: 54-05-7; 50-63-5; 132-73-0

  invertebrates; animals; Homo; Hominidae; Primates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; Commonwealth-of-Nations; Developing-Countries; South-Asia; Asia
CC: VV200; HH400; HH410
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Control-=
by
  -Chemicals-and-Drugs; Pesticide-and-Drug-Resistance

Record 407 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Surveillance of foodborne diseases: what are the options?
AU: Borgdorff-MW; Motarjemi-Y
AD: National Institute of Public Health and the Environment, Department of
  Infectious Diseases Epidemiology, Bilthoven, Netherlands.
SO: World-Health-Statistics-Quarterly. 1997, 50: 1-2, 12-23; 120 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: Methods for surveillance of foodborne diseases are reviewed: records fo=
r
  registration of deaths and hospital discharges, disease notification, sen=
tinel
  surveillance, laboratory surveillance, outbreak investigation, and
  epidemiological studies. Each method, its advantages and disadvantages, a=
nd its
  relevance for meeting the various objectives and needs of surveillance ar=
e
  discussed.

  reviews-

Record 408 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Prevalence of antibody against infectious bovine rhinotracheitis virus =
in
  sentinel cattle in West and East Nusa Tenggara.
AU: Wiyono-A; Sarosa-A; Geong-M; Utami-S
AD: Research Institute for Veterinary Science Jalan R.E. Martadinata 30, P.=
O.
  Box 52, Bogor 16114, Indonesia.
SO: Jurnal-Ilmu-Ternak-dan-Veteriner. 1995, 1: 2, 99-104.
PY: 1995
LA: English
LS: Indonesian
AB: 4977 serum samples were collected between June 1990 and June 1993 from
  sentinel cattle in West and East Nusa Tenggara, Timor. 3731 sera were tes=
ted
  for antibody against bovine herpesvirus-1, the causal agent of infectious
  bovine rhinotracheitis (IBR) using a serum neutralization test (SNT). A t=
otal
  of 349 sera (10.4%) reacted. IBR reactors was more prevalent in East Nusa
  Tenggara than in West Nusa Tenggara. It is concluded that antibodies agai=
nst
  IBR virus are present among cattle in East and West Nusa Tenggara.
DE: disease-surveys
OD: cattle-; bovine-herpesvirus-1
GE: Indonesia-; Timor-
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; bovine-herpesvirus; Herpesviridae; viruses; South-East-Asia; Asi=
a;
  ASEAN-Countries; Developing-Countries; Indonesia

Record 411 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Association between risk of seroconversion of sentinel cattle to blueto=
ngue
  viruses and Culicoides species (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) in Queensland,
  Australia.
AU: Ward-MP; Doherty-WM; Johnson-SJ
AD: Animal Research Institute, Queensland Department of Primary Industries,
  Locked Mail Bag 4, Moorooka, Queensland 4105, Australia.
SO: Preventive-Veterinary-Medicine. 1997, 32: 3-4, 267-274; 21 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: The association between risk of seroconversion of sentinel cattle to
  bluetongue viruses and the number of Culicoides brevitarsis and C. wadai =
caught
  by light traps, was investigated using survival analysis. 8 sentinel herd=
s that
  seroconverted to bluetongue viruses between 1990 and 1994, and for which =
insect
  -trapping data were available, were selected for inclusion in the study. =
The
  herds were located at 6 sites along the eastern coast of Queensland, Aust=
ralia.
  C. brevitarsis was detected at all locations where sentinel herds were
  maintained, whereas C. wadai was detected at only two locations where 4
  sentinel herds were maintained during the study period. The mean number o=
f C.
  brevitarsis and C. wadai caught per month was 230 and 21, respectively. A
  significantly positive association was found between the risk of seroconv=
ersion
  of sentinel cattle to bluetongue viruses and the number of C. wadai caugh=
t in
  the same month.
DE: seroconversion-; sentinel-animals; insect-traps; disease-vectors; vecto=
r
  -borne-diseases; viral-diseases
OD: bluetongue-virus; Culicoides-brevitarsis; cattle-; viruses-; Culicoides
  -wadai; Culicoides-
GE: Queensland-; Australia-
BT: Orbivirus; Reoviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Culicoides; Ceratopogonida=
e;

ants;

Record 412 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: EHDV-1, a new Australian serotype of epizootic haemorrhagic disease vir=
us
  isolated from sentinel cattle in the Northern Territory.
AU: Weir-RP; Harmsen-MB; Hunt-NT; Blacksell-SD; Lunt-RA; Pritchard-LI; Newb=
erry
  -KM; Hyatt-AD; Gould-AR; Melville-LF
AD: Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries, Berrimah Agricultural Res=
earch
  Centre, P.O. Box 79, Berrimah, Northern Territory 0828, Australia.
SO: Veterinary-Microbiology. 1997, 58: 2-4, 135-143; 27 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: In 1992, a virus (DPP2209) was isolated from sentinel cattle located at
  Coastal Plains Research Station, approximately 60 km east of Darwin, Nort=
hern
  Territory, Australia. This virus was identified as a serotype of epizooti=
c
  haemorrhagic disease of deer virus previously undescribed in Australia. 1=
7
  isolations of this virus were made from 8 animals during the period Febru=
ary to
  May 1992. Electron microscopic studies showed the presence of orbivirus-l=
ike
  structures. Serogrouping ELISA, indirect immunofluorescence assay and the
  serogrouping plaque reduction neutralization test indicated the virus was=
 a
  member of the epizootic haemorrhagic disease serogroup. Serotype specific
  plaque reduction neutralization tests, indicated the virus was a member o=
f the
  epizootic haemorrhagic disease serogroup not previously isolated in Austr=
alia.
  Analysis of the VP3 gene confirmed this observation. Cross neutralization
  testing of the isolate with known epizootic haemorrhagic disease serotype
  viruses including endemic Australian and exotic strains identified isolat=
e
  DPP2209 as epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus serotype 1.
DE: serotypes-; identification-; ELISA-; neutralization-tests;
  immunofluorescence-; viral-diseases
OD: Orbivirus-; cattle-; epizootic-haemorrhagic-disease-of-deer-virus
GE: Australia-; Northern-Territory
BT: Reoviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla=

Record 413 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: An epidemic of Aino virus and incidence of congenital abnormalities in
  cattle in Okayama Prefecture.
AU: Fukutomi-T; Okuda-K; Akashi-H; Bessho-R; Hashimoto-N; Mito-T; Nagano-H;
  Nagai-M
AD: Okayama Prefecture Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, Mitsu-cho, Mitsu,
  Okayama 709-21, Japan.
SO: Journal-of-the-Japan-Veterinary-Medical-Association. 1997, 50: 8, 442-4=
47;
  12 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: Japanese
LS: English
AB: From September to November 1995, a serological survey showed that 75% o=
f
  farms and 61.5% of sentinel calves examined were positive for antibodies =
to
  Aino virus (AIV) in the southern Okayama Prefecture, Japan. Six cases of
  congenital abnormalities were observed from November 1995 to March 1996, =
5 of 6
  cases were stillbirths at 8 to 9 months of pregnancy. There were 5 cases =
of
  cervical gryposis and 4 of arthrogryposis. One case showed a cerebral def=
ect
  and cerebellar hypoplasia. Viruses were isolated from erythrocytes and bl=
ood
  plasma from 3 sentinel calves in early October 1995, and the dates of ser=
o
  -conversion and virus isolation suggested fetal infection occurring at 3 =
to 5
  months of pregnancy. The isolates had physicochemical properties of AIV a=
nd
  cross-reacted with the JaNAr-28 strain in a neutralizing test.
DE: congenital-abnormalities; fetal-death; nervous-system-diseases; brain-;
  viral-diseases; cattle-diseases
OD: cattle-; Bunyaviridae-
GE: Japan-

Record 414 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Peach texture during ripening after extended storage.
AU: Murillo-JA; Brusewitz-GH; Maness-NO
AD: Biosystems and Agricultural Engineering Department, Oklahoma State
  University, Stillwater, OK 74078, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Food-Quality. 1997, 20: 1, 61-72; 22 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: Fruits of 4 peach cultivars (Sentinel, Topaz, Parade and Fairtime) were
  stored at 0=B0C for 28 days. Time-texture tests were carried out over the=
 next 4
  days during fruit ripening at 25=B0. Cylindrical fruit specimens were pen=
etrated
  with a wire probe installed in an Instron universal testing machine. From=
 the
  force-displacement response, firmness parameters were determined and a fa=
st
  Fourier transform frequency analysis was performed to determine the jagge=
dness
  of the curves. Effegi firmness, Instron peak force, and spectrum area cha=
nged
  the most during ripening. The lowest frequency ratio (0-0.19 Hz) changed =
more
  than any other frequency ratio during ripening. Significant decreases in =
Effegi
  firmness and in Instron peak force, steady state force and frequency rati=
os
  were observed between the first and the second day of ripening but the ch=
anges
  were not significant thereafter. After one day of ripening, fruits of the=
 late
  -season cultivars Fairtime and Parade were significantly less firm than f=
ruits
  of the mid-season cultivar Topaz and the early season cultivar Sentinel. =
After
  2 days of ripening, differences in firmness parameters among the 4 cultiv=
ars
  were not significant.
DE: peaches-; cultivars-; storage-quality; fruits-; firmness-; ripening-; c=
old
  -storage; texture-; temperate-fruits; fruit-crops
OD: Prunus-persica
BT: Prunus; Rosaceae; Rosales; dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta; pl=
ants
CC: QQ050; QQ110; FF020
CD: Crop-Produce; Food-Storage-and-Preservation; Plant-Breeding-and-Genetic=
s
PT: Journal-article
UD: 980116
AN: 970311392

nti
  -R. conorii antibody activity in human and animal sera.

  -R; Mansueto-P; Mansueto-S

  Via Palabanda 12, 09123 Cagliari, Italy.
SO: Igiene-Moderna. 1996, 105: 1, 75-84; 30 ref.
PY: 1996
LA: Italian
LS: English
AB: The authors report the results of monitoring for anti-Rickettsia conori=
i
  antibodies in human and canine populations of western Sicily, Italy, in 1=
967
  -88. Dogs represent an epidemiological sentinel for evaluating the preval=
ence
  of R. conorii infection and the intensity of circulation of rickettsiae i=
n
  vector ticks. Seropositivity in dogs was strictly correlated with the num=
ber of
  clinical cases of boutonneuse fever (Mediterranean spotted fever). Fluctu=
ations
  of seropositivity and corresponding clinical and asymptomatic cases provi=
ded
  important data for the understanding of the epidemiology of Mediterranean
  spotted fever in western Sicily.

Record 416 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Prevalence of anti-Rift-Valley-fever IgM antibody in abattoir workers i=
n the
  Nile delta during the 1993 outbreak in Egypt.
AU: Abu-Elyazeed-R; El-Sharkawy-S; Olson-J; Botros-B; Soliman-A; Salib-A;
  Cummings-C; Arthur-R
AD: Risk Assessment Branch, U.S. Naval Medical Research, Unit No. 3, Cairo,
  Egypt.
SO: Bulletin-of-the-World-Health-Organization. 1996, 74: 2, 155-158; 8 ref.
PY: 1996
LA: English
LS: French
AB: In the early summer of 1993, an outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) was
  reported among both humans and animals in Aswan Governorate, Upper Egypt.=
 To
  determine whether RVF infection had spread to the Nile delta region of th=
e
  country, the authors carried out a cross-sectional survey of 1181
  occupationally exposed abattoir workers (97% males; age range 10-72 years=
) in
  15 governorates of Egypt in November 1993. The overall prevalence of anti=
-RVF
  virus IgM antibody was 2% (range: 0% (7 governorates) to 10%). The highes=
t
  prevalences were in Ismailia (10%) and Sharqiya (8%) Governorates. None o=
f the
  seropositive subjects reported having experienced an episode of fever in =
the 2
  months prior to the study. The prevalence of antibody was significantly h=
igher
  (P<0.05) among workers employed in high-risk jobs such as cutting animals=
'
  throats (relative risk (RR =3D 2.24)) and handling animal parts (RR =3D 2=
.37). The
  findings suggest that abattoir workers represent a useful sentinel popula=
tion
  for surveillance of RVF.
DE: abattoir-workers; disease-prevalence; IgM-; immunoglobulins-; serologic=
al
  -surveys; occupational-hazards; livestock-; zoonoses-; epidemiology-
OD: arboviruses-; Rift-valley-fever-virus; man-
GE: Egypt-
BT: viruses; Phlebovirus; arboviruses; Bunyaviridae; Homo; Hominidae; Prima=
tes;
  mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Middle-East; Developing-Countrie=
s;
  Mediterranean-Region; North-Africa; Africa
CC: VV200; VV500; VV900
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Environm=
ental
  -Health; Health-and-Safety-at-Work
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0042-9686
UD: 980116

Record 417 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Epidemiology and control of Fasciola hepatica in the Middle-Atlas, Moro=
cco.
AU: Khallaayoune-K; Stromberg-BE; Gray-GD (ed.); Uilenberg-G
AD: Departement de Parasitologie, Institut Agronomique et Veterinaire Hassa=
n II,
  BP 6202, Rabat-Instituts, Morocco.
SO: Parasitology research in Africa. Proceedings of an IFS Workshop, Bobo
  -Dioulasso, Burkina Faso, 6-10 November 1995. 1996, 189-202; 44 ref.
PB: International Foundation for Science (IFS); Stockholm; Sweden
PY: 1996
LA: English
LS: French
AB: In Morocco, Fasciola hepatica is a major cause of economic losses to
  livestock producers. A 3-year epidemiological study was carried out in th=
e
  rangeland of the Middle-Atlas to determine the seasonal pattern in the
  transmission of F. hepatica and an adequate strategy of control. The infe=
ction
  was followed in sentinel sheep and the dynamics of the snail intermediate=
 host,
  Lymnaea truncatula, was monitored. High fluke burdens were recorded in bo=
th
  lambs and ewes in the autumn and winter, suggesting that transmission occ=
urred
  in late spring. Fluke burdens ranged from 1 to 302 in ewes and from 1 to =
345 in
  lambs. Infection with >200 flukes was always fatal. Snail populations
  correlated with fluke transmission as observed in the sentinel sheep.
  Evaluation of the production advantages afforded by a strategic anthelmin=
tic
  treatment showed that lambs treated with a flukicide gained 13.07 kg over=
 7
  months, whereas the control group gained only 6.67 kg over the same perio=
d. The
  mortality rates were 20 and 0% in the control and treated groups, respect=
ively.
  Similar advantages were observed in pregnant ewes. The lambing rate was
  significantly higher in the treated group (92%) than in the control group
  (76%). The average lamb birth weight was 3.5 kg in the group of treated e=
wes
  and was only 2.8 kg in the control group.
DE: livestock-; epidemiology-; disease-control; surveys-; parasitoses-;
  parasites-; helminths-
OD: Fasciola-hepatica; sheep-; Lymnaea-truncatula
GE: Morocco-
ID: Parasitology-research-in-Africa
BT: Fasciola; Fasciolidae; Digenea; Trematoda; Platyhelminthes; invertebrat=
es;
  animals; Ovis; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; Lymnaea; Lymnaeidae; Gastropoda; Mollusca; Mediterranean-Region=
;
  Developing-Countries; Francophone-Africa; Maghreb; North-Africa; Africa
CC: LL820; HH400
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Control=
-by
  -Chemicals-and-Drugs
PT: Conference-paper
IB: 91-85798-45-2
UD: 980116
AN: 970805477

Record 418 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Risk analysis: true hydatids infection in dogs from feeding untreated s=
heep
  and goat meat.
CA: New Zealand, Ministry of Agriculture.
SO: Sentinel-Wellington. 1996, No. 58, 8.
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: An issue that arose during the preparation of a national pest managemen=
t
  strategy for Echinococcus granulosus in New Zealand, was whether controls=
 on
  the feeding of sheep and goat meat to dogs needed to be applied. A quanti=
tative
  and qualitative risk analysis concluded that the feeding of untreated she=
ep and
  goat meat to dogs would be very unlikely to lead to the transmission of E=
.
  granulosus.

Record 419 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Assays with commercially produced Trichogramma (Hymenoptera:
  Trichogrammatidae) to determine suitability for obliquebanded leafroller
  (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae) control.
AU: Lawson-DS; Nyrop-JP; Reissig-WH
AD: Department of Entomology, Cornell University, New York State Agricultur=
al
  Experiment Station, Geneva, NY 1446, USA.
SO: Environmental-Entomology. 1997, 26: 3, 684-693; 32 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: Laboratory assays were used to compare the ability of commercially prod=
uced
  Trichogramma spp. to parasitize eggs of Choristoneura rosaceana in the
  laboratory and field in New York State. T. platneri parasitized more eggs=
 per
  egg mass than did T. pretiosum or T. minutum produced by either of 2
  insectaries. T. minutum produced at 1 insectary caused significantly more=
 host
  mortality by host-feeding and repiercing than by parasitism. Variation in
  parasitoid performance from different insectaries and among shipments fro=
m the
  same insectary was common. Young egg masses were more heavily parasitized=
 than
  old egg masses. Parasitism increased as the number of conspecific female
  Trichogramma spp. placed on the same host increased, but the number of eg=
gs
  parasitized per female decreased. Exposure of host egg masses to female
  Trichogramma spp. prevented additional oviposition in the same egg mass b=
y
  conspecific, ovipositionally experienced females but had no effect on
  parasitism by conspecific, ovipositionally naive females. The method used=
 to
  attach sentinel egg masses to foliage influenced parasitism rates. Moiste=
ning
  the leaf with water and adhering the egg mass to the moistened leaf had t=
he
  least impact. Inundative releases of Trichogramma spp. into an apple orch=
ard
  paralleled laboratory assays by showing greater parasitism of C. rosacean=
a egg
  masses by T. platneri than with T. minutum. However, extreme differences
  observed in field performance between the 2 species was not predicted fro=
m the
  assays.
DE: natural-enemies; assays-; oviposition-; apples-; biological-control; co=
ntrol
  -; fruit-crops; pest-control; agricultural-entomology; habitats-; orchard=
s-
OD: malus-pumila; Choristoneura-rosaceana; Trichogramma-pretiosum; Trichogr=
amma
  -minutum; Trichogramma-; arthropods-; Malus-
GE: New-York; USA-
ID: Trichogramma-platneri
BT: Malus; Rosaceae; Rosales; dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta; pla=
nts;
  Choristoneura; Tortricidae; Lepidoptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrat=
es;
  animals; Trichogramma; Trichogrammatidae; Hymenoptera; Middle-Atlantic-St=
ates
  -of-USA; Northeastern-States-of-USA; USA; Developed-Countries; North-Amer=
ica;
  America; OECD-Countries
CC: FF600; HH100; LL820
CD: Pests,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Plants; Biological-Control;
  Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article

Record 420 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Dispersal of Trichogramma platneri Nagarkattii (Hym., Trichogrammatidae=
)
  from point-source releases in an apple orchard in California.
AU: McDougall-SJ; Mills-NJ
AD: Center for Biological Control, University of California, 201 Wellman Ha=
ll,
  Berkeley, CA 94720-3112, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Applied-Entomology. 1997, 121: 4, 205-209; 21 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: The dispersal of Trichogramma platneri from a central release point was
  evaluated in an apple orchard during 1992, in relation to time and the nu=
mber
  of parasitoids released. Dispersal was monitored by parasitism of Cydia
  pomonella eggs, with 5400, 16 200 or 32 400 parasitoids/release tree. The
  higher release rates of T. platneri resulted in greater parasitism of sen=
tinel
  eggs during the first 3 days, increasing from about 18% for a release rat=
e of
  5400 to about 36% for a release rate of 32 400. T. platneri parasitized a
  greater percentage of sentinel eggs on the north side of the tree. Parasi=
tism
  of sentinel eggs declined by 50% during the second 3-day period following
  release. Parasitism of sentinel eggs declined from a mean of 62% at the p=
oint
  -source to <10% 14 m away during the first 3 days after release.
DE: dispersal-; parasitoids-; biological-control-agents; release-; natural
  -enemies; insect-pests; insect-control; apples-; biological-control; cont=
rol-;
  fruit-crops; temperate-fruits; biology-; pest-control; agricultural-entom=
ology;
  habitats-; orchards-
OD: malus-pumila; Cydia-pomonella; arthropods-; Malus-
GE: California-; USA-
ID: Trichogramma-platneri
BT: Malus; Rosaceae; Rosales; dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta; pla=
nts;
  Cydia; Tortricidae; Lepidoptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; anim=

  Pacific-States-of-USA; Western-States-of-USA; USA; Developed-Countries; N=

  -America; America; OECD-Countries; Trichogramma; Trichogrammatidae; Hymen=

Record 421 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Fallacies in ecological risk assessment practices.
AU: Power-M; McCarty-LS
AD: Department of Agricultural Economics, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg,
  Manitoba, R3T 2N2, Canada.
SO: Environmental-Science-and-Technology. 1997, 31: 8, 370-375; 44 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: Since the advent of ecological risk assessment, there has been insuffic=
ient
  time to develop a consensus that guides its use in science-based policy
  activities. As a part of risk assessment, science and policy have been co=
mbined
  to create several myths that hold important consequences for environmenta=
l
  decision making. These myths -a "sensitive," or "sentinel," species can b=
e
  selected and appropriately used; chronic data are better suited to regula=
tory
  needs than are acute data; and controlled experimental data can be accura=
tely
  extrapolated to the field- continue because of failures to clearly distin=
guish
  between the roles and uses of science and policy. Though possibly useful =
from a
  policy perspective, these myths are not scientifically valid. Issues of
  representativeness, lack of ecological knowledge, and variability questio=
n
  their scientific foundation. Science has played an important part in deve=
loping
  assessment techniques, but it cannot address all the issues surrounding
  environmental risk management. Policy must be used to make management-rel=
ated
  decisions. Therefore, the most important role for science is the provisio=
n of
  information to be used in environmental decision making.
DE: risk-assessment
ID: environmental-impact-assessment
CC: ZZ330
CD: General-Ecology
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0013-936X
UD: 980116
AN: 971913722

  http://sladmin.silverplatter.com:4416/lpascripts/holdlink.pl?lpa.holdlink=

ssnurl=3D
  FLD1%3DISSN%2B%28ISSN%29%26CNT%3D50%26SAB1%3D$$LPAISSN&lpa.holdlink.isbnu=

Record 422 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Serogrouping and topotyping of Sudanese and United States strains of
  epizootic hemorrhagic disease virus using PCR.
AU: Aradaib-IE; Mohammed-MEH; Mukhtar-MM; Ghalib-HW; Osburn-BI
AD: Department of Veterinary Pathology, Microbiology and Immunology, School=
 of
  Veterinary Medicine, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, USA.
SO: Comparative-Immunology,-Microbiology-and-Infectious-Diseases. 1997, 20:=
 3,
  211-218; 31 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
LS: French
AB: A polymerase chain reaction (PCR) protocol for detection of USA epizoot=
ic
  haemorrhagic disease virus (EHDV) serotype 1 (EHDV-1) and serotype 2 (EHD=
V-2)
  ribonucleic acid was evaluated for detection of Sudanese EHDV strains. EH=
DV
  serotype 5 (EHDV-5) and EHDV isolate 318 (untyped), designated (EHDV-318)=
, from
  sentinel calves at the Khartoum University farm, Sudan, were used. RNA fr=
om
  EHDV-5 and EHDV-318 and a number of EHDV field isolates, propagated in ce=
ll
  cultures, were detected by the PCR-based assay. The specific 387 bp PCR
  products were presented on ethidium-bromide stained agarose gel. Specific=
ity of
  the PCR products was confirmed by chemiluminescent hybridization with a n=
on
  -radiolabelled internal probe. An amplification product was not detected =
when
  the PCR-based assay was applied to RNA from 6 serotypes of bluetongue vir=
us BTV
  and total nucleic acid extracts from uninfected BHK-21 cells. It is concl=
uded
  that the EHDV-PCR assay could detect Sudanese as well as USA strains of E=
HDV
  and may be useful as an additional diagnostic assay to the current proced=
ures
  used for virus isolation and detection of EHDV infections.
DE: serotypes-; strains-; diagnostic-techniques; RNA-; polymerase-chain
  -reaction; viral-diseases
OD: bluetongue-virus; epizootic-haemorrhagic-disease-of-deer-virus; cattle-=

  arboviruses-
GE: Sudan-; USA-
BT: Orbivirus; Reoviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants;

a
  -South-of-Sahara; Africa; ACP-Countries; Least-Developed-Countries; Devel=
oping
  -Countries; Developed-Countries; North-America; America; OECD-Countries

Record 424 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: BVD virus transmission following attenuated vaccines to BVDV seronegati=
ve
  cattle.
AU: Cortese-VS; Ellis-J; Whittaker-R; Grooms-DL; Brock-KV
AD: Pfizer Animal Health, Exton, Pennysylvania, USA.
SO: Large-Animal-Practice. 1997, 18: 5, 18-24; 23 ref.
PY: 1997
LA: English
AB: Ten 500-lb calves were immune suppressed with 40 mg/animal of dexametha=
sone
  for 5 days and were vaccinated with 1 of 2 different vaccines (Resvac 4 o=
r
  Somubac) containing a modified live bovine viral diarrhoea virus (BVDV; N=
ADL
  strain) fraction on the third day of dexamethasone treatment. Nasal swabs=
 and
  whole blood samples were obtained from vaccinated and commingled nonvacci=
nated
  calves on a weekly basis for virus isolation. In Study 2, 17 BVDV seroneg=
ative
  adult Angus cows were vaccinated via intramuscular injection with a modif=
ied
  live BVDV (NADL strain) vaccine and commingled with 5 sentinel seronegati=
ve
  cows. Serum was collected from the cows 105 days before vaccination, on t=
he day
  of vaccination, and 6 weeks, 12 weeks and 6 months after vaccination. Vir=
us
  neutralizing antibody tests were performed using the NADL strain of BVDV =
as the
  reference strain. There was no evidence of significant viral transmission=
 by
  any group of vaccinated calves during the 180 day study period.
DE: live-vaccines; vaccination-; disease-transmission; viral-diseases
OD: bovine-diarrhoea-virus; cattle-
BT: Pestivirus; Flaviviridae; viruses; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyl=
a;
  mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
UD: 980116
AN: 972218461

Record 425 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Recent studies on bluetongue in Peninsular Malaysia.
AU: Hassan-SS; Gard-GP; Polkinghorne-I; Abdul-Rahman-MA; Hussin-AA; Maizan-=
M;
  Zainal-M; Kadariah-A; St-George-TD (ed.); Peng-KeGao
AD: Veterinary Research Institute, PO Box 369, 30740 Ipoh, Perak, Malaysia.
SO: Bluetongue disease in Southeast Asia and the Pacific: Proceedings of th=
e
  First Southeast Asia and Pacific Regional Bluetongue Symposium, Greenlake
  Hotel, Kunming, P.R. China, 22-24 August 1995. 1996, 23-27; 15 ref.
PB: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR); Canb=
erra;
  Australia
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: Bluetongue is endemic in Malaysia. Bluetongue virus infection is widesp=
read
  among local cattle, buffalo, sheep and goats, but the clinical form of th=
e
  disease is inapparent in indigenous sheep. The Veterinary Research Instit=
ute
  and CSIRO collaborated to investigate bluetongue in Malaysia. Sentinel gr=
oups
  of cattle and sheep were established at 4 sites throughout the country. B=
lood
  samples from these sentinels were collected over a 9 month observation pe=
riod.
  16 viruses isolated from heparinised blood samples were typed by the plaq=
ue
  -reduction test into 6 different serotypes: BLU 1, 2, 3, 9, 16 and 23. Th=
e
  pathogenicity of 5 bluetongue virus serotypes was studied by intravenous
  inoculation of 0.5 ml heparinised blood of the original isolates into pro=
genies
  of imported commercial Merino-Border Leicester crossbred sheep, shown to =
be
  free of bluetongue antibodies by AGID and competitive ELISA. Although vir=
us
  titres in their blood ranged from 102.4 to 101.9 ECE LD50/0.5 ml, the she=
ep did
  not show any clinical signs.
DE: sentinel-animals; serotypes-; pathogenicity-; livestock-; epidemiology-
OD: arboviruses-; cattle-; sheep-; bluetongue-virus
GE: Malaysia-
ID: Southeast-Asia-and-Pacific-Regional-Bluetongue-Symposium
BT: viruses; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Ovis; Orbivirus; Reoviridae; arboviruses; Commonwealth=
-of
  -Nations; ASEAN-Countries; Developing-Countries; South-East-Asia; Asia;
  Threshold-Countries

Record 426 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Bluetongue virus research in Indonesia.
AU: Sendow-I; Sularsih; Soleha-E; Pearce-M; Bahri-S; Daniels-PW; St-George-=
TD
  (ed.); Peng-KeGao
AD: Research Institute for Veterinary Science, PO Box 52, Bogor 16114, Indo=
nesia.
SO: Bluetongue disease in Southeast Asia and the Pacific: Proceedings of th=
e
  First Southeast Asia and Pacific Regional Bluetongue Symposium, Greenlake
  Hotel, Kunming, P.R. China, 22-24 August 1995. 1996, 28-32; 21 ref.
PB: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR); Canb=
erra;
  Australia
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: Sentinel herds were established in West Java, Bali, Nusa Tenggara Timur=
 and
  Irian Jaya in 1988-93 to determine the presence and seasonality of blueto=
ngue
  virus (BLU) infection in Indonesia. BLU was isolated from Culicoides fulv=
us, C.
  orientalis (in a pooled sample with C. fulvus), C. peregrinus and Anophel=
es
  spp. collected near sentinel sites, and from the blood of the sentinel ca=
ttle.
  Serological results indicated that seroconversion mostly occurred at the =
end of
  the wet season and that large ruminants had a higher prevalence of antibo=
dy
  than small ruminants. BLU serotypes 1, 3, 7, 9, 12, 16, 21 and 23 were
  successfully isolated from blood from apparently healthy cattle. The
  pathogenicity of BLU isolates was determined in local and imported sheep.

Record 428 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Investigation of bluetongue disease in the Bayannur Meng of Inner Mongo=
lia.
AU: Guo-ZhaiJun; Hao-JuCai; Chen-JianGuo; Li-ZhiHua; Zhang-KhaiLi; Hu-YuLin=
g; Li
  -Gen; Pu-Long; Guo-ZJ; Hao-JC; Chen-JG; Li-ZH; Zhang-KL; Hu-YL; Li-G; Pu-=
L; St
  -George-TD (ed.); Kegao-P
AD: Bayannur Meng Station of Veterinary Medicine, Linhe 015500, Inner Mongo=
lia,
  China.
SO: Bluetongue disease in Southeast Asia and the Pacific: Proceedings of th=
e
  First Southeast Asia and Pacific Regional Bluetongue Symposium, Greenlake
  Hotel, Kunming, P.R. China, 22-24 August 1995. 1996, 80-83; 8 ref.
PB: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR); Canb=
erra;
  Australia
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: Serological testing for bluetongue antibodies was carried out by agar g=
el
  immunodiffusion in 7 cities and counties of the Bayannur Meng of Inner Mo=
ngolia
  [Nei Menggu] in 1987. Among the samples from sheep, goats, Yellow cattle =
and
  camels, 23.2% (650 of 2799) were seropositive. This proportion was higher=
 among
  goats at 57.9% (523 of 903) and lower among sheep at 7.5% (127 of 1684), =
with
  no positive reactions found at all in camels. The seropositive sheep and =
goats
  showed no clinical signs. However, some sheep and goats in a sentinel her=
d
  showed elevated temperatures and changes in white blood cells. Through th=
e use
  of sentinel herds, bluetongue disease was found to occur under natural
  conditions in Bayannur during an epidemic period. Within the sentinel her=
d, the
  seropositive rate was 59.2%. After inoculation of embryonated chicken egg=
s and
  cell cultures as well as sheep experiments, bluetongue viruses were isola=
ted
  from sheep. These isolates were shown to be the same group as the Yunnan =
strain
  and USA BLU17.
DE: sentinel-animals; seroprevalence-; disease-prevalence; epidemiological
  -surveys; livestock-; epidemiology-; animal-diseases; viral-diseases
OD: arboviruses-; sheep-; goats-; cattle-; camels-; bluetongue-virus
GE: China-; Nei-Menggu
ID: Southeast-Asia-and-Pacific-Regional-Bluetongue-Symposium
BT: viruses; Ovis; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Capra; Bos; Camelus; Camelidae; Tylopoda; Orbivirus;
  Reoviridae; arboviruses; Developing-Countries; East-Asia; Asia; Northern-=
China;
  China
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals

Record 429 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Recent experiences with the monitoring of sentinel herds in Northern
  Australia.
AU: Melville-LF; Weir-R; Harmsen-M; Walsh-S; Hunt-NT; Pritchard-I; Daniels-=
PW;
  St-George-TD (ed.); Peng-KeGao
AD: Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries, Berrimah Agricultural Res=
earch
  Centre, PO Box 79, Berrimah, Darwin, NT 0828, Australia.
SO: Bluetongue disease in Southeast Asia and the Pacific: Proceedings of th=
e
  First Southeast Asia and Pacific Regional Bluetongue Symposium, Greenlake
  Hotel, Kunming, P.R. China, 22-24 August 1995. 1996, 100-105; 13 ref.
PB: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR); Canb=
erra;
  Australia
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: From 1990 to 1995, sentinel herds have been monitored regularly at 6
  locations throughout the Northern Territory of Australia. At all sites, m=
onthly
  serology has been conducted for the bluetongue (BLU), epizootic haemorrha=
gic
  disease (EHD) and Palyam group viruses. Weekly virus isolation was also c=
arried
  out at the site of greatest arboviral activity. During the observation pe=
riod,
  5 BLU serotypes, 5 EHD serotypes, 3 Simbu serogroup viruses, one bovine
  ephemeral fever (BEF) serogroup virus and other arboviruses were isolated=
 from
  the sentinel cattle. There was marked annual variation in the total numbe=
r and
  identity of viruses isolated. Seroconversions in the sentinel herds also =
showed
  annual variation.

Record 430 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Establishment of sentinel herds to monitor bluetongue in China.
AU: Li-HuaChun; Li-ZhiHua; Zhou-FuZhong; Ben-Jin; Zhang-KhaiLi; Liu-Gui; Li
  -ChunDi; Zhang-YingGuo; Shi-WenBao; Zhao-JinGuang; Wang-JiaYen; Du-JinWen=
; Kong
  -DeHui; Yang-GuangHua; Niu-BaoSheng; Niu-YongFu; Li-HC; Li-ZH; Zhou-FZ; B=
en-J;
  Zhang-KL; Liu-G; Li-CD; Zhang-YG; Shi-WB; Zhao-JG; Wang-JY; Du-JW; Kong-D=
H;
  Yang-GH; Niu-BS; Niu-YF; St-George-TD (ed.); Peng-KeGao
AD: Yunnan Tropical and Subtropical Animal Virus Diseases Laboratory, Jindi=
an
  650224, Kunming, China.
SO: Bluetongue disease in Southeast Asia and the Pacific: Proceedings of th=
e
  First Southeast Asia and Pacific Regional Bluetongue Symposium, Greenlake
  Hotel, Kunming, P.R. China, 22-24 August 1995. 1996, 106-109; 3 ref.
PB: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR); Canb=
erra;
  Australia
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: Sentinel herds have been used in Australia since 1969 to monitor endemi=
c
  virus infections of livestock. The technique, developed in Australia, has=
 since
  been introduced to New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Indonesia, Malaysia, US=
A,
  Canada, Central America and the Caribbean. In 1984, sentinel herds were
  established for a Sino-Australian ephemeral fever project in northeast Ch=
ina.
  In 1991, the first sentinel group for bluetongue, a disease first recogni=
sed in
  China's Yunnan Province in 1979, was established near Kunming. The herd
  comprised 15 goats and two cattle. This paper reports the establishment a=
nd
  operation of 3 more sentinel herds in Yunnan, in Shizong County and at tw=
o
  sites in Eshan County (12 cattle, 10 cattle and 15 goats, respectively).
DE: sentinel-surveillance; monitoring-; sentinel-animals; epidemiology-; an=
imal
  -diseases; viral-diseases
OD: arboviruses-; cattle-; sheep-; goats-; bluetongue-virus

ID: Southeast-Asia-and-Pacific-Regional-Bluetongue-Symposium
BT: viruses; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Ovis; Capra; Orbivirus; Reoviridae; arboviruses; Devel=
oping
  -Countries; East-Asia; Asia; South-Western-China; China

Record 431 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Epidemiological considerations in the study of bluetongue viruses.
AU: Daniels-PW; Sendow-I; Melville-LF; St-George-TD (ed.); Peng-KeGao
AD: CSIRO Australian Animal Health Laboratory, PO Bag 24, Geelong, Vic 3220=
,
  Australia.
SO: Bluetongue disease in Southeast Asia and the Pacific: Proceedings of th=
e
  First Southeast Asia and Pacific Regional Bluetongue Symposium, Greenlake
  Hotel, Kunming, P.R. China, 22-24 August 1995. 1996, 110-119; 43 ref.
PB: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR); Canb=
erra;
  Australia
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: Epidemiological studies of bluetongue viruses depend on understanding
  certain key features of the biology of the 24 serotypes. Bluetongue virus=
es are
  arboviruses, spread by insect vectors comprising some species in the genu=
s
  Culicoides. Among ruminant hosts, cattle are the major reservoir or ampli=
fier
  host, with only some breeds of sheep showing disease. Bluetongue viruses =
have
  both serotype and serogroup reactive antigens, and also show serological =
cross
  -reactions with other viruses. Serological tests must be interpreted on t=
he
  basis of this knowledge. The distribution of bluetongue viruses can be ma=
pped
  through serological surveys, but confirmation of virus presence in any ar=
ea
  requires virus isolation. Monitoring sentinel groups of animals at freque=
nt
  intervals allows both isolations and descriptions of seasonal patterns of
  seroconversions. Isolating viruses from insects allows identification of
  potential vectors, which must be confirmed by experimental transmission
  studies. Molecular virology allows comparison of sequence data from isola=
tes,
  so that the relationships between viruses in different geographical areas=
 can
  be studied. Pathogenicity does not depend on serotype, but must be tested
  experimentally to determine the potential economic problem constituted by
  viruses from a given area. The financial cost to farmers, a major conside=
ration
  in any epidemiological study, can only be determined by accurate on-farm
  records and accurate diagnosis of disease outbreaks. The application of t=
hese
  principles has been demonstrated in northern Australia and Indonesia, wit=
h good
  results. Much is now known of the distribution of the bluetongue virus gr=
oup in
  these neighbouring countries, and 8 bluetongue serotypes have been isolat=
ed
  from sentinel cattle in both countries.
DE: sentinel-animals; sentinel-surveillance; serotypes-; epidemiology-; rev=
iews-
OD: arboviruses-; Culicoides-; bluetongue-virus
ID: Southeast-Asia-and-Pacific-Regional-Bluetongue-Symposium
BT: viruses; Ceratopogonidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates;
  animals; Orbivirus; Reoviridae; arboviruses
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Conference-paper
IB: 1-86320-187-4
UD: 971016
AN: 970502407
WEBLH: Check for Holdings
  http://sladmin.silverplatter.com:4416/lpascripts/holdlink.pl?lpa.holdlink=
.url=3Dht
  tp://orbexpress.library.yale.edu/cgi
  -bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?DB%3Dlocal%26BOOL1%3Das%2Ba%2Bphrase%26&lpa.holdlink.i=
ssnurl=3D
  FLD1%3DISSN%2B%28ISSN%29%26CNT%3D50%26SAB1%3D$$LPAISSN&lpa.holdlink.isbnu=
rl=3DFLD1
  %3DISBN%2B%28ISBN%29%26CNT%3D50%26SAB1%3D$$LPAISBN&lpa.holdlink.issn=3D&l=
pa.holdli
  nk.isbn=3D1-86320-187-4

Record 432 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Australian National Arbovirus Monitoring Program - a model for studying
  bluetongue epidemiology in China.
AU: Kirkland-PD; Ellis-T; Melville-LF; Johnson-SJ; St-George-TD (ed.); Peng=
-KeGao
AD: Virology Laboratory, Elizabeth MacArthur Agricultural Institute, PMB 8,
  Camden, NSW 2570, Australia.
SO: Bluetongue disease in Southeast Asia and the Pacific: Proceedings of th=
e
  First Southeast Asia and Pacific Regional Bluetongue Symposium, Greenlake
  Hotel, Kunming, P.R. China, 22-24 August 1995. 1996, 95-99; 5 ref.
PB: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR); Canb=
erra;
  Australia
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: In Australia, bluetongue viruses have not caused outbreaks of disease i=
n
  sheep, but their presence continues to cause economic loss, especially in=
 terms
  of reduced markets for the export of live sheep, cattle, semen and embryo=
s. As
  some of the Australian serotypes of bluetongue virus (BLU) are capable of
  causing disease under experimental conditions, the sheep industry and ani=
mal
  health authorities are concerned that pathogenic BLU serotypes could ente=
r
  major sheep-raising areas. This paper describes an extensive, nationwide
  sentinel herd programme to monitor BLU epidemiology in Australia. This Na=
tional
  Arbovirus Monitoring Programme ensures the detection of any movements of
  bluetongue viruses towards the disease-free zone of southern and eastern
  Australia, and allows delimitation of virus-free zones from which animals=
 can
  be safely exported. To assist with the development of disease control
  programmes, a similar approach could be used to monitor the spread of
  bluetongue and other important vector-borne diseases in China and other
  countries.
DE: monitoring-; sentinel-surveillance; sentinel-animals; epidemiology-; an=
imal
  -diseases; viral-diseases
OD: arboviruses-; cattle-; bluetongue-virus
GE: Australia-
ID: Southeast-Asia-and-Pacific-Regional-Bluetongue-Symposium
BT: viruses; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Orbivirus; Reoviridae; arboviruses; Australasia; Ocean=
ia;
  Commonwealth-of-Nations; Developed-Countries; OECD-Countries
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Conference-paper
IB: 1-86320-187-4
UD: 971016

Record 433 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1996-1998/07

TI: Estimations of the divergence of bluetongue viral populations in Indone=
sia
  on the basis of virus isolation and PCR sequence analysis.
AU: Sendow-I; Pritchard-I; Daniels-PW; Eaton-BT; St-George-TD (ed.); Peng-K=
eGao
AD: Research Institute for Veterinary Science, PO Box 52, Bogor 16151, Indo=
nesia.
SO: Bluetongue disease in Southeast Asia and the Pacific: Proceedings of th=
e
  First Southeast Asia and Pacific Regional Bluetongue Symposium, Greenlake
  Hotel, Kunming, P.R. China, 22-24 August 1995. 1996, 203-207; 28 ref.
PB: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR); Canb=
erra;
  Australia
PY: 1996
LA: English
AB: In Indonesia, 7 serotypes of bluetongue virus (BLU) have been isolated,
  mostly from the blood of sentinel cattle, but also from Culicoides and
  Culicidae. 3 serotypes have also been isolated from locations some 4000 k=
m
  apart in eastern and western Indonesia. How mobile are virus populations =
in
  such a large country? Does each virus serotype comprise one large homogen=
ous
  national population or are there detectable differences at the molecular =
level
  among isolates from different sources? Are there detectable differences f=
rom a
  single source over relatively short periods of time? Differences may indi=
cate
  separate subpopulations of viruses, and give a means of studying aspects =
of
  their epidemiology. This study compared the nucleotide sequences of speci=
fic
  regions of the viral genomes of Indonesian isolates of bluetongue virus
  amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
DE: serotypes-; nucleotide-sequences; geographical-variation; epidemiology-=
;
  animal-diseases; viral-diseases
OD: arboviruses-; bluetongue-virus
GE: Indonesia-
ID: Southeast-Asia-and-Pacific-Regional-Bluetongue-Symposium
BT: viruses; Orbivirus; Reoviridae; arboviruses; South-East-Asia; Asia; ASE=
AN
  -Countries; Developing-Countries

CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
