Record 578 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1995

TI: Chronic toxicity and carcinogenicity of olestra in Swiss CD-1 mice.
AU: Lafranconi-WM; Long-PH; Atkinson-JE; Knezevich-AL; Wooding-WL
AD: Procter & Gamble Company, Winton Hill Technical Center, Cincinnati, OH =
45224
  -1703, USA.
SO: Food-and-Chemical-Toxicology. 1994, 32: 9, 789-798; 29 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: Two 2-year feeding studies were conducted in Swiss CD-1 mice to evaluat=
e the
  oral toxicity and carcinogenicity potential of olestra, a fat substitute
  consisting of a mixture of the hexa-, hepta- and octaesters of sucrose fo=
rmed
  with long-chain fatty acids. In a dose-response study, olestra was fed at=
 0,
  2.5, 5 or 10% (w/w) of the diet. In a companion study conducted to confir=
m
  equivocal effects, olestra was fed at 0 or 10% (w/w) of the diet. Olestra
  -containing diets were supplemented with fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E and=
 K to
  maintain the nutritional status of the olestra-fed mice at a level simila=
r to
  that of the control mice. 100 mice/sex were placed in each group. 50
  mice/sex/group were predesignated to the carcinogenicity portion of the s=
tudy
  and all survivors were killed at 24 months. 15 mice/sex/group were
  predesignated to the toxicity portion of the study and were killed at 12
  months. 35 mice/sex/group were included as sentinel animals to be used fo=
r
  monitoring nutritional status. Ophthalmoscopic examinations were conducte=
d
  before the test and at 12 and 24 months. Body weights and food consumptio=
n were
  estimated weekly. Gross observations, clinical chemistry and haematology =
data
  were obtained on mice killed at 12 and 24 months. Complete gross postmort=
em
  examinations, including organ weight and organ-to-body and organ-to-brain
  weight ratios were performed on all mice. Histopathology was conducted on=
 a
  full complement of tissues from all mice allocated to the carcinogenicity
  portions of the studies. There were no olestra-related effects on any of =
the
  endpoints measured, including survival, time-to-tumour or tumour incidenc=
e,
  ophthalmology, clinical chemistry, haematology, organ weights or tissue
  morphology. The results indicate that olestra is not toxic or carcinogeni=
c when
  fed to mice at up to 10% of the diet for 2 years.
DE: sucrose-polyester; lipid-substitutes; toxicity-; carcinogenesis-; safet=
y-;
  test-reports
OD: mice-
BT: Muridae; Rodents; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals
CC: VV140; LL510; LL900
CD: Human-Nutrition-Animal-Models; Animal-Nutrition-Physiology; Animal
  -Toxicology,-Poisoning-and-Pharmacology
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0278-6915
UD: 960116
AN: 951402972

Record 579 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1995

TI: Community-based survey versus sentinel site sampling in determining the
  nutritional status of rural children. Implications for nutritional survei=
llance
  and the development of nutritional programmes.
AU: Solarsh-GC; Sanders-DM; Gibson-CA; Gouws-E
AD: Department of Paediatrics and Child Health, Centre for Social and
  Development Studies, University of Natal, Durban, South Africa.
SO: South-African-Medical-Journal. 1994, 84: 11, 747-752; 21 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: A study of anthropometric status of children <5 years old, was conducte=
d in
  the Nqutu district of KwaZulu, South Africa, by means of a representative
  community-based sample and concurrent samples from primary health care cl=
inics,
  preschools and primary schools. The extent of acute nutritional stress in=
 the
  district was evaluated as an indication of the appropriateness of food re=
lief
  efforts in the region. The absence of wasting and the high prevalence of
  stunting (37.5%) suggested that the main problem was chronic socioeconomi=
c
  underdevelopment, rather than a severe or immediate lack of food. The fac=
t that
  <20% of households were in any way reliant on domestic production for the=
ir
  maize requirements explains why a drought that occurred did not have a gr=
eater
  impact on the nutritional state of this vulnerable group. The usefulness =
of
  clinics, preschools and schools as sites for the collection of anthropome=
tric
  data and the development of nutritional programmes was also evaluated.
DE: food-aid; socioeconomic-status; nutrition-programmes; nutrition-surveys=

  anthropometric-dimensions; schools-; health-centres; children-; nutrition=
al
  -state; rural-areas; rural-development

Record 580 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1995

TI: Field performance of some new American and Polish strawberry cultivars =
grown
  in Poland.
AU: Cieslinski-G; Klimczak-A; Smolarz-K; Maas-JL (ed.); Galletta-GJ
AD: Research Institute of Pomology and Floriculture, Skierniewice, Poland.
SO: Second international strawberry symposium, Beltsville, Maryland, USA, 1=
3-18
  September 1992. Acta-Horticulturae. 1993, No. 348, 171-176; 17 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: Nine strawberry (Fragaria X ananassa) cultivars were assessed in field
  trials during 1987-90. The experiment consisted of five American cultivar=
s
  (Allstar, Honeoye, Rosanne, Sentinel and Sumner), two Polish cultivars (K=
ama
  and Dukat), and Senga Sengana and Surprise des Halles as controls. Plants=
 were
  in matted rows at 0.3 X 0.8 m spacings. Among the American strawberry
  cultivars, Honeoye was the highest yielding and comparable to the standar=
d
  cultivar Senga Sengana (respectively, 12.9 and 16.3 kg/plot). Cultivars
  Allstar, Rosanne and Sentinel did not give satisfactory yields (respectiv=
ely,
  5.4, 4.6 and 4.5 kg/plot in 1989, and 7.2, 5.4 and 7.1 kg/plot in 1990).
  Sentinel and Sumner produced the largest fruit in almost all instances. H=
oneoye
  had the lowest Botrytis cinerea incidence and good fruit quality, even la=
te in
  the season.
DE: strawberries-; cultivars-; genetic-variation; disease-resistance; plant
  -pathogenic-fungi; varietal-reactions; assessment-; fruit-crops; small-fr=
uits;
  plant-pathology
OD: Fragaria-ananassa; Botrytis-cinerea; fungi-; Fragaria-
GE: Poland-
ID: Second-international-strawberry-symposium; International-strawberry-sym=
posium
BT: fungi; plant-pathogens; pathogens; Fragaria; Rosaceae; Rosales;
  dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta; plants; Botrytis; Deuteromycoti=
na;
  Eumycota; Central-Europe; Europe; Developed-Countries
CC: FF020
CD: Plant-Breeding-and-Genetics

Record 581 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1995

TI: Effect of acaricide control of Amblyomma variegatum ticks on bovine
  dermatophilosis on Nevis.
AU: Hadrill-DJ; Walker-AR
AD: Department of Agriculture, Charlestown, Nevis.
SO: Tropical-Animal-Health-and-Production. 1994, 26: 1, 28-34; 11 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
LS: French, Spanish
AB: A sentinel group of 8 cattle was compared with similar cattle in a herd=
 of
  90 of which 21 were pastured with the sentinels. The sentinel group was n=
ot
  treated with acaricide whilst the rest of the cattle were treated weekly =
with
  the organophosphate acaricide ethion (Bovinox). Weekly counts of adult ti=
cks
  and rankings of dermatophilosis were made on the sentinel herd. The remai=
ning
  cattle were observed for the presence of ticks and dermatophilosis prior =
to the
  weekly treatment with acaricide. All sentinel cattle became infested with=
 A.
  variegatum and dermatophilosis developed on all. Rank correlations of tic=
k
  numbers and dermatophilosis scores were between +0.34 and +0.98, varying =
with
  maturity of cattle and time during the trial. Incidence of dermatophilosi=
s on
  the cattle treated with acaricide was very low. Tick numbers on the senti=
nel
  animals were poorly correlated with rainfall and temperature. It is concl=
uded
  that acaricide treatment is the best option for controlling bovine
  dermatophilosis in Nevis.
DE: skin-diseases; disease-vectors; disease-control; ethion-; control-;
  acaricides-; infections-; transmission-; organophosphorus-acaricides; che=
mical
  -control; bacterial-diseases; tick-infestations; disease-transmission; ca=
ttle
  -diseases

cari
  -; Ixodidae-

rates;

Record 583 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1995

TI: Use of sentinel mallards for epizootiologic studies of avian botulism.
AU: Rocke-TE; Brand-CJ
AD: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, National Wildlife Health Research Cente=
r,
  6006 Schroeder Road, Madison, WI 53711, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Wildlife-Diseases. 1994, 30: 4, 514-522; 19 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: Captive-reared mallards (Anas platyrhynchos) were used as sentinels to =
study
  the epizootiology of avian botulism at the Sacramento National Wildlife R=
efuge,
  Willows, California, (USA) from 1986 to 1989. Sentinel mallards were wing
  -clipped, and 40 to 50 birds were confined in 1.6-ha enclosures in 11 sel=
ected
  wetlands (pools). Enclosures were searched intensively 3 to 4 times weekl=
y from
  July through October. Sick and dead wild sentinel birds were collected, k=
illed,
  and tested for type C botulism toxin. Botulism epizootics occurred in sen=
tinel
  mallards in 1986, and 1989, but only a few isolated cases of botulism wer=
e
  detected in 1988. In most epizootics, botulism also was detected simultan=
eously
  in wild birds using the same pool outside the enclosure. Outbreaks in sen=
tinels
  were started and perpetuated in the absence of vertebrate carcasses. A se=
x
  -specific trend in the probability of intoxication was detected, with mal=
es
  contracting botulism at a higher rate than females. Daily mortality rates=
 of
  sentinels during botulism epizootics ranged from 0.0006 to 0.0600, with a=
 mean
  of 0.0190. These rates would result in the daily loss of 0.6 to 60 birds =
per
  1000 at risk. The use of sentinel birds provided an effective means of
  gathering site-specific epidemiological data.
DE: wild-birds; bacterial-diseases; mortality-; waterfowl-; epidemiology-;
  botulism-
OD: Clostridium-botulinum; Anseriformes-
GE: USA-; California-
BT: birds; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; wild-animals; aquatic-animals;
  aquatic-organisms; Clostridium; Bacillaceae; Firmicutes; bacteria; prokar=
yotes;
  OECD-Countries; Developed-Countries; North-America; America; Pacific-Stat=
es-of
  -USA; Western-States-of-USA; USA
CC: LL820; PP710
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Biologi=
cal
  -Resources-Animal
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0090-3558
UD: 960116

Record 584 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1995

TI: Diversity within natural populations of Eastern equine encephalomyeliti=
s
  virus.
AU: Weaver-SC; Bellew-LA; Gousset-L; Repik-PM; Scott-TW; Holland-JJ
AD: Department of Biology, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, C=
A
  92093, USA.
SO: Virology-New-York. 1993, 195: 2, 700-709; 31 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: Genetic and phenotypic diversity were evaluated within two natural
  populations of Eastern equine encephalomyelitis (EEE) virus. The Maryland
  strain was isolated from Culiseta melanura and a sentinel bobwhite quail =
on the
  Delmerva peninsula. New York isolates were from songbirds and C. melanura
  collected near Syracuse. RNA fingerprinting revealed that most population=
s
  within infected hosts (unpassaged isolates) contained a consensus genotyp=
e
  along with minority genotypes differing in 1-3 T1)>-resistant oligonucleo=
tides.
  Mutation frequencies were similar to those reported for other RNA viruses=
,
  suggesting that the slow rate of EEE virus evolution is not limited by fi=
delity
  of genome replication. Within a given year, genetic diversity was general=
ly
  greater among geographically distant isolates than among those from the s=
ame
  transmission focus, suggesting that dispersal among EEE viruses in North
  America is not complete annually. Two of 3 bird isolates from Maryland an=
d New
  York contained relatively distantly related genotypes, differing in 15-19
  oligonucleotides. A 1985 mosquito isolate from Maryland contained stable,=
 small
  plaque variants which comprised the majority of that population. These sm=
all
  plaque variants differed by up to 8 T1-resistant oligonucleotides when co=
mpared
  with their large plaque counterparts. Temperature sensitive virus was not
  detected in 6 unpassaged mosquito isolates from Maryland and New York.
DE: rna-; nucleotide-sequences; disease-vectors; diversity-; wild-birds;
  epidemiology-; viral-diseases; horse-diseases
OD: birds-; colinus-virginianus; culiseta-melanura; equine-encephalomyeliti=
s
  -virus; arboviruses-; eastern-equine-encephalitis-virus; horses-
GE: USA-; Maryland-; New-York
BT: birds; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; wild-animals; Colinus; Phasianid=

Record 586 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Identification of cockroach aeroallergens from living cultures of Germa=
n or
  American cockroaches.
AU: Helm-RM; Burks-W; Williams-LW; Milne-DE; Brenner-RJ
AD: Arkansas Children's Hospital, 800 Marshall St., Little Rock, AR 72202, =
USA.
SO: International-Archives-of-Allergy-and-Immunology. 1993, 101: 4, 359-363=
; 25
  ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: The Air Sentinel and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) membranes were used=
 to
  capture airborne particles over living colonies of German (Blattella germ=
anica)
  or American (Periplaneta americana) cockroaches. Silver-stained SDS-PAGE =
gels
  revealed protein bands at 80, 55, 36 and several bands below the 33-kDa m=
arker.
  SDS-PAGE/immunoblots of PTFE eluates from German cockroach colonies incub=
ated
  with serum from cockroach-sensitive individuals revealed IgE-binding band=
s with
  apparent molecular weights of 36 and 80 kDa. Only the 36-kDa allergen and
  allergens below the 33-kDa marker were evident in the American PTFE eluat=
e.
  ELISA analysis with a monoclonal antibody assay identified the presence o=
f both
  Bla g I and Bla g II in the German PTFE eluate. No Bla g I or Bla g II co=
uld be
  identified in the American PTFE eluate. These studies demonstrate that in
  addition to Bla g I and Bla g II, several other aerosolized allergens bec=
ome
  airborne over cockroach colonies and may be important in the environment =
where
  cockroaches are abundant.
DE: antigens-; SDS-PAGE; arthropod-allergies; allergens-
OD: Dictyoptera-; Blattidae-; Blattellidae-; man-; Blattella-germanica;
  Periplaneta-americana; Blattaria-
ID: aeroallergens
BT: immunological-factors; antigens; insects; arthropods; invertebrates;

  vertebrates; Chordata; Blattella; Blattellidae; Periplaneta; Blattidae

Record 587 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Predictors of treatment failure in multiple drug-resistant falciparum
  malaria: results from a 42-day follow-up of 224 patients in Eastern Thail=
and.
AU: Fontanet-AL; Walker-AM
AD: Epidemiology Department, Harvard School of Public Health, Boston, MA, U=
SA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1993, 49: 4, 465-472=
; 13
  ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: The results of a 42-day follow-up of 224 patients treated with mefloqui=
ne
  for uncomplicated falciparum malaria in Eastern Thailand are reported. Th=
e risk
  of treatment failure among the 209 patients who completed the follow-up w=
as 57%
  (95% confidence interval [CI] =3D 50,64). The daily risk of treatment fai=
lure,
  estimated through an exponential survival function, was constant during t=
he
  follow-up period and equal to 1.9%. Five patient characteristics were fou=
nd to
  be independent and important predictors of treatment failure in a Cox
  proportional hazards model: a young age (adjusted hazard ratio [AHR] for =
an
  increase of 10 years of age =3D 0.75 [95% CI =3D 0.62,0.91]); a history o=
f a least
  3 documented mefloquine treatments in the past year (AHR =3D 1.89 [95% CI=
 =3D
  1.10,3.24]); a parasitaemia count > 100 000/=B5l (AHR =3D 1.80 [95% CI =
=3D
  1.16,2.80]); and a history of diarrhoea in the first 2 days after treatme=
nt
  (AHR =3D 1.51 [95% CI =3D 0.99,2.31]). A haemoglobin level _ 10 g/dl on t=
he day of
  consultation was also a predictor of treatment failure, but only among pa=
tients
  who had been treated for malaria in the past 120 days (AHR =3D 4.38 [95% =
CI =3D
  1.55,12.1]). These latter patients may have become anaemic while they wer=
e
  unsuccessfully treated with mefloquine for an infection by a multiple dru=
g
  -resistant strain in the past 120 days. It appears that the anaemic patie=
nts
  may have been included in the study at the time of recrudescence from thi=
s
  original infection, and they were at higher risk of treatment failure sin=
ce the
  strain infecting them was mefloquine-resistant. Children living in malari=
al
  areas, being at higher risk of treatment failure, may represent a suitabl=
e
  sentinel population for the monitoring of in vivo drug resistance.
DE: malaria-; children-; antimalarials-; antiprotozoal-agents; drug-resista=
nce;
  drug-therapy; mefloquine-; mathematical-models; prediction-; parasites-
OD: Plasmodiidae-; Apicomplexa-; Plasmodium-falciparum; man-; protozoa-
GE: Thailand-; Asia-; South-East-Asia
ID: treatment-failure
RN: 53230-10-7; 51773-92-3
BT: man; Homo; Hominidae; primates; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals=

  Haemospororida; Apicomplexa; Protozoa; invertebrates; Plasmodium; Plasmod=
iidae;
  ASEAN-Countries; Developing-Countries; South-East-Asia; Asia
CC: VV200; HH400; HH410
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Control-=

Record 588 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Trichogramma maidis host-searching in corn vs. pepper.
AU: Maini-S; Burgio-G; Carrieri-M
AD: Istituto di Entomologia 'G. Grandi', Universita degli Studi di Bologna,
  Italy.
SO: Redia. 1991, 74: 3, Appendix, 121-127; Paper presented at the 4th Europ=
ean
  Workshop 'Insect parasitoids', held in Perugia, Italy, 3-5 April 1991; 24=
 ref.
PY: 1991
LA: English
AB: Field studies in maize and pepper [Capsicum annuum] were carried out ne=
ar
  Bologna, northern Italy, to evaluate the foraging behaviour of Trichogram=
ma
  maidis, an egg parasitoid of the pyralid Ostrinia nubilalis. T. maidis (B=
ologna
  strain) was reared on eggs of the pyralid Ephestia kuehniella and release=
d at
  about the time of deposition of the 1st- and 2nd-generation egg masses of=
 O.
  nubilalis. Four releases in June and 4 in July were made in plots of both=
 crops
  at the rate of 6.4 adults/m2 over an area of 800 m2. Parasitization in th=
e
  plots was monitored using sentinel egg masses of O. nubilalis. A comparis=
on of
  total parasitization rates by T. maidis in maize and pepper showed that t=
here
  were no significant differences between the 2 crops in the 1st generation=
 of O.
  nubilalis (21.95% in maize versus 24.82% in pepper), but a significantly =
higher
  rate in pepper in the 2nd generation (10.71% versus 20.95%.). The absence=
 of
  parasitization in sentinel egg masses of O. nubilalis deployed in a contr=
ol
  plot 100 m from the release point showed that indigenous species of
  Trichogramma had no influence on the results. Given that the canopy of pe=
pper
  remains practically unchanged from spring to summer, it is suggested that=
 the
  most plausible explanation for the results is that the host-searching abi=
lity
  of T. maidis decreases as the leaf area index of maize increases. In both
  crops, there was an inverse relationship between distance from release po=
int
  and percentage parasitism of sentinel egg masses.
DE: Beneficial-insects; Natural-enemies; Insect-pests; Cereals-; Vegetables=
-;
  Biological-control-agents; Eggs-; Reproduction-; Maize-; food-plants; fie=
lds-;
  crops-; control-; biological-control; parasitoids-; hosts-; biology-; beh=
aviour
  -; agricultural-entomology
OD: Trichogrammatidae-; Hymenoptera-; Insects-; Pyralidae-; Lepidoptera-;
  Ostrinia-nubilalis; Capsicum-annuum; Trichogramma-maidis; arthropods-; Ep=
hestia
  -kuehniella; Zea-mays
GE: Italy-
ID: Insect-parasitoids
BT: beneficial-arthropods; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; beneficial
  -organisms; insects; arthropod-pests; pests; parasites; Hymenoptera;

  dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta; plants; Trichogramma;

Record 589 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Impact estimation through sentinel community surveillance: an affordabl=
e
  epidemiological approach.
AU: Ledogar-RJ; Andersson-N
SO: Third-World-Planning-Review. 1993, 15: 3, 263-272; 3 tab.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: Sentinel Community Surveillance using epidemiological methods has sever=
al
  advantages for planners in fields other than health. By separating and
  analysing the components of risk, it provides the detail necessary to mak=
e
  informal judgements concerning potential impact, and provides the possibi=
lity
  of returning to the same individuals to measure whether planning decision=
s had
  intended results. This repeatability factor, together with the larger num=
ber of
  respondents it provides per unit of expenditure, makes it more cost-effec=
tive
  than most other survey methods. Because it is community-based, the method=
ology
  provides a voice for communities in planning judgements while also having
  sufficient scientific rigour that its conclusions can interact with exist=
ing
  formal measurement systems. It is particularly suited to decentralized pl=
anning
  structures and is capable of assisting district and local leadership in m=
aking
  more scientific decisions. The method is applied to drought and structura=
l
  adjustment in Zimbabwe and education in Monrovia, Liberia.
DE: data-collection; surveys-; methodology-; community-development; plannin=
g-;
  rural-development
GE: Zimbabwe-; Liberia-
BT: SADCC-Countries; ACP-Countries; Anglophone-Africa; Commonwealth-of-Nati=
ons;
  Developing-Countries; Southern-Africa; Africa-South-of-Sahara; Africa; Le=
ast
  -Developed-Countries; West-Africa
CC: EE450; ZZ900; EE120
CD: Development-Aid,-Agencies-and-Projects; Techniques-and-Methodology; Pol=
icy
  -and-Planning-General

Record 590 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Post-epizootic activity of western equine encephalitis virus in Argenti=
na.
OT: Actividad post-epizootica del virus de la encefalitis equina del oeste =
en la
  Argentina.
AU: Aviles-G; Bianchi-TI; Daffner-JF; Sabattini-MS
AD: Instituto Nacional de Virosis Hemorragicas, Pergamino, Argentina.
SO: Revista-Argentina-de-Microbiologia. 1993, 25: 2, 88-99; 19 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: Spanish
LS: English
AB: Western equine encephalitis (WEE) virus activity was studied in Argenti=
na
  during 1983-86 by equine case notification and the use of sentinel animal=
s
  (horses, chickens and geese). Of the 13 foci of disease notified in Cordo=
ba and
  Santa Fe provinces, 5 of 16 presumed equine cases were shown to be positi=
ve by
  haemagglutination inhibition. 28 notified human cases were found to be
  negative. Anti-WEE virus antibody prevalence was lower in sentinel horses=
 in
  Cordoba province (4%) than Santa Fe province (13%). Antibodies disappeare=
d over
  a 12-month period in 40% of Santa Fe horses. 2 seroconversions were detec=
ted in
  Cordoba (December 1983-April 1986) and 9 in Santa Fe province (February 1=
984
  -July 1986). One of the horses from Cordoba also seroconverted with the
  enzootic WEE AG 80-646 virus. Due to recognized cross-reactivity between =
the 2
  virus strains, seroconversion was attributed to WEE epizootic virus. No v=
iral
  activity was detected in sentinel birds.
DE: disease-surveys; sentinel-animals; epidemics-; viral-diseases; serologi=
cal
  -surveys; epidemiology-; horse-diseases
OD: arboviruses-; Togaviridae-; Alphavirus-; man-; western-equine-encephali=
tis
  -virus; horses-; equine-encephalomyelitis-virus
GE: Argentina-; South-America
BT: experimental-animals; animals; viruses; pathogens; animal-viruses;
  arboviruses; Togaviridae; Homo; Hominidae; primates; mammals; vertebrates=
;
  Chordata; equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Alphavirus; Equus; Equidae;
  Perissodactyla; ungulates; Latin-America; Developing-Countries; South-Ame=
rica;
  America; Threshold-Countries

Record 591 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Avian hosts of St. Louis encephalitis virus in Pine Bluff, Arkansas, 19=
91.
AU: McLean-RG; Kirk-LJ; Shriner-RB; Townsend-M
AD: Division of Vector-Borne Infectious Diseases, National Center for Infec=
tious
  Diseases, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Fort Collins, CO 80=
522
  -2087, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1993, 49: 1, 46-52; =
26
  ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: An investigation of the extent of St. Louis encephalitis (SLE) virus
  activity in the avian population of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, USA, was conduc=
ted
  from 30 August 1991 to 5 September 1991, following a SLE epidemic that re=
sulted
  in 25 human cases. A total of 363 birds of 33 species were captured with =
ground
  -level mist nets at 4 sites along the northern edge of the city. No virus=
es
  were isolated from the serum of these birds, but 91 birds (25%) of 11 spe=
cies
  had detectable neutralizing antibody against the TBH-28 strain of SLE vir=
us in
  the constant-virus, serum-dilution, plaque-reduction neutralization test =
in
  Vero cell culture. No antibody to eastern equine encephalitis virus was
  detected. The prevalence of antibody to SLE virus varied among the sites =
from
  11 to 44%, but the prevalence at each site was influenced by the avian sp=
ecies
  composition. The 2 most abundant species captured in the city, the Americ=
an
  robin (Turdus migratorius) (43%) and house sparrow [Passer domesticus] (4=
2%),
  also had the highest prevalence of antibody. Nine other bird species were
  serologically positive but at significantly lower rates than for the abun=
dant
  species. The antibody prevalence was higher in immature birds (27%) than =
in
  adult birds (15%), but the antibody titres were higher in adult birds tha=
n in
  immature ones. The overall SLE antibody prevalence and the prevalence for=
 house
  sparrows were significantly higher than the average prevalence for avian =
hosts
  studied during previous SLE epidemics. Therefore, house sparrows would be=
 a
  good choice for a local sentinel species.
DE: serological-surveys; hosts-; wild-birds; epidemics-; epidemiology-
OD: arboviruses-; Flavivirus-; Ploceidae-; St-Louis-encephalitis-virus; Tur=
dus
  -migratorius; Passer-domesticus; birds-
GE: USA-; Arkansas-; North-America
ID: Turdidae; St-Louis-encephalitis
BT: birds; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; wild-animals; viruses; pathogens=
;
  Flaviviridae; animal-viruses; arboviruses; Passeriformes; Flavivirus; Tur=
dus;
  Muscicapidae; Passer; Ploceidae; North-America; America; Developed-Countr=
ies;
  OECD-Countries; West-South-Central-States-of-USA; Southern-States-of-USA;=
 USA;

Record 592 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Epidemiology of cutaneous leishmaniasis at a focus monitored by the
  Multinational Force and Observers in the northeastern Sinai Desert of Egy=
pt.
AU: Fryauff-DJ; Modi-GB; Mansour-NS; Kreutzer-RD; Soliman-S; Youssef-FG
AD: Department of Research Sciences, U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit No.3,
  Cairo, Egypt.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1993, 49: 5, 598-607=
; 28
  ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: A longitudinal epidemiological study of cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL)
  transmission was conducted between July 1989 and June 1991 in a 1200-km2 =
sector
  of the northeastern Sinai Desert monitored by the Multinational Force and
  Observers (MFO), an international peace keeping mission between Egypt and
  Israel. The occurrence of human cases, sandfly density, rodent collection=
 and
  isolations of Leishmania confirmed only 1 of 4 surveyed locations as a
  significant focus of CL transmission. Phlebotomus papatasi, the only
  anthropophilic sandfly species encountered at this focus, comprised >96% =
of the
  sandfly population and attained human landing densities exceeding 100
  sandflies/person/h during 1990. Seasonal activity of this species ranged =
from
  April to November, with highest densities occurring during the period May
  -September. A peak promastigote infection rate of 2.4% (13 of 534) was ob=
served
  in P. papatasi during July 1990. 12 of the 60 (20%) persons at risk durin=
g the
  6 months of intense sandfly activity at this site developed lesions consi=
stent
  with CL; Leishmania major was isolated from 9 (75%) of these cases. L. ma=
jor
  infection was acquired by 2 of 22 (9%) sentinel hamsters used during the =
same
  period. >97% of the 897 wild rodents trapped at this site were desert ger=
bil
  species. L. major was the only Leishmania isolated from human, sandfly, w=
ild
  rodent (Gerbillus pyramidum), and sentinel hamster infections that origin=
ated
  at site Check point 1-Delta, the focus of CL transmission within jurisdic=
tion
  of the MFO. The altered ecology of this area, created by construction of =
a dam,
  may contribute significantly to the transmission dynamics of CL at this f=
ocus.
DE: disease-vectors; wild-animals; cutaneous-leishmaniasis; leishmaniasis-;
  epidemiology-; parasites-
OD: Diptera-; Psychodidae-; Phlebotominae-; Sarcomastigophora-; Trypanosoma=
tidae
  -; man-; rodents-; Phlebotomus-papatasi; Leishmania-major; protozoa-
GE: Egypt-; North-Africa; Middle-East
ID: Gerbillus-pyramidum; military-medicine; Sinai
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; Dip=
tera;
  Psychodidae; Protozoa; Kinetoplastida; Sarcomastigophora; Homo; Hominidae=
;
  primates; mammals; Phlebotomus; Phlebotominae; Leishmania; Trypanosomatid=
ae;
  North-Africa; Africa; Developing-Countries; Mediterranean-Region; Middle-=
East

Record 593 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Elimination of mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) from a breeding colony using
  serological testing and isolation.
AU: Fleming-DM
AD: University of Cambridge, Central Biomedical Services, Addenbrooke's Hos=
pital
  Site, Hills Road, Cambridge, CB2 2SP, UK.
SO: Scandinavian-Journal-of-Laboratory-Animal-Science. 1993, 20: 4, 209-214=
; 17
  ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: A colony of Peruvian mice backcrossed onto C3H/He mice was found by
  serological testing to be infected with MHV. 10 male and 10 female mice o=
f the
  most recent backcross generation were selected and tested for antibodies =
to
  MHV. 19 animals were serologically positive. These were passed into a pos=
itive
  pressure isolator via a Virkson bath. MF1 sentinel mice in a second isola=
tor
  unit were exposed to dirty litter from the backcross from day 13 onwards.=
 Blood
  samples were taken from the sentinels on days 27, 34, 48 and 76. The back=
cross
  mice produced their first litter on day 43. No seroconversion occurred in=
 the
  sentinel mice, or in offspring of the backcross. Animals from the origina=
l
  colony tested at the same age and time as the backcross offspring had
  seroconverted to MHV.
DE: laboratory-animals; viral-diseases; liver-diseases; hygiene-; disease-c=
ontrol
OD: Coronaviridae-; murine-hepatitis-virus; mice-
ID: hepatitis-virus
BT: experimental-animals; animals; animal-viruses; pathogens; viruses;
  Coronavirus; Coronaviridae; Muridae; rodents; mammals; vertebrates; Chord=
ata

Record 594 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Serologic surveillance for the Lyme disease spirochete, Borrelia
  burgdorferi, in Minnesota by using white-tailed deer as sentinel animals.
AU: Gill-JS; McLean-RG; Shriner-RB; Johnson-RC
AD: Department of Microbiology, University of Osteopathic Medicine and Heal=
th
  Sciences, 3200 Grand Avenue, Des Moines, IA 50312, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Clinical-Microbiology. 1994, 32: 2, 444-451; 42 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: To determine the effectiveness of white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virgini=
anus)
  as sentinel animals in serological surveillance programmes for B. burgdor=
feri,
  ELISA and Western immunoblotting analyses were performed on 467 deer seru=
m
  samples. The seropositivity rate in the ELISA was 5% for the 150 samples
  collected at the 3 sites in which the tick Ixodes scapularis was absent. =
The 3
  sites with established I. scapularis populations had a seropositivity rat=
e of
  80% for 317 samples. Results were similar for 2 closely situated sites, o=
ne
  with an established I. scapularis population and one without; these sites=
 were
  only 15 km apart. Rates of seropositivity were significantly higher in ye=
arling
  and adult deer than in fawns. The mean numbers of bands seen on Western
  immunoblots were 3.0 for samples negative in the ELISA and 13.8 for sampl=
es
  positive in the ELISA; all of these samples were collected from sites in =
which
  I. scapularis was established. At sites in which I. scapularis was absent=
, the
  mean numbers of bands seen were 1.6 for samples negative in the ELISA and=
 8.2
  for samples positive in the ELISA. There were 14 different B. burgdorferi
  antigens that reacted with >50% of the ELISA-positive samples from areas =
with
  I. scapularis. A 19.5-kDa antigen reacted with 94% of the ELISA-positive
  samples. Reactivity against OspA and OspB was weak and infrequent (2%).
  Serological analysis of white-tailed deer sera appears to be an accurate =
and
  sensitive surveillance method for determining whether B. burgdorferi is p=
resent
  in specific geographic locations.
DE: tickborne-diseases; zoonoses-; serological-surveys; sentinel-animals; w=
ild
  -animals; disease-vectors; ELISA-; immunoblotting-; Lyme-disease; epidemi=
ology-
OD: Spirochaetaceae-; mammals-; Cervidae-; Acari-; Ixodidae-; Borrelia
  -burgdorferi; Odocoileus-virginianus; Ixodes-scapularis; Odocoileus-
GE: USA-; Minnesota-; North-America
BT: experimental-animals; animals; vertebrates; Chordata; Spirochaetales;
  Gracilicutes; bacteria; prokaryotes; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals;
  ungulates; Arachnida; arthropods; invertebrates; Metastigmata; Acari; Bor=
relia;
  Spirochaetaceae; Odocoileus; Cervidae; Ixodes; Ixodidae; North-America;
  America; Developed-Countries; OECD-Countries; Lake-States-of-USA; North-C=
entral
  -States-of-USA; USA; West-North-Central-States-of-USA
CC: VV200; LL820; PP710; ZZ900
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Parasite=

Record 595 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: One medicine-practical application for non-sedentary pastoral populatio=
ns.
AU: Ward-DE; Ruppanner-R; Marchot-PJ; Hansen-JW
SO: Nomadic-Peoples. 1993, No. 32, 55-63; 1 fig.; 10 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: This paper examines some theoretical and practical aspects of deliverin=
g
  human and animal health care to rural societies. Economic theory of the p=
rivate
  versus the public good argues against the integration of human and animal
  health interventions. Judging by the scarcity of documented examples of
  beneficial integration of human and veterinary health care interventions,
  economic theory may indeed bear out what is found in practice. Explanatio=
ns for
  this apparent lack of integration of human and animal health care systems=
 may
  stem from the Western oriented, anthropocentric way development specialis=
ts
  approach the problem. Examples are described where appropriate and financ=
ially
  viable animal health delivery systems are designed on sound veterinary
  epidemiology and ethnoveterinary principles. These examples may serve as =
a
  basis for designing integrated human and veterinary health care intervent=
ions.
  Available tools, such as geographic information systems, sentinel cases, =
ethno
  -veterinary research and pictogram/computer systems, which may be used to
  design more cost effective interventions, are discussed.
DE: health-care; animal-health; services-; integrated-systems; veterinary
  -services; rural-development
CC: LL800; EE120; UU350; VV000
CD: Animal-Health-and-Hygiene-General; Policy-and-Planning-General; Health
  -Services; Human-Health-and-Hygiene-General
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0822-7942
UD: 950516
AN: 941802462

Record 596 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Surveillance of mosquitoes and arbovirus infection at the Ross River Da=
m
  (Stage 1), Australia.
AU: Barker-Hudson-P; Kay-BH; Jones-RE; Fanning-ID; Smythe-LD; Hudson-P-Bark=
er-
AD: PO Box 42828, Casuarina, Darwin, Northern Territory 0810, Australia.
SO: Journal-of-the-American-Mosquito-Control-Association. 1993, 9: 4, 389-3=
99;
  17 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: The temporal and spatial abundance of the mosquito fauna of the Ross Ri=
ver
  Dam (Stage 1) in northern Queensland, Australia, between January 1984 and
  September 1985, are described. Culex annulirostris, Anopheles annulipes s=
.l.,
  Mansonia uniformis, M. septempunctata and the non-dam breeding Aedes vigi=
lax
  were the major species collected by dry ice-supplemented light traps set =
at
  various distances from the edge of the reservoir. To estimate the level o=
f
  arbovirus activity in these different zones, sentinel chicken flocks were=
 bled
  4 times a year and their antibody conversion rates determined by the
  haemagglutination-inhibition test. Although mosquito abundance at sites c=
lose
  to the reservoir were 1.5-6.1 times higher than at the more distant sites=
,
  arbovirus conversion rates, particularly to the alphaviruses Ross River a=
nd
  Sindbis, varied according to zone and year, suggesting that risk of infec=
tion
  was no greater around the dam than elsewhere. Other arboviruses thought t=
o have
  been present were Getah, Murray Valley encephalitis, Kunjin, Kokobera, Al=
fuy
  and Edge Hill.
DE: disease-vectors; surveys-; epidemiology-; population-ecology; ecology-;
  serological-surveys; dams-; sentinel-animals
OD: Diptera-; arboviruses-; Alphavirus-; Flavivirus-; Togaviridae-; fowls-;
  Culex-annulirostris; Anopheles-annulipes; Mansonia-uniformis; Aedes-vigil=
ax;
  Culicidae-; Ross-River-virus; Sindbis-virus; Getah-virus; Murray-Valley
  -encephalitis-virus
GE: Australia-; Queensland-
ID: Mansonia-septempunctata; Kunjin-virus; Kokobera-virus; Alfuy-virus; Edg=
e
  -Hill-virus

  -gallus; Gallus; Phasianidae; Galliformes; birds; vertebrates; Chordata;
  poultry; domestic-animals; Culex; Culicidae; Diptera; Anopheles; Mansonia
  -Diptera; Aedes; Alphavirus; Flavivirus; OECD-Countries; Australasia; Oce=
ania;
  Commonwealth-of-Nations; Developed-Countries; Australia

Record 597 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Influenza virus subtypes in aquatic birds of eastern Germany.
AU: Suss-J; Schafer-J; Sinnecker-H; Webster-RG
AD: Institut fur Veterinarmedizin, Bundesgesundheitsamt, Diedersdorfer Weg =
1,
  12277 Berlin, Germany.
SO: Archives-of-Virology. 1994, 135: 1-2, 101-114; 39 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: In a 12-year surveillance (1977-1989) in eastern Germany, avian influen=
za A
  viruses were isolated from 236 feral ducks, 89 other wild birds, 735 dome=
stic
  ducks from a single farm, and from 193 Pekin ducks used as sentinels for
  populations of wild aquatic (mainly sea) birds. The efficiency of virus
  isolation was 9.9% overall - 8.7% in wild ducks, 0.9% in other wild birds=
, and
  38% in Pekin ducks. The use of sentinel ducks in wild pelagic bird coloni=
es
  improved virus detection rates 5-fold, suggesting an advantage in ecologi=
cal
  studies. Among the 40 different combinations of haemagglutinin and
  neuraminidase subtypes H6N1 (23.6%) was the most common for all species
  followed by H4N6 (11%). Among individual species the frequency profiles
  included H2N3 (20.8%) and H4N6 (20.3%) in wild ducks; H7N7 (22.3%), H4N6
  (24.4%) and H2N3 (10.4%) in sentinel Pekin ducks; and H6N1 (34.8%) and H6=
N6
  (15.1%) in domestic ducks on the single farm. Using sentinel birds for
  serological assays it was possible to trace an 'influenza season' in fera=
l swan
  populations, beginning in August and continuing through the winter months=
.
  Comparison of subtype distribution of influenzaviruses for Europe and Nor=
th
  America showed significant differences. This indicates 2 geographically
  distinct gene pools of influenzaviruses in birds.
DE: wild-animals; disease-surveys; serotypes-; strain-differences; epidemio=
logy
  -; viral-diseases
OD: ducks-; Anseriformes-; swans-; avian-influenzavirus; birds-
GE: Germany-
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Anatidae; Anseriformes; birds;
  Orthomyxoviridae; viruses; animal-viruses; pathogens; OECD-Countries; Dev=
eloped
  -Countries; European-Communities; Western-Europe; Europe
CC: LL820; PP710
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Biologi=
cal
  -Resources-Animal
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0304-8608
UD: 950516
AN: 942204390

  http://sladmin.silverplatter.com:4416/lpascripts/holdlink.pl?lpa.holdlink=

Record 598 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Bluetongue virus isolations from vectors and ruminants in Central Ameri=
ca
  and the Caribbean.
AU: Mo-CL; Thompson-LH; Homan-EJ; Oviedo-MT; Greiner-EC; Gonzalez-J; Saenz-=
MR
CA: Interamerican Bluetongue Team.
AD: School of Veterinary Medicine, University of Wisconsin, 2015 Linden Dri=
ve
  West, Madison, WI 53706, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1994, 55: 2, 211-215; 15 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: A regional prospective study of the epidemiology of bluetongue virus (B=
TV)
  serotypes covering 11 countries in Central America and the Caribbean took=
 place
  between 1987 and 1992. Active surveillance revealed BTV infection to be e=
ndemic
  in the absence of confirmed indigenous cases of bluetongue. During the st=
udy,
  >300 BTV isolations were obtained from cattle and sheep. Results of the e=
arlier
  years of the study were summarized, and surveillance activities from Nove=
mber
  1990 to February 1992 were evaluated. 45 BTV isolations were made during =
this
  time, 44 from sentinel cattle and 1 from a ram with clinical signs compat=
ible
  with contagious ecthyma. Virus isolation from potential vectors also was
  attempted, yielding a further 9 BTV isolates from parous Culicoides insig=
nis
  and C. pusillus, 2 from blood-engorged C. filarifer, and 1 epizootic
  haemorrhagic disease virus type-2 isolate from parous C. pusillus. BTV-1 =
was
  the predominant serotype in Central America in 1991, after an apparent ab=
sence
  of 1 year in the sentinel animals. Other serotypes in Central America at =
that
  time included BTV-3 and -6. In Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, BT=
V-4
  became the predominant serotype, without detection of BTV-8 and BTV-17, w=
hich
  were common in recent years of the study. The serotypes found in the Cari=
bbean
  Basin continued to have marked differences from those in North America. T=
he
  importance of viewing bluetongue as an infection, the distribution of whi=
ch is
  determined principally by ecological factors, is emphasized.
DE: viral-diseases; disease-prevalence; disease-surveys; vectors-; disease
  -vectors; cattle-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: cattle-; sheep-; culicoides-; orbivirus-; bluetongue-virus; ruminants-
GE: Caribbean-; Central-America
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; ungulates; Ovis; Ceratopogonidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods;
  invertebrates; arboviruses; pathogens; Reoviridae; viruses; animal-viruse=
s;
  Orbivirus; America
CC: LL820; LL860
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Animal
  -Disorders-Not-caused-by-Organisms
PT: Journal-article

Record 599 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Definition of vector-free areas by monitoring of sentinel cattle for
  multiple arbovirus infections.
AU: Kirkland-PD; Kennedy-DJ; Williams-CF; Hornitzky-CL; Gleeson-A; Batty-EM=
;
  Walton-TE (ed.); Osburn-BI
AD: Elizabeth MacArthur Agricultural Institute, NSW Department of Agricultu=
re,
  Camden, Australia.
SO: Bluetongue, African horse sickness, and related orbiviruses: Proceeding=
s of
  the Second International Symposium. 1992, 924-932; 3 ref.
PB: CRC Press Inc.; Boca Raton; USA
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: This paper demonstrates how data collected from the monitoring of arbov=
irus
  infections of sentinel cattle and sheep can be applied to the definition =
of the
  distribution of the vector, Culicoides brevitarsis, and be a simple, cost
  -effective tool for the definition of vector free areas. These data can a=
lso be
  used to assess differences in vector preferences for sheep and cattle and=
 to
  compare the transmission of bluetongue (BLU) viruses to sheep and cattle.
DE: viral-diseases; disease-transmission; sentinel-animals; disease-vectors=

Record 600 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Results of a decade's monitoring for orbiviruses in sentinel cattle pas=
tured
  in an area of regular arbovirus activity in Northern Australia.
AU: Gard-GP; Melville-LF; Walton-TE (ed.); Osburn-BI
AD: Bureau of Rural Resources, Canberra, ACT, Australia.
SO: Bluetongue, African horse sickness, and related orbiviruses: Proceeding=
s of
  the Second International Symposium. 1992, 85-89; 7 ref.
PB: CRC Press Inc.; Boca Raton; USA
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Each summer rainy season, from 1981 until 1990, a sentinel herd of
  approximately 20 young steers was pastured near Darwin, Northern Territor=
ies,
  and exposed to natural infection by arboviruses. During the 10 year obser=
vation
  period, 7 serotypes of bluetongue (BLU) virus (BLU-1, BLU-3, BLU-9, BLU-1=
5, BLU
  -16, BLU-21, BLU-23), four of epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus (2, 5,=
 7 and
  8) and 4 Palyoma serogroup viruses (BC, CVG, DAG and MAR) were recovered =
from
  the cattle. Striking variations in annual virus activity, infection rates=
, and
  viraemias were recorded.

  epidemiology-; cattle-diseases; sheep-diseases

;

Record 602 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Epidemiologic studies of bluetongue viral infections in Indonesian live=
stock.
AU: Sendow-I; Daniels-PW; Soleha-E; Sukarsih; Walton-TE (ed.); Osburn-BI
AD: Research Institute for Veterinary Science, Bogor, Indonesia.
SO: Bluetongue, African horse sickness, and related orbiviruses: Proceeding=
s of
  the Second International Symposium. 1992, 147-154; 11 ref.
PB: CRC Press Inc.; Boca Raton; USA
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Clinical bluetongue (BLU) disease has not yet been diagnosed in Indones=
ian
  ruminants, although sheep imported from Australia have suffered severe
  mortalities with clinical signs and pathology consistent with BLU.
  Seroepidemiological studies have shown that BLU virus infections are wide=
spread
  throughout the islands of Indonesia, affecting buffaloes, cattle, sheep, =
and
  goats. Livestock at higher altitudes have a lower prevalence of infection=
s than
  those in low altitude areas. Hence, the absence of clinical diseases is i=
n
  spite of the presence of large populations of naive animals. Studies with
  sentinel groups of animals are showing that there is a seasonal pattern o=
f
  infections with BLU group viruses, with a pattern emerging of viral activ=
ity at
  the end of the wet season. Confirmed isolations of BLU viruses in Indones=
ia
  allow more precise seroepidemiological studies to be conducted, in which =
the
  geographical distribution and species susceptibility for the isolated ser=
otypes
  are determined.
DE: viral-diseases; goat-diseases; disease-prevalence; epidemiology-; seaso=
ns-;
  disease-surveys; livestock-; cattle-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: cattle-; bluetongue-virus; buffaloes-; sheep-; goats-
GE: Indonesia-
BT: domestic-animals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Bos; Bovidae; ruminan=
ts;
  Artiodactyla; mammals; ungulates; Orbivirus; arboviruses; viruses; Reovir=
idae;
  animal-viruses; pathogens; Bubalus; Ovis; Capra; Developing-Countries; AS=
EAN
  -Countries; South-East-Asia; Asia
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals

Record 603 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Comparison of a "dipstick" ELISA and competitive ELISA for detection of
  antibodies to bluetongue viruses in cattle blood samples.
AU: Afshar-A; Dulac-GC; Riva-J; Walton-TE (ed.); Osburn-BI
AD: Agriculture Canada, ADRI, Nepean, Ont., Canada.
SO: Bluetongue, African horse sickness, and related orbiviruses: Proceeding=
s of
  the Second International Symposium. 1992, 575-579; 11 ref.
PB: CRC Press Inc.; Boca Raton; USA
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: A blocking (b) ELISA that uses bluetongue (BLU) antigen bound to
  nitrocellulose paper (NC) mounted in the windows of "Cerex" dipsticks and=
 a MAb
  against a group-specific antigen of BLU virus is described for the detect=
ion of
  anti-BLU virus antibodies. In the absence of anti-BLU virus antibody in t=
he
  test sample, BLU virus antigen sites were reactive with MAb as indicated =
by a
  coloured dot. Anti-BLU virus antibody, if present in the test sample bloc=
ked
  the antigen, preventing its reaction with MAb in the subsequent step of t=
he
  test and no colour reaction developed. The performance of the dipstick bE=
LISA
  in detecting anti-BLU virus antibodies in field blood eluate samples, pre=
pared
  from whole blood dried on filter paper, from 395 BLU virus-free cattle in
  Canada and 265 sentinel cattle in Florida, USA, was evaluated and compare=
d with
  the standard competitive (c) ELISA. The specificity of the dipstick bELIS=
A
  compared favourably with that of the cELISA (100%) for samples collected =
from
  Canada. The sensitivity and specificity of the dipstick bELISA for sample=
s
  collected from cattle in Florida were lower and relative to the cELISA re=
sults
  were in the order of 88.2% and 88.9%, respectively.
DE: diagnostic-techniques; viral-diseases; immunological-techniques; monocl=
onal
  -antibodies; ELISA-; immunodiagnosis-; cattle-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: cattle-; bluetongue-virus; sheep-
GE: Canada-; USA-
BT: antibodies; immunoglobulins; immunological-factors; Bos; Bovidae; rumin=
ants;
  Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; ungulates; Orbivir=
us;
  arboviruses; viruses; Reoviridae; animal-viruses; pathogens; Ovis; Develo=
ped
  -Countries; Commonwealth-of-Nations; North-America; America; OECD-Countri=
es
CC: LL820; ZZ900
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Techniq=
ues
  -and-Methodology

Record 604 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Prevalence and incidence of bluetongue viruses in the Caribbean basin:
  serologic and virologic findings.
AU: Thompson-LH; Mo-CL; Oviedo-MT; Homan-EJ; Walton-TE (ed.); Osburn-BI
AD: USDA, ARS, ABADRL, Laramie, WY, USA.
SO: Bluetongue, African horse sickness, and related orbiviruses: Proceeding=
s of
  the Second International Symposium. 1992, 106-113; 11 ref.
PB: CRC Press Inc.; Boca Raton; USA
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Between May 1987 and December 1990, a total of 288 BLU virus isolations=
 were
  made in Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama,
  Trinidad, Tobago, Barbados, Puerto Rico, Dominican Republic and Jamaica a=
nd the
  serotypes were determined. Tables are given of the country, date, number =
of
  isolations and serotypes found. BLU group-specific antibody was detected =
by
  agar gel immunodiffusion in all sentinel herds to one or more of the sero=
types
  BLU-1, BLU-3, BLU-4, BLU-6, BLU-8 and BLU-11, BLU-12, BLU-14, and BLU-17.=
 It
  was concluded that BLU virus infection is widespread and enzootic in the
  Caribbean and Central American countries.

ock-;

Record 605 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Serologic survey and vector surveillance for bluetongue in southern Tur=
key.
AU: Burgu-I; Urman-HK; Akca-Y; Yonguc-A; Mellor-PS; Hamblin-C; Walton-TE (e=
d.);
  Osburn-BI
AD: Ankara Universities, Veterniner Facultesi, Mikrobioloji, Anibilim Dali
  Viroloji, Bilim Dali, Baskanligi, Ankara, Turkey.
SO: Bluetongue, African horse sickness, and related orbiviruses: Proceeding=
s of
  the Second International Symposium. 1992, 168-174; 7 ref.
PB: CRC Press Inc.; Boca Raton; USA
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: A serological study of BLU virus activity in southern Turkey was made
  between 1986 and 1989. Serum samples from more than 3000 cattle and sheep
  collected from 21 provinces, mainly in southern Turkey, were examined. An=
alysis
  of data for cattle suggests that BLU viruses have either been absent or h=
ave
  only occurred at very low levels since 1982. Although the prevalence of
  seropositive sheep declined with animals born from 1985 onwards, a signif=
icant
  proportion of these animals still seroconverted. Sentinel herds of cattle=
 and
  sheep confirmed the absence of bluetongue in these regions. Vector studie=
s
  carried out between September 1988 and 1989 recorded widespread prevalenc=
e of
  Culicoides imicola, a major virus vector, across southern Turkey. This ve=
ctor
  was active throughout the region in Spring, Summer and Autumn but was abs=
ent
  from all areas between December and February. It is concluded that BLU vi=
ruses
  are not endemic in southern Turkey, but that virus incursions do occur at
  intervals, possibly from areas to the southeast of the country. The prese=
nce of
  large numbers of young serologically naive animals, however, suggests tha=
t
  Turkey is now exceptionally vulnerable to future incursions of BLU viruse=
s.
DE: viral-diseases; disease-prevalence; seasons-; vectors-; disease
  -transmission; disease-surveys; disease-vectors; livestock-; epidemiology=
-;
  cattle-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: cattle-; sheep-; Culicoides-imicola; culicoides-; bluetongue-virus;
  arboviruses-; Diptera-; Ceratopogonidae-
GE: Turkey-
BT: domestic-animals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Bos; Bovidae; ruminan=
ts;
  Artiodactyla; mammals; ungulates; Ovis; Culicoides; Ceratopogonidae; Dipt=
era;
  insects; arthropods; invertebrates; Orbivirus; arboviruses; viruses;
  Reoviridae; animal-viruses; pathogens; Developing-Countries; Mediterranea=
n
  -Region; OECD-Countries; West-Asia; Asia
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Miscellaneous
IB: 0-8493-5169-3
UD: 950516
AN: 942205166

Record 606 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Iowa's Sentinel Project Researching Agricultural Injury Notification Sy=
stems
  (SPRAINS).
AU: Jones-SK; Anthony-D
AD: Bureau of Environmental Health, Division of Health Protection, Iowa
  Department of Public Health, Des Moines, IA 50319-0075, USA.
SO: Paper -American-Society-of-Agricultural-Engineers. 1993, No. 93-5010, 7=
 pp.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: A description and the major findings of the Sentinel Project Researchin=
g
  Agricultural Injury Notification Systems (SPRAINS) Project are presented;=
 this
  is a three-year statewide passive surveillance system funded by Centers f=
or
  Disease Control to identify agricultural related injury in Iowa, USA. It =
aimed
  to identify high-risk groups and circumstances for injury; identify poten=
tial
  educational, regulatory and engineering interventions to prevent farm inj=
ury;
  and to evaluate the effectiveness of established injury control measures =
by
  monitoring changes in injury rate. A computerized system was used to stud=
y
  nearly 8000 agriculture-related injuries, including nearly 250 fatalities=
.

on
GE: USA-; Iowa-
BT: North-America; America; Developed-Countries; OECD-Countries; Corn-Belt
  -States-of-USA; North-Central-States-of-USA; USA; West-North-Central-Stat=
es-of
  -USA

  http://sladmin.silverplatter.com:4416/lpascripts/holdlink.pl?lpa.holdlink=

  tp://orbexpress.library.yale.edu/cgi

Record 607 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Influence of habitat, season, and attractant on adult behavior of the
  screwworm (Diptera: Calliphoridae) in a tropical dry zone in Costa Rica.
AU: Parker-FD; Welch-JB; Matlock-RB Jr.
AD: Screwworm Research Laboratory, USDA-ARS, San Jose, Costa Rica.
SO: Journal-of-Economic-Entomology. 1993, 86: 5, 1359-1375; 38 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: Influence of attractant, season, habitat, temperature and physiological
  state of Cochliomyia hominivorax on daily activity and oviposition were
  examined during a 122-day study in a tropical dry forest in Costa Rica. F=
lies
  were marked and released. Numbers of flies visiting baits increased durin=
g the
  wet season and decreased during the dry season; 3 times more flies were
  observed at baits during the wet season than were observed during the dry
  season. An average of 33 females and 3 males was observed per day during =
the
  study. More flies (3.6 times) were attracted to rotting liver than to sen=
tinel
  sheep; many flies originally marked at liver failed to return and few of =
them
  oviposited on sentinel sheep. Females marked at sheep remained in the stu=
dy
  area longer. More females marked at sheep sites were recaptured (51.4-54.=
1%)
  than those marked at liver sites (32.3-44.7%). More than 6 times as many =
flies
  were observed at forest than at pasture sites. The physiological state of=
 the
  female influenced daily activity. High temperatures during midday (>31=B0=
C)
  depressed activity and decreased the number of foraging hours available f=
or
  flies during the dry season. Decreasing host resources and number of hour=
s
  available for foraging may be factors that limit screwworm populations in=
 the
  dry season.
DE: habitats-; ecology-; temperature-; diurnal-activity; behaviour-; ovipos=
ition
  -; myiasis-; tropical-forests; seasonality-; carrion-; sentinel-animals;
  population-ecology; dispersal-; environmental-factors; sheep-diseases
OD: Cochliomyia-hominivorax; sheep-; Cochliomyia-
GE: Costa-Rica
BT: experimental-animals; animals; Cochliomyia; Calliphoridae; Diptera; ins=
ects;
  arthropods; invertebrates; Ovis; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammal=
s;
  vertebrates; Chordata; ungulates; Threshold-Countries; CACM; Central-Amer=
ica;
  America; Developing-Countries; Latin-America
CC: LL820; VV200; LL300
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Parasit=
es,
  -Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Animal-Behaviour
PT: Journal-article

Record 608 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: The epidemiology of Lyme borreliosis in Italy.
AU: Cimmino-MA; Fumarola-D; Sambri-V; Accardo-S
AD: Cattedra di Reumatologia, Dipartimento di Medicina Interna, Universita =
di
  Genova, Viale Benedetto XV 6, 16132 Genova, Italy.
SO: Microbiologica. 1992, 15: 4, 419-424; 22 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Erythema migrans was described in Italy only in 1971, although Italian
  dermatologists were familiar with it a long time before. In 1983, the fir=
st
  case of Lyme borreliosis with multisystem involvement was identified. The
  endemic areas in Italy are the Ligurian coast, the province of Friuli Ven=
ezia
  Giulia, and the region surrounding the town of Bologna. Serosurveys of th=
e
  general population and of sentinel animals were useless in determining th=
e
  diffusion of Lyme borreliosis, whereas evaluation of people at risk of ti=
ck
  bites and patients with suggestive signs of symptoms was more effective. =
Among
  the clinical manifestations of Lyme borreliosis, cutaneous involvement is=
 4
  times more frequent than neuroborreliosis and arthritis is less frequent =
in
  Italy than in the USA.
DE: reviews-; Lyme-disease; epidemiology-
OD: Borrelia-burgdorferi; man-
GE: Italy-
ID: erythema-migrans
BT: Borrelia; Spirochaetaceae; Spirochaetales; Gracilicutes; bacteria;
  prokaryotes; Homo; Hominidae; primates; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Mediterranean-Region; Developed-Countries; European-Communities;=
 OECD
  -Countries; Southern-Europe; Europe
CC: VV200
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans

Record 609 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Efficient assessment of filariasis endemicity by screening for filarial
  antigenaemia in a sentinel population.
AU: Ramzy-RMR; Hafez-ON; Gad-AM; Faris-R; Harb-M; Buck-AA; Weil-GJ
AD: Centre for Research and Training on Vectors of Diseases, Ain Shams
  University, Cairo, Egypt.
SO: Transactions-of-the-Royal-Society-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 199=
4,
  88: 1, 41-44; 10 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: It has previously been reported that a MAb-based ELISA (AD12) is sensit=
ive
  and specific for bancroftian filariasis in Egypt. This assay was used in =
a
  sentinel population as a means of efficiently screening for filariasis
  endemicity. Antigen testing was performed with finger-prick blood collect=
ed
  during the day from 743 schoolchildren (ages 11-16 years). Students come =
from 5
  villages in Qalubia Governorate, 35 km north-east of Cairo, Egypt. The
  prevalence of filarial antigenaemia in the school was 17.2%. Antigenaemia=
 rates
  in children from the 5 villages were 29, 20, 18, 17 and 10% (non-uniformi=
ty
  significant by chi2 analysis). The data agreed with the Ministry of Healt=
h
  rankings of relative endemicity for the villages based on night blood sur=
veys.
  The village with the highest antigen prevalence in children was surveyed =
one
  year before this study. Prevalence rates of antigenaemia and microfilarae=
mia at
  that time for a different sample of children aged 11-16 years were 33% an=
d 22%,
  respectively. It is concluded that antigen detection in schoolchildren of=
 this
  age group is an efficient means of assessing filariasis endemicity in Egy=
pt.
DE: children-; epidemiology-; monoclonal-antibodies; serological-surveys;
  antigens-; ELISA-; immunodiagnosis-; filariasis-; parasites-; helminths-
OD: Wuchereria-bancrofti; man-
GE: Egypt-
ID: prevalence
BT: man; Homo; Hominidae; primates; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals=
;
  antibodies; immunoglobulins; immunological-factors; invertebrates; Wucher=
eria;
  Onchocercidae; Nematoda; North-Africa; Africa; Developing-Countries;
  Mediterranean-Region; Middle-East

Record 610 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Congenital scoliosis in calves suspected of Aino virus infection.
AU: Ishibashi-K; Tomishita-Y; Shirakawa-H; Takaya-M; Watanabe-A
AD: Chu Livestock Hygiene Service Centre, Fukuoka Prefecture, Hakata-ku, Fu=
kuoka
  816, Japan.
SO: Journal-of-the-Japan-Veterinary-Medical-Association. 1994, 47: 2, 87-90=
; 12
  ref.
PY: 1994
LA: Japanese
LS: English
AB: Between October, 1988, and March, 1992, congenital scoliosis was seen i=
n 11
  calves. Neutralizing antibody to Aino virus was detected in the serum of =
the 9
  pre-colostral and 2 post-colostral calves. Arthrogryposis was present in =
9
  cases, and hydrocephalus and cerebellar hypoplasia in 5 and 2, respective=
ly.
  Non-suppurative encephalomyelitis and regressive changes in skeletal musc=
les
  were seen histologically. A serological survey using sentinel calves show=
ed
  that outbreaks of Aino virus infection had occurred in August-October in =
1988
  and 1990.

Record 611 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Isolation of an influenza A virus of unusual subtype (H1N7) from pigs i=
n
  England, and the subsequent experimental transmission from pig to pig.
AU: Brown-IH; Alexander-DJ; Chakraverty-P; Harris-PA; Manvell-RJ
AD: Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries & Food, Central Veterinary Laborator=
y,
  Weybidge, New Haw, Addlestone, Surrey KT15 3NB, UK.
SO: Veterinary-Microbiology. 1994, 39: 1-2, 125-134; 19 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: A novel H1N7 influenza virus (A/swine/Eng/191973/92) was isolated from =
nasal
  swabs collected from 2 pigs on a farm where there had been recent clinica=
l
  disease due to infection with an H1N1 virus (A/swine/Eng/195852/92).
  Antigenically, the haemagglutinin (HA) of the H1N7 virus was related most
  closely to the HA of A/USSR/90/77, whilst the neuraminidase (NA) appeared=
 to be
  related most closely to the NA of A/equine/Prague/1/56 (H7N7). Pigs infec=
ted
  experimentally with A/swine/Eng/191973/92 developed mild clinical signs,
  excreted virus into the nasal passages for up to 9 days after infection,
  appeared normal at PM, transmitted the virus to sentinel pigs, but 7 out =
of 8
  pigs failed to seroconvert. It is suggested that the H1N7 virus has a low
  pathogenicity for pigs, resulting in limited virus multiplication which i=
s
  insufficient to stimulate a detectable primary humoral immune response.
DE: viral-diseases; experimental-infection; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-; swine-influenzavirus
GE: UK-; England-
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;

  European-Communities; British-Isles; Western-Europe; Europe; Commonwealth=
-of
  -Nations; Developed-Countries; OECD-Countries; Great-Britain; UK
CC: LL820

Record 612 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Diagnostic analysis of the prolonged bluetongue virus RNA presence foun=
d in
  the blood of naturally infected cattle and experimentally infected sheep.
AU: Katz-J; Alstad-D; Gustafson-G; Evermann-J
AD: Diagnostic Virology Laboratory, National Veterinary Services Laboratori=
es,
  Veterinary Services, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, USDA, Am=
es, IA
  50010, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Veterinary-Diagnostic-Investigation. 1994, 6: 2, 139-142; 29=
 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: Bluetongue virus (BTV) RNA was detected by the polymerase chain reactio=
n
  (PCR) in the blood of 24 naturally infected cattle for as long as 160 day=
s
  after the estimated date of infection. Blood samples from these animals a=
nd
  from 10 experimentally BTV-infected sheep, which also exhibited a prolong=
ed
  haematological BTV RNA presence, were concurrently evaluated for viral
  infectivity. Infectivity analyses were conducted using the sentinel sheep
  inoculation and embryonated chicken egg inoculation procedures. Blood spe=
cimens
  from the experimental sheep taken 50, 56, 71 and 89 days after BTV inocul=
ation
  were uniformly negative for viral infectivity despite their uniformly pos=
itive
  status with PCR evaluation. Three collections of blood from the naturally
  infected cattle at least 100, 135, and 160 days after infection also reve=
aled
  no recoverable viral infectivity but an initially high and progressively
  decreasing prevalence of BTV with the PCR technique. These retrospective
  epidemiological and prospective experimental approaches were concordant i=
n that
  both studies demonstrated consistent discrepancies between the viral
  infectivity and the PCR diagnostic data. The significance of these
  discrepancies is discussed with respect to Koch's postulates and with res=
pect
  to the possibility that the biological vector of BTV (Culicoides variipen=
nis)
  may recover BTV infectivity from PCR-positive but virus isolation-negativ=
e
  blood.
DE: diagnosis-; polymerase-chain-reaction; RNA-; latent-infections; disease
  -vectors; viral-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: bluetongue-virus; cattle-; sheep-; Culicoides-variipennis; arboviruses-=
;
  Diptera-; Ceratopogonidae-
BT: Orbivirus; arboviruses; viruses; Reoviridae; animal-viruses; pathogens;=
 Bos;
  Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals=
;
  ungulates; Ovis; Culicoides; Ceratopogonidae; Diptera; insects; arthropod=
s;
  invertebrates

Record 613 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Treatment of group E streptococci-induced lymphadenitis in swine by fee=
ding
  various concentrations of chlortetracycline: relation of antibody with
  prevalence of abscesses.
AU: Olson-LD; Miller-RB; Schlink-GT
AD: Department of Veterinary Pathology, College of Veterinary Medicine,
  University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65211, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1994, 55: 5, 650-653; 13 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: Consumption of chlortetracycline (CTC) at concentration of 220 mg/kg of=
 feed
  for 4 weeks in experiment 1 and at concentrations of 110 and 220 mg/kg fo=
r 3
  weeks and 440 mg/kg for 2 weeks in experiment 2 failed to eliminate
  streptococci-induced lymphadenitis from pigs referred to as principals.
  Abscesses, mostly in the head and neck, developed in at least a third of =
all
  swine in the various groups fed these CTC concentrations. Feeding of 220 =
mg of
  CTC/kg of feed in experiment 1 began 12 weeks after exposure of principal=
s to
  an untypeable group E streptococcus (GES; isolate 3X29A). In experiment 2=
,
  feeding of 110 and 220 mg of CTC/kg of feed began 5 weeks after exposure =
of
  principals to GES and feeding of 440 mg of CTC/kg of feed began 6 weeks a=
fter
  exposure. One or more cohabiting sentinel pigs of experiment 1 and one or=
 more
  sentinels in all groups of principals of experiment 2, except group 2,
  developed abscesses that were mostly in the head and neck. In experiment =
2,
  correlation between serum GES antibody titre and development of one or mo=
re
  abscesses in the principals was highly significant; however, correlation
  between antibody titre and abscesses in the sentinels was not significant=
.
DE: lymphadenitis-; chlortetracycline-; drug-therapy; abscesses-; antibioti=
cs-;
  bacterial-diseases; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-; Streptococcus-
RN: 57-62-5; 64-72-2
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;

  Streptococcaceae; Firmicutes

Record 614 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: The use of gamma irradiated Glossina austeni females as sentinel insect=
s for
  entomological monitoring in tsetse control programmes.
AU: Vreysen-MJB; Vloedt-AMV-van-der; Van-der-Vloedt-AMV
AD: Entomology Unit, Joint FAO/IAEA Programme, IAEA Laboratories, A-2444
  Seibersdorf, Austria.
SO: Revue-d'Elevage-et-de-Medecine-Veterinaire-des-Pays-Tropicaux. 1992, 45=
: 3
  -4, 303-309; 10 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
LS: French, Spanish
AB: A 60 Gy gamma treatment administered to females of G. austeni on day 2 =
or 9
  following emergence, and likewise, a 50 Gy gamma treatment given to pupae=
 on
  day 33 following larviposition, induced complete sterility in the female =
flies
  without altering their mating behaviour. Treated females remained recepti=
ve to
  mating with untreated males up to 15 days following emergence (mating res=
ponse
  of 84%). The timing of treatment (on day 33 post larviposition, on day 2 =
and 9
  following emergence) influenced significantly the dynamics of follicle
  development. Females, irrespective of their age when treatment was receiv=
ed,
  showed a normal development pattern of the follicles in position A1 and C=
1,
  i.e. normal vitellogenesis, maturation and ovulation. Female treated as p=
upae,
  however, revealed no visible signs of a development of follicles in posit=
ion B1
  and D1. From day 15 on, females displayed inactive ovaries characterized =
by
  atrophied oocytes and nurse cells. Treating females on day 2 or 9 of thei=
r
  adult life resulted in various degrees of development of the B1 and D1
  follicles. During laboratory cage tests, untreated males exposed to equal
  numbers of virgin untreated and treated females, showed no significant
  preference to mating with either type of female. A high degree of multipl=
e
  mating was observed when untreated and treated females were offered sever=
al
  mating opportunities. On day 9 following emergence, 24.0% of untreated an=
d
  23.8% of females treated with 60 Gy (on day 2), accepted a male during a =
4th
  mating occasion. The receptivity to remating decreased with a higher radi=
ation
  dose (120 Gy) and when treatment was given later in the female life (day =
5).
  The results of the laboratory experiments are discussed in view of deploy=
ing
  gamma sterilized female G. austeni for entomological monitoring in those =
areas
  where low fly densities exist and especially, to expose potential relic f=
ly
  pockets after control operations have been completed.
DE: monitoring-; control-programmes; ovarian-development; sterilization-; g=
amma
  -radiation; effects-; reproduction-; sterile-insect-release
OD: Diptera-; Glossinidae-; Glossina-austeni
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; Diptera; Glossina; Glossin=
idae
CC: VV200; LL820; HH700; TT300
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Parasite=
s,
  -Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Other-Control-Measu=
res;
  Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0035-1865
UD: 950516
AN: 940502005

Record 615 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Vector ecology of bluetongue viruses in Central America and the Caribbe=
an.
AU: Greiner-EC; Mo-CL; Tanya-V; Thompson-LH; Oviedo-MT; Walton-TE (ed.); Os=
burn
  -BI
CA: Interamerican Bluetongue Team.
AD: University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, USA.
SO: Bluetongue, African horse sickness, and related orbiviruses: Proceeding=
s of
  the Second International Symposium. 1992, 320-324; 7 ref.
PB: CRC Press, Inc.; Boca Raton, Florida; USA
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: A programme was begun in 1986 to examine the epidemiology of bluetongue
  (BLU) viruses throughout Central America, including Panama, and the Carib=
bean
  nations. Special insect collections were made at selected sentinel farms =
to
  allow detection of natural infections with BLU viruses. BLU isolates were=
 made
  from Culicoides insignis (12 656 parous and 979 blooded females were exam=
ined:
  1 isolate of BLU-3 from parous females at Turrialba, Costa Rica, 5 of BLU=
-6
  from Comayagua, Honduras), C. filarifer (1483 parous and 566 blooded: 2
  isolates of BLU-6 from blooded females at Pataluk, Guatemala), and C. pus=
illus
  (636 parous and 30 blooded females: 1 isolate of BLU-3 from parous female=
s at
  Mandeville, Jamaica). No isolates were made from C. phlebotomus (40 parou=
s and
  234 blooded), C. leopoldoi (245 parous), C. neopulicaris (54 parous), C. =
furens
  (21 parous), and C. foxi (3 parous). Isolates of the same BLU virus serot=
ypes
  were made from sentinel calves during the same time period.
DE: disease-vectors; parous-rates; sentinel-animals; epidemiology-
OD: Diptera-; Ceratopogonidae-; arboviruses-; Culicoides-insignis; Culicoid=
es
  -pusillus; bluetongue-virus; Culicoides-; Culicoides-furens; cattle-
GE: Central-America; Caribbean-; Honduras-; Guatemala-; Costa-Rica; El-Salv=
ador;
  Trinidad-and-Tobago; Barbados-; Puerto-Rico; Jamaica-
ID: Culicoides-filarifer; Culicoides-phlebotomus; Culicoides-leopoldoi;
  Culicoides-neopulicaris; Culicoides-foxi
BT: experimental-animals; animals; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; Dipt=
era;
  viruses; pathogens; Culicoides; Ceratopogonidae; Orbivirus; arboviruses;
  Reoviridae; animal-viruses; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammal=
s;
  vertebrates; Chordata; ungulates; America; Latin-America; CACM; Central
  -America; Developing-Countries; Threshold-Countries; ACP-Countries; Carib=
bean
  -Community; Commonwealth-of-Nations; Lesser-Antilles; Caribbean; Windward
  -Islands; Greater-Antilles

Record 617 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Transmission of murine viruses and mycoplasma in laboratory mouse colon=
ies
  with respect to housing conditions.
AU: Homberger-FR; Thomann-PE
AD: Institute of Laboratory Animal Science, University of Zurich,
  Winterthurerstr. 190, 8057 Zurich, Switzerland.
SO: Laboratory-Animals. 1994, 28: 2, 113-120; 21 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: Pathogen-free sentinel mice were placed in 7 animal rooms with differen=
t
  housing conditions and were serologically screened for antibodies to mous=
e
  hepatitis virus (MHV), pneumonia virus of mice (PMV), Sendai virus, reovi=
rus 3,
  Theiler's mouse encephalomyelitis virus (TMEV), ectromelia virus and Myco=
plasma
  pulmonis by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays, at intervals after
  introduction. The commonest detected antibody was against MHV, which was =
found
  in mice from 4 rooms, followed by PVM antibody in mice from 3 rooms.
  Seroconversion to Sendai virus and TMEV was detected in mice from one roo=
m
  each. No seroconversion to any of the antigens was found in 2 rooms. The =
common
  criteria of these 2 rooms were that they housed pathogen-free animals fro=
m a
  single source and that access to the rooms was, purposely or not, restric=
ted to
  people who had no contact with other mice. The study demonstrated the
  importance of husbandry and hygienic regimen on the prevalence of infecti=
ous
  agents in laboratory mice.
DE: laboratory-animals; disease-transmission; SPF-husbandry; viral-diseases=
;
  animal-housing
OD: murine-paramyxovirus; reovirus-; ectromelia-virus; Mycoplasma-pulmonis;=
 mice-
ID: mouse-hepatitis-virus; pneumonia-virus-of-mice; Theiler's-mouse
  -encephalomyelitis-virus
BT: experimental-animals; animals; Paramyxovirus; Paramyxoviridae; viruses;
  animal-viruses; pathogens; Reoviridae; Orthopoxvirus; Chordopoxvirinae;
  Poxviridae; Mycoplasma; Mycoplasmataceae; Mycoplasmatales; Mollicutes;
  Tenericutes; bacteria; prokaryotes; Muridae; rodents; mammals; vertebrate=
s;
  Chordata
CC: LL040; LL820
CD: Laboratory-Animal-Science; Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic
  -Diseases-of-Animals

Record 618 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Phylogenetic characterisation of bluetongue viruses from naturally-infe=
cted
  insects, cattle and sheep in Australia.
AU: McColl-KA; Gould-AR; Pritchard-LI; Melville-L; Bellis-G
AD: Australian Animal Health Laboratory, CSIRO, PO Bag 24, Geelong, Vic. 32=
20,
  Australia.
SO: Australian-Veterinary-Journal. 1994, 71: 4, 102-105; 22 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to detect bluetongue virus
  (BTV) in a number of clinical and insect samples collected in the Norther=
n
  Territory of Australia. Sequence analyses of the amplified BTV genes
  differentiated endemic Australian and exotic viruses. Two potential exoti=
c BTV
  were detected as a result of PCR analyses of blood from sentinel animals =
and of
  the insect vector, Culicoides wadai. The detection of BTV in C. wadai was=
 the
  first direct demonstration of the presence of BTV in this potential vecto=
r.
  Sequence data were used to differentiate between BTV 20 isolated in 1975 =
and 2
  isolates of the same serotype, isolated in 1992, and indicated that the l=
atter
  were probably a recent incursion into Australia from Indonesia; they had
  greater VP3 sequence homology to the BTV 9 (Java) than to Australian isol=
ates.
  PCR, by using rapid sequencing techniques, significantly reduced the time=
 taken
  for diagnosis from a clinical isolate.
DE: viral-diseases; disease-vectors; polymerase-chain-reaction; biotechnolo=
gy-;
  taxonomy-; phylogeny-; sheep-diseases
OD: Culicoides-wadai; sheep-; cattle-; bluetongue-virus; Culicoides-;
  arboviruses-; Diptera-; Ceratopogonidae-
GE: Australia-; Northern-Territory
BT: Culicoides; Ceratopogonidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrate=
s;
  animals; Ovis; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; ungulates; Bos; Orbivirus; arboviruses; viruses; Reoviridae; an=
imal
  -viruses; pathogens; OECD-Countries; Australasia; Oceania; Commonwealth-o=
f
  -Nations; Developed-Countries; Australia

  -Treatment-and-Diagnosis-Non-Drug
