Record 619 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Natural transmission of foot-and-mouth disease virus from African buffa=
lo
  (Syncerus caffer) to cattle in a wildlife area of Zimbabwe.
AU: Dawe-PS; Flanagan-FO; Madekurozwa-RL; Sorensen-KJ; Anderson-EC; Foggin-=
CM;
  Ferris-NP; Knowles-NJ
AD: Department of Veterinary Services, Veterinary Research Laboratory, PO B=
ox
  8101, Causeway, Harare, Zimbabwe.
SO: Veterinary-Record. 1994, 134: 10, 230-232; 11 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: An outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) occurred during April 1991 =
in a
  trypanosomiasis sentinel cattle herd by the Rifa River to the east of Lak=
e
  Kariba, Zimbabwe. Despite the cattle having been vaccinated biannually fo=
r the
  previous 5 years the disease was severe. The viruses isolated from the af=
fected
  animals were typed as FMD virus type SAT 1. Free-living African buffalo w=
hich
  had been using the same watering place as the affected cattle were sample=
d and
  FMD type SAT 1 virus was isolated. Partial nucleotide sequencing of the g=
ene
  coding for the capsid protein 1D (VP1) of one of the viruses isolated fro=
m
  cattle and 2 of the viruses isolated from buffalo detected a close relati=
onship
  between the 3 viruses. Since no other cattle were present in the area and=
 no
  outbreaks of SAT 1 had occurred in Zimbabwe since 1989, it was concluded =
that
  the disease had been transmitted from buffalo to cattle.
DE: wild-animals; nucleotide-sequences; viral-proteins; foot-and-mouth-dise=
ase;
  disease-transmission; viral-diseases
OD: cattle-; buffaloes-
GE: Zimbabwe-
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla;
  mammals; ungulates; Bubalus; SADCC-Countries; ACP-Countries; Anglophone-A=
frica;
  Commonwealth-of-Nations; Developing-Countries; Southern-Africa; Africa-So=
uth-of
  -Sahara; Africa

Record 620 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Vertical transmission of Rickettsia tsutsugamushi in Leptotrombidium
  (Leptotrombidium) pallidum..
AU: Takahashi-M
AD: Department of Medical Zoology, Saitama Medical School, Moroyama-cho, Ir=
uma
  -gun, Saitama 350-04, Japan.
SO: Japanese-Journal-of-Sanitary-Zoology. 1990, 41: 4, 389-403; 26 ref.
PY: 1990
LA: Japanese
LS: English
AB: Infective foci of L. pallidum naturally infected with Rickettsia
  tsutsugamushi were discovered by exposing Microtus montebelli as sentinel
  animals on the ground at Hitsujiyama Park, Chichibu City, Saitama Prefect=
ure,
  Japan, in November 1985. From wild rodents (Apodemus speciosus) captured =
around
  the foci, engorged larvae of L. pallidum were collected and successfully =
reared
  by feeding on fresh eggs of Collembola. Four laboratory colonies of L. pa=
llidum
  positive for the Karp strain of R. tsutsugamushi were established, and ve=
rtical
  transmission from the parental generation (P) to F3 in these family lines=
 was
  examined by isolating rickettsiae from individual mites through passage i=
nto
  mice. From F1 to F3 in 4 family lines, a total of 115 unfed larvae, 53 ad=
ult
  females and 51 adult males were examined for rickettsiae. Only 6 males we=
re
  negative and all others were positive for R. tsutsugamushi. The rate of
  transovarial transmission from P to F1, F1 to F2, and F2 to F3 generation=
s were
  100%, and filial infection rates of their offspring were nearly 100%.
  Spermatophores from infected males were examined for rickettsiae and all =
of 78
  spermatophores were negative for R. tsutsugamushi. Furthermore, each of 7=
 R.
  tsutsugamushi-positive males was mated with each of 7 rickettsiae-negativ=
e
  females, and a total of 227 unfed larvae were obtained from these females=
. R.
  tsutsugamushi was not isolated or detected from any of these larvae. It w=
as
  concluded that R. tsutsugamushi-positive males did not play any significa=
nt
  role in the vertical transmission of R. tsutsugamushi; the rickettsia was
  transmitted to the next generation only through the eggs of R. tsutsugamu=
shi
  -positive females.
DE: Human-diseases; Disease-vectors; Disease-transmission; Vertical
  -transmission; Epidemiology-; Small-mammals; Zoonoses-; Sentinel-animals;
  transovarial-transmission
OD: Acari-; Trombiculidae-; Rickettsiaceae-; Man-; Apodemus-speciosus; Rode=
nts-;
  Microtus-montebelli; Rickettsia-tsutsugamushi; Leptotrombidium-pallidum
GE: Japan-; Honshu-
ID: Rickettsial-diseases
BT: mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; experimental-animals; Arachnid=
a;
  arthropods; invertebrates; Prostigmata; mites; Acari; Rickettsiales; bact=
eria;
  prokaryotes; Homo; Hominidae; primates; Apodemus; Murinae; Muridae; roden=
ts;
  Microtus; Microtinae; Rickettsia; Rickettsiaceae; Leptotrombidium;
  Trombiculidae; Developed-Countries; East-Asia; Asia; OECD-Countries; Japa=

Record 621 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: First test of the release of Spalangia cameroni Perkins (Hymenoptera:
  Pteromalidae) for the control of dipteran pests in animal housing.
OT: Prime prove sull' impiego di Spalangia cameroni Perkins (Hymenoptera:
  Pteromalidae) nel contenimento dei ditteri nocivi negli allevamenti zoote=
cnici.
AU: Maini-S; Bellini-R
AD: Istituto di Enomologia, Universita di Bologna, Italy.
SO: XVI Congresso Nazionale della Societa Italiana di Parassitologia, Cagli=
ari,
  S. Margherita di Pula, 7-11 Maggio 1990. Parassitologia. 1990, 32: Supple=
mento,
  171-172; 1 ref.
PY: 1990
LA: Italian
LS: English
AB: An indigenous strain of the dipteran pupal parasitoid S. cameroni was
  released in 2 caged-layer poultry farms in Romagna, Italy. Another 3 simi=
lar
  farms were used as controls. 2 different methods were used simultaneously=
 for
  testing the parasitization activity. These included sampling of wild pupa=
e (of
  Musca domestica, Ophyra aenescens [Hydrotaea aenescens], Fannia canicular=
is and
  Muscina stabulans) and placement of sentinel house fly (Musca domestica) =
pupae.
  Neither method showed a significant increase in the rate of parasitism. T=
he
  possible reasons for the limited effectiveness of the release are examine=
d.
DE: control-; biological-control; poultry-housing; biological-control-agent=
s;
  evaluation-
OD: Hymenoptera-; Pteromalidae-; Muscidae-; Fanniidae-; Musca-domestica;

eroni;
  Diptera-; arthropods-

ina;
  Spalangia; Pteromalidae; Mediterranean-Region; Developed-Countries; Europ=

  -Communities; OECD-Countries; Southern-Europe; Europe

Record 622 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Feral swine as a potential amplifying host for vesicular stomatitis vir=
us
  New Jersey serotype on Ossabaw Island, Georgia.
AU: Stallknecht-DE; Kavanaugh-DM; Corn-JL; Eernisse-KA; Comer-JA; Nettles-V=
F
AD: Southeastern Cooperative Wildlife Disease Study, College of Veterinary
  Medicine, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Wildlife-Diseases. 1993, 29: 3, 377-383; 31 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: Sentinel feral pigs on Ossabaw Island, Georgia (USA), were serologicall=
y
  monitored for antibodies to vesicular stomatitis New Jersey serotype (VSN=
J)
  virus from 17 April to 27 August 1990. Seroconversions to VSNJ virus were
  detected in 24% of pigs throughout the island. Differences in the inciden=
ce of
  seroconversion were detected between pigs sampled in the Pleistocene and
  Holocene formations of the island suggesting that the presence of virus i=
s
  forest type dependent. Based on the consistency in onset and spatial
  distribution of seroconversions with data from 1981 to 1985, it was concl=
uded
  that this is a very stable host-parasite system. Sequential virus isolati=
on
  attempts from nasal swabs, tonsil swabs, and blood were made on a subsamp=
le of
  54 sentinel pigs from 9 May to 4 July 1990. The VSNJ virus was isolated f=
rom 5
  pigs from 16 May to 20 June. Vesicular lesions were detected on 2 of thes=
e
  animals. Although infections in these feral pigs were short-lived (< 7 da=
ys)
  and were followed by a strong neutralizing antibody response, VSNJ virus =
was
  detected in a single group of pigs for a period exceeding 1 month. It is
  concluded that feral pigs could provide a source of virus to feeding arth=
ropods
  for extended periods of time. The failure to detect a viraemia in these
  animals, however, indicates that a source other than blood may be require=
d for
  transmission to occur.
DE: epidemiology-; viral-diseases; wild-animals; wild-pigs; swine-diseases
OD: vesicular-stomatitis-virus; pigs-
GE: USA-; Georgia-
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla;
  ungulates; mammals; wild-animals; Vesiculovirus; animal-viruses; pathogen=
s;
  Rhabdoviridae; viruses; North-America; America; Developed-Countries; OECD
  -Countries; South-Atlantic-States-of-USA; Southern-States-of-USA; USA;
  Southeastern-States-of-USA
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals

Record 624 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Cold injury of peach and nectarine cultivars after a fall freeze.
AU: Smith-MW; Carroll-BL; Taylor-GG
AD: Department of Horticulture and Landscape Architecture, Oklahoma State
  University, Stillwater, OK 74078, USA.
SO: HortScience. 1994, 29: 7, 821; 4 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: Information is presented on the extent of cold injury to various peach =
and
  nectarine cultivars following an autumn temperature drop from 5 to -11=B0=
C within
  12 h. The trees were growing on a Teller loam (Mollisols) at the Fruit Re=
search
  Station near Perkins, central Oklahoma. There had been no prior freezing
  temperatures and trees were fully foliated. Of the nectarine cultivars,
  Fantasia and Sunfre had the least cold injury; Armking, Mayfire and Sunge=
m were
  killed by the frost. Sentinel was the least damaged of the peach cultivar=
s; Sam
  Houston was the only peach cultivar for which all the trees sampled were =
killed.
DE: frost-injury; loam-soils; Mollisols-; peaches-; nectarines-; frost-;
  resistance-; cultivars-; cold-resistance; temperate-fruits; fruit-crops
OD: Prunus-persica

  North-America; America; Developed-Countries; OECD-Countries; Southern-Pla=
ins
  -States-of-USA; West-South-Central-States-of-USA; Southern-States-of-USA;=

Record 625 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Assessing cercarial transmission of Cyathocotyle bushiensis and
  Sphaeridiotrema pseudoglobulus by use of sentinel snails.
AU: Lepitzki-DAW; Scott-ME; McLaughlin-JD
AD: Institute of Parasitology, Macdonald Campus of McGill University, 21 11=
1
  Lakeshore Road, Ste. Anne de Bellevue, QC H9X 3V9, Canada.
SO: Canadian-Journal-of-Zoology. 1994, 72: 5, 885-891; 24 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
LS: French
AB: Bithynia tentaculata was used to assess spatial and temporal variation =
in
  cercarial transmission of Cyathocotyle bushiensis and Sphaeridiotrema
  pseudoglobulus at 2 field locations in southern Quebec and south-eastern
  Ontario, Canada, from mid-August to the end of October 1989. Sentinel sna=
ils
  held in plastic mesh bags acquired infections with both digeneans, althou=
gh low
  levels of metacercariae of C. bushiensis precluded any conclusions being
  reached regarding the transmission of this parasite. In contrast, extensi=
ve
  spatial heterogeneity was observed in the S. pseudoglobulus-snail system.
  Sentinel snails within 10 m of each other were apparently exposed to grea=
tly
  different levels of naturally occurring cercariae. All size classes (<5, =
5-6.9,
  7-8.9 and _9 mm shell length) of sentinels were apparently equally suscep=
tible
  to cercarial infections but no consistent temporal differences in infecti=
on
  levels were found.
DE: cercariae-; sentinel-animals; intermediate-hosts; transmission-; parasi=
tes-;
  disease-transmission; helminths-
OD: Psilostomidae-; Digenea-; Bithyniidae-; Gastropoda-; Bithynia-tentacula=
ta
GE: Canada-; Quebec-; Ontario-

s
BT: digenean-larvae; Digenea; Trematoda; Platyhelminthes; invertebrates;

rates;

Record 626 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Isolation of bluetongue virus from a calf and antibody survey of cattle=
 in
  Okinawa.
AU: Takayoshi-K; Kokuba-T; Kubo-M; Miura-Y
AD: Institute of Animal Health, Naha, Okinawa 900, Japan.
SO: Journal-of-the-Japan-Veterinary-Medical-Association. 1994, 47: 9, 651-6=
54;
  11 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: Japanese
LS: English
AB: A bluetongue virus (ON-89-1) was isolated in June, 1989, in HmLu-1 cell
  culture from the blood of a healthy calf on Okinawa Island. Tests on sent=
inel
  calves in the 6-year period 1985-1990 showed seroconversion in the summer=
 of
  each year and widespread dissemination of the infection in cattle through=
out
  Okinawa Prefecture.

Record 628 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Overwintering and establishment potential of Bagous affinis (Coleoptera=
:
  Curculionidae) on Hydrilla verticillata (Hydrocharitaceae) in northern
  California.
AU: Godfrey-KE; Anderson-LWJ; Perry-SD; Dechoretz-N
AD: USDA, ARS, Aquatic Weed Control Research Laboratory, University of
  California, Davis, CA 95616, USA.
SO: Florida-Entomologist. 1994, 77: 2, 221-230; 9 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
LS: Spanish
AB: Bagous affinis has potential as a biological control agent for undergro=
und
  tubers of Hydrilla verticillata. The ability of B. affinis to overwinter =
and
  establish was investigated at 2 sites in northern California; a pond in
  Calaveras County and the Chowchilla River in Madera County. In cage studi=
es
  conducted at the pond, B. affinis survived 2 winters (1991-92 and 1992-93=
).
  After releases at the pond, B. affinis successfully reproduced and surviv=
ed
  during summer 1992. Weevil larvae damaged both sentinel and native tubers=
 at
  the site. In the spring, following the release of B. affinis at the pond,=
 a
  light trap and baited shelter traps were used to detect weevils that had
  overwintered naturally at the site. No weevils were recovered. At the
  Chowchilla River site, B. affinis failed to establish, possibly due to a =
lack
  of tubers in the section of the river where the releases were made.
DE: plant-pests; beneficial-insects; aquatic-weeds; natural-enemies; biolog=
ical
  -control; biological-control-agents; evaluation-; control-; weeds-; biolo=
gy-;
  pest-control; agricultural-entomology
OD: Coleoptera-; Curculionidae-; Hydrilla-verticillata; arthropods-
GE: USA-; California-
ID: Bagous-affinis
BT: pests; animals; beneficial-arthropods; arthropods; invertebrates; benef=
icial
  -organisms; insects; aquatic-plants; aquatic-organisms; plants; weeds;
  Coleoptera; Hydrilla; Hydrocharitaceae; Hydrocharitales; monocotyledons;
  angiosperms; Spermatophyta; Developed-Countries; North-America; America; =
OECD

Record 629 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Serological response in sheep vaccinated against Coxiella burnetii (Q f=
ever).
AU: Lang-GH; Prescott-JF; Williams-JC
AD: Department of Veterinary Microbiology and Immunology, Ontario Veterinar=
y
  College, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario N1G 2W1, Canada.
SO: Canadian-Veterinary-Journal. 1994, 35: 6, 373-374; 10 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: A research sheep flock consisting of 100 ewes and 12 rams of the Arcott
  breed, were vaccinated using chloroform-methanol gamma-irradiated residue
  prepared from C. burnetii phase I, Ohio strain. The flock was monitored o=
ver 5
  -year period. Sheep were vaccinated once with the vaccine and responded w=
ell
  overall. Successive vaccination of different animals with the same antige=
n
  batch, which was thawed and frozen on about 6 occasions over 4 years, pro=
duced
  gradually decreasing antibody titres as detected in ELISA. Regardless of
  whether the initial titres were high or low, all reactants from the first
  vaccinated group remained ELISA seropositive for at least 5 years. The fi=
fth
  -year ELISA titres were still >1:1000 in 70% and 1:100-1:1000 in 30% of t=
ested
  sheep. Local reactions to vaccination were minimal in the sheep. General
  reactions were not observed. A second administration of the vaccine to 3 =
sheep
  did not elicit more serious vaccination reactions. 43 sentinel sheep rema=
ined
  ELISA seronegative throughout the observation period.
DE: bacterial-diseases; immunization-; sheep-diseases
OD: sheep-; Coxiella-burnetii; Coxiella-
GE: Canada-
BT: Ovis; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; ungulates; Coxiella; Rickettsiaceae; Rickettsiales; bacteria;
  prokaryotes; OECD-Countries; Commonwealth-of-Nations; Developed-Countries=
;
  North-America; America
CC: LL820; HH600
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Host
  -Resistance-and-Immunity
PT: Journal-article

Record 630 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Development and evaluation of a non-isotopically labelled DNA probe for=
 the
  diagnosis of infectious laryngotracheitis.
AU: Key-DW; Gough-BC; Derbyshire-JB; Nagy-E
AD: Ontario Ministry of Agriculture and Foods, Veterinary Services Laborato=
ry,
  P.O. Box 3612, Guelph, Ont. N1H 6RB, Canada.
SO: Avian-Diseases. 1994, 38: 3, 467-474; 18 ref.
PY: 1994
LA: English
LS: Spanish
AB: A digoxigenin-labelled cloned infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV)=
 DNA
  fragment was evaluated as a non-radioactive alternative probe in the diag=
nosis
  of infectious laryngotracheitis. The dot-blot hybridization protocol was
  optimized and was capable of detecting 40 pg of purified ILTV DNA and as =
few as
  50 ILTV-infected chicken embryo liver cells. The diagnostic use of this
  approach was evaluated through 4 ILTV inoculation trials using a mild fie=
ld
  isolate, a virulent challenge strain, a tissue-culture-origin vaccine, an=
d an
  egg-origin vaccine. Birds were examined for clinical signs of ILT, and
  conjunctival and pharyngeal swabs from inoculated and sentinel birds were
  tested for ILTV by the digoxigenin-labelled probe and by virus isolation.=
 In
  general, higher numbers of ILTV positive samples were detected by both as=
says
  from conjunctival swabs. For the non-vaccine strains, detection by dot-bl=
ot
  -hybridization was equivalent to that for virus isolation. However, for t=
he 2
  vaccine strains, there was some lack of correlation between the dot-blot
  results and the virus-isolation results. The kappa values between virus
  -isolation results and dot-blot results for the tissue-culture-origin vac=
cine,
  egg-origin vaccine, Ont 1596 field isolate, and virulent strain were 0.00=
,
  0.16, 0.39 and 0.24, respectively, for pharyngeal samples and 0.19, 0.29,=
 0.58
  and 0.48 respectively, for conjunctival samples.
DE: diagnostic-techniques; digoxigenin-; immunoblotting-; fowl-diseases; vi=
ral
  -diseases; DNA-probes; poultry-; poultry-diseases
OD: fowls-; avian-laryngotracheitis-virus
RN: 1672-46-4
BT: domestic-animals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; birds; poultry; Gallu=
s
  -gallus; Gallus; Phasianidae; Galliformes; avian-herpesvirus; Herpesvirid=
ae;
  animal-viruses; pathogens; viruses

Record 631 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Disposal of waste herbicide effluent.
AU: Code-GR; Chambers-AJ; Roberts-G
AD: Department of Agriculture, Rutherglen Research Institute RMB 1145,
  Rutherglen, Vic. 3685, Australia.
SO: Research-Report-Series -Department-of-Agriculture,-Victoria. 1994, No. =
153,
  24 pp.; 5 ref.
PB: Victorian Department of Agriculture; East Melbourne; Australia
PY: 1994
LA: English
AB: The effectiveness of the Sentinel effluent treatment plant in removing
  chlorsulfuron, fluazifop-P, glyphosate, paraquat, simazine, dimethoate an=
d
  endosulfan from water at concn typical of those used in spray application=
s and
  from waste water equipment washing was evaluated. Pesticide concn were re=
duced
  to levels similar to the Australian national standards for residues in wa=
ter,
  except for glyphosate for which 710 ppm occured in the liquid after filtr=
ation.
  The unit was simple and easy to operate. However, disposal of the floccul=
ated
  chemicals and spent activated carbon was difficult and limited the use of=
 the
  plant. An appendix gives details of Toxicity Characteristic Leaching Proc=
edure
  test methods and methods used to determine the concn of analytes.

Record 632 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Arboviruses of wild birds and mammals.
AU: McLean-RG
AD: Division of Vector-borne Infectious Diseases, Center for Infectious
  Diseases, Centers for Disease Control, PO Box 2087, Fort Collins, CO 8052=
2, USA.
SO: Bulletin-of-the-Society-for-Vector-Ecology. 1991, 16: 1, 3-16; In
  Proceedings, Symposium: Vectors of Wildlife Diseases, 22nd Annual SOVE
  Conference, Mesa, Arizona, November 12, 1990 ; 74 ref.
PY: 1991
LA: English
AB: The distribution and ecology of 5 of the arboviruses of public health
  importance in the USA - St. Louis encephalitis virus, western equine
  encephalitis virus, eastern equine encephalitis virus, La Crosse virus an=
d
  Colorado tick fever virus - are briefly reviewed and related to the
  characteristics of birds and mammals that make them good hosts for the vi=
ruses.
  Information is presented on the scope of arbovirus surveillance programme=
s, on
  the qualities of vertebrate species that make them good sentinels, and on=
 the
  types of birds and mammals that have been used for surveillance purposes.=
 The
  effectiveness of surveillance programmes in predicting human risk to thes=
e
  arboviruses is discussed and some hypotheses for the development of epizo=
otics
  and future research needs are indicated.

sts;

Record 633 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Attempt at predicting Japanese encephalitis (JE) epidemic by a serologi=
cal
  study in 'sentinel' pigs.
AU: Baruah-HC; Chakraborty-MS; Bhat-HR; Dutta-LP; Dutta-LP
AD: Regional Medical Research Centre, N.E. Region (ICMR), Dibrugarh - 786 0=
01,
  Assam, India.
SO: Proceedings of the seminar on zoonoses.  1991, 17-20; 6 ref.
PB: Regional Medical Research Centre; Dibrugarh - 786 001, Assam; India
PY: 1991
LA: English
AB: In a study of about 35 'sentinel' pigs carried out in Dibrugarh Distric=
t in
  endemic villages under 4 Primary Health Centres from November, 1987 to Ja=
nuary,
  1989, seroconversion in the sentinel pigs for Japanese encephalitis (JE) =
virus
  was seasonal. Seroconversion started in the month of June reaching a peak=
 in
  August/September and gradually declining in titre towards subsequent mont=
hs.
  This timing was correlated with human, serologically proved, JE cases in =
and
  around the area under study.

Record 634 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Biotic and abiotic parameters associated with an epizootic of Coelomomy=
ces
  punctatus in a larval population of the mosquito Anopheles quadrimaculatu=
s.=20
AU: Apperson-CS; Federici-BA; Tarver-FR; Stewart-W
AD: Department of Entomology, Box 7613, North Carolina State University,
  Raleigh, NC 27695-7613, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Invertebrate-Pathology. 1992, 60: 3, 219-228; 24 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Biotic and abiotic parameters associated with an epizootic of the fungu=
s C.
  punctatus in larval populations of A. quadrimaculatus were investigated f=
or 3
  mosquito breeding seasons (1986-88) in 2 adjacent farm ponds in North Car=
olina,
  USA. In the first pond, the prevalence of infected larvae averaged 42% (r=
ange 0
  -85%) for collections made weekly from 1 May to 20 November 1986, but lar=
vae
  did not occur in this pond in 1987. Infection rates in the adjacent pond,
  sampled during the mosquito breeding seasons of 1987 and 1988, declined f=
rom
  10.9% (range 0-27.5%) in 1987 to 2.5% (range 0-14.2%) in 1988. Correlatio=
n
  analyses between the number of female copepods and fungal infection rates=
 in
  sentinel mosquitoes were significant (P>0.01) for Acanthocyclops robustus=
 but
  insignificant for 8 other species. Infections obtained in sentinel larvae
  placed in the ponds for 3-h intervals indicated that C. punctatus infecte=
d
  larvae around sundown. Infection rates for field-collected larvae increas=
ed
  with the stage of larval development. However, experiments with sentinel =
larvae
  showed that early instars were more susceptible to infection than later
  instars, suggesting that the higher infection rates in late instars resul=
ted
  from individual larvae being infected by 2 or more zygotes during larval
  development. Standard multiple regression analyses, used to determine the
  relationship between seasonal infection rates and water chemistry, weathe=
r
  variables, and the abundance of early and late instar larvae, showed that=
 the
  abundance of late instars was the only independent variable common to lin=
ear
  models. The models only accounted for 20 and 9% of the variation in larva=
l
  infection rates for 1987 and 1988, respectively. These results indicate t=
hat of
  the parameters examined, the seasonal abundance of the copepod A. robustu=
s was
  the most important factor (or variable) correlated with the prevalence of
  mosquito infection.
DE: Aquatic-insects; Ponds-; Intermediate-hosts; Aquatic-invertebrates;
  entomogenous-fungi; epidemiology-
OD: Diptera-; Culicidae-; Blastocladiales-; Crustacea-; Copepoda-; Cyclopoi=
da-;
  Anopheles-quadrimaculatus; Acanthocyclops-robustus
GE: USA-; North-Carolina; North-America
ID: Chytridiomycetes; Epizootics; Coelomomycetaceae; Coelomomyces-punctatus
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; aquatic-arthropods; aquati=
c
  -invertebrates; aquatic-animals; fungi; Diptera; Mastigomycotina; Eumycot=
a;
  Crustacea; Copepoda; Anopheles; Culicidae; Acanthocyclops; Cyclopidae;
  Cyclopoida; North-America; America; Appalachian-States-of-USA; Southern-S=
tates
  -of-USA; USA; South-Atlantic-States-of-USA
CC: TT300; MM300; LL820; HH100

Record 635 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Evidence for the copepods Acanthocyclops robustus and Mesocyclops edax =
as
  competent intermediate hosts for Coelomomyces punctatus during an epizoot=
ic in
  a larval population of the mosquito Anopheles quadrimaculatus.=20
AU: Apperson-CS; Federici-BA; Stewart-W; Tarver-FR
AD: Department of Entomology, Box 7613, North Carolina State University,
  Raleigh, NC 27695-7613, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Invertebrate-Pathology. 1992, 60: 3, 229-236; 20 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Field and laboratory experiments were conducted during an epizootic of =
C.
  punctatus in a population of A. quadrimaculatus in a North Carolina farm =
pond
  to examine the interactions of several potential copepod hosts with the
  mosquito and fungus. The diel vertical migratory behaviour of the copepod
  species Acanthocyclops robustus, Eucyclops serrulatus, Macrocyclops albid=
us and
  Mesocyclops edax were monitored in relation to infection rates in sentine=
l
  mosquito larvae. Mosquito infection occurred primarily around dusk, the s=
ame
  period during which A. robustus and E. serrulatus were the most abundant =
near
  the surface of the pond. However, exposure of A. robustus, E. serrulatus,
  Macrocyclops albidus, Mesocyclops edax, Microcyclops varicans and Paracyc=
lops
  poppei to fungal meiospores in the laboratory showed that only A. robustu=
s and
  Mesocyclops edax were competent intermediate hosts for C. punctatus. Labo=
ratory
  studies of the diel periodicity of gametangial dehiscence in A. robustus =
and M.
  edax infected with C. punctatus revealed that gamete release and zygote
  formation also occurred around dusk. The combined results of the laborato=
ry and
  field studies on copepod abundance, susceptibility to infection, and
  periodicity of gametangial dehiscence suggested that A. robustus was the
  principal intermediate host for C. punctatus during the epizootic, though=
 it is
  probable that M. edax also contributed importantly to the overall rate of
  larval infection.
DE: Aquatic-insects; Ponds-; Intermediate-hosts; Aquatic-invertebrates;
  entomogenous-fungi; epidemiology-
OD: Diptera-; Culicidae-; Blastocladiales-; Crustacea-; Copepoda-; Cyclopoi=
da-;
  Anopheles-quadrimaculatus; Eucyclops-serrulatus; Acanthocyclops-robustus
GE: USA-; North-Carolina; North-America
ID: Chytridiomycetes; Epizootics; Coelomomycetaceae; Coelomomyces-punctatus=
;
  Microcyclops-varicans; Paracyclops-poppei; Macrocyclops-albidus; Mesocycl=
ops
  -edax
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; aquatic-arthropods; aquati=
c
  -invertebrates; aquatic-animals; fungi; Diptera; Mastigomycotina; Eumycot=
a;
  Crustacea; Copepoda; Anopheles; Culicidae; Eucyclops; Cyclopidae; Cyclopo=
ida;
  Acanthocyclops; North-America; America; Appalachian-States-of-USA; Southe=
rn
  -States-of-USA; USA; South-Atlantic-States-of-USA
CC: TT300; MM300; LL820; HH100

  -Ecology; Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals;
  Biological-Control

Record 636 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Patterns of hyperparasitism of Cotesia melanoscela (Hymenoptera: Bracon=
idae)
  in southern Ontario.
AU: Bourchier-RS; Nealis-VG
AD: Forestry Canada, Ontario Region, P.O. Box 490, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., =
P6A
  5M7, Canada.
SO: Environmental-Entomology. 1992, 21: 4, 907-912; 12 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Patterns of hyperparasitism of cocoons of Cotesia melanoscela [C.
  melanoscelus], a parasitoid of Lymantria dispar, in southern Ontario were
  studied by periodic sampling of naturally occurring cocoons found under b=
urlap
  bands and by deploying laboratory-produced sentinel cocoons on bark discs=
. At
  least 6 species of hyperparasitoids were recovered. The most common speci=
es of
  hyperparasitoids showed definite associations with sampling method and wi=
th red
  or white oak trees [Quercus rubra and Q. alba]. Hyperparasitism of C.
  melanoscelus began in early June and persisted throughout the summer. The=
 peak
  activity of hyperparasitoids was recorded in late June and early July and=
 was
  coincident with the maximum number of available natural C. melanoscelus c=
ocoons
  in diapause. The probability of C. melanoscelus survival during any singl=
e
  sampling interval declined steadily over the sampling period (14 June-3 A=
ugust
  1989). During this sampling period, 95.9% of the available C. melanoscelu=
s
  cocoons were killed by hyperparasitoids. This estimate of hyperparasitism=
 is a
  minimum rate for Ontario; cocoons not attacked by the end of the sampling
  period were in diapause and thus were vulnerable to hyperparasitism for u=
p to
  10 months after sampling ended.
DE: Beneficial-insects; Natural-enemies; Forest-pests; Forest-trees;
  Hyperparasitoids-; Insect-pests; habitats-; parasitoids-; hosts-; Broadle=
aves-;
  parasites-; agricultural-entomology
OD: Hymenoptera-; Braconidae-; Insects-; Lepidoptera-; Lymantriidae-; Querc=
us
  -rubra; Cotesia-melanoscelus; Quercus-alba; Quercus-; Lymantria-dispar;
  Lymantria-; arthropods-

ts;
  trees; woody-plants; Spermatophyta; plants; arthropod-pests; dicotyledons=

  angiosperms; Hymenoptera; Lepidoptera; Quercus; Fagaceae; Fagales; Cotesi=
a;
  Braconidae; Lymantria; Lymantriidae; Canada; North-America; America

Record 637 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Epizootiology of the fungus Entomophaga maimaiga, and its impact on gyp=
sy
  moth populations.
AU: Weseloh-RM; Andreadis-TG
AD: Department of Entomology, Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station, =
New
  Havana, CT 06504, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Invertebrate-Pathology. 1992, 59: 2, 133-141; 27 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: The effect of the fungus Entomophaga maimaiga on populations of Lymantr=
ia
  dispar was investigated by assessing the prevalence of disease in larvae
  collected from forest plots in Connecticut in 1990 and in laboratory-rear=
ed,
  sentinel larvae exposed in wire cages in the same plots. Large amounts of
  rainfall in May appeared to be critical for development of the fungus. Un=
der
  favourable conditions, infection rates averaged 5% or less in May, but re=
ached
  40% or more in June. Infective conidia were produced in May, while restin=
g
  spores became increasingly common within dead cadavers in June. E. maimai=
ga was
  slightly more prevalent in forest-collected larvae from irrigated portion=
s of
  the sites, and was significantly more prevalent in caged larvae in the
  irrigated areas. Infection rates also varied between plots, and were corr=
elated
  with density of L. dispar and tree composition. Using a day-degree model,
  estimates of daily recruitment and death of fungus-infected larvae were
  obtained. Recruitment in May was not related to precipitation, possibly b=
ecause
  of abundant rainfall, but in June recruitment was correlated with the spo=
radic
  rainfall that occurred then. Data on recruitment and death were used to
  construct survival curves for larvae. Only a few to over half the larvae
  survived the fungus epizootic in different plots.
DE: Population-dynamics; Ecology-; Insect-pests; Forest-pests; Natural-enem=
ies;
  Microbial-pesticides; Insecticides-; Rain-; Environmental-factors; Forest
  -trees; pathogens-; hosts-; Entomogenous-fungi; fungal-diseases; biology-=
;
  agricultural-entomology; biological-control-agents
OD: Lymantriidae-; Lepidoptera-; Lymantria-dispar; arthropods-
GE: Connecticut-; USA-
ID: Entomophaga-maimaiga
BT: arthropod-pests; pests; animals; arthropods; invertebrates; insects;
  pesticides; trees; woody-plants; Spermatophyta; plants; fungi; Lepidopter=
a;
  Lymantria; Lymantriidae; New-England-States-of-USA; Northeastern-States-o=
f-USA;
  USA; North-America; America
CC: FF600; KK100; KK110; HH100
CD: Pests,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Plants; Forestry-General;
  Silviculture; Biological-Control
PT: Journal-article

Record 638 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Evaluation of the Carbo-Flo pesticide waste management system.
AU: Hall-FR; Downer-RA; Chapple-AC; Bode-LE (ed.); Chasin-DG
AD: Laboratory for Pest Control Application Technology (LPCAT), Ohio State
  University, Wooster, OH 44691, USA.
SO: Pesticide-formulations-and-application-systems:-11th-volume. 1992, 24-3=
2;
  proceedings of a conference on pesticide formulations and application sys=
tems
  held in San Antonio, USA, 14-15 November 1991, STP series no. 1112; 5 ref=
.
PB: ASTM; Philadelphia; USA
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: The Carbo-Flo water effluent treatment process uses a simple flocculati=
on
  and filtration system which requires no specialized personnel for its eff=
ective
  use. Treatment is carried out using pre-weighed/pre-packed materials desi=
gned
  to treat 1000 litres of diluted spray liquor. The flocculation and settle=
ment
  process takes a min. of 1 h, and filtration through 1 coarse gravel and 2=
 fine
  carbon filters takes approx. 2 h. Water containing atrazine, alachlor and
  permethrin were processed through the specially designed Sentinel system.
  Trials using both single products and a 3-way mix were performed. Analysi=
s of
  the treated water at different points in the system was carried out using=
 GC.
  All treatments resulted in >99.9% of the pesticides being removed from th=
e end
  water. Water thus treated can be recycled for subsequent use as rinse wat=
er or
  may be discharged into a soakaway. All solid waste from the process can b=
e
  incinerated. The carbon filters can be regenerated. Some possible user pr=
oblems
  with the flocculation process were encountered and investigated. Adequate
  dilution of the pesticide waste liquor was found to be essential for the
  process to be completely efficient.
DE: Herbicides-; application-; dispersal-; waste-water-treatment; Atrazine-=
;
  Alachlor-; Equipment-; Pesticides-; waste-water; treatment-; Insecticide
  -residues; Pesticide-residues; Techniques-; residues-; Permethrin-; plant
  -pathology; agricultural-entomology
ID: Pesticide-formulations-and-application-systems
RN: 1912-24-9; 15972-60-8; 52645-53-1
BT: pesticides; triazine-herbicides; herbicides; chloroacetanilide-herbicid=
es;
  anilide-herbicides; amide-herbicides; pyrethroid-insecticides; insecticid=
es
CC: NN430; NN400; ZZ900; FF600; HH400
CD: Pest-and-Weed-Control-Equipment; Agricultural-and-Forestry-Equipment
  -General; Techniques-and-Methodology; Pests,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Disea=
ses-of
  -Plants; Control-by-Chemicals-and-Drugs
PT: Conference-paper
IB: 0-8031-1414-1 (hardback)
UD: 950316

Record 639 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Arbovirus and arbovirus vector surveillance in New Zealand.
AU: Ryan-TJ; Frampton-ER; Motha-MXJ; Horner-GW
AD: MAF Quality Management, Ruakura, New Zealand.
SO: Surveillance-Wellington. 1991, 18: 5, 24-26; 15 ref.
PY: 1991
LA: English
AB: The use of sentinel cattle herds for the surveillance of arboviruses of
  livestock in New Zealand is discussed. In the 10 northern coastal distric=
ts
  where the climate was most suitable for the survival of Culicoides spp., =
one
  cattle herd from each district was selected. Also, local veterinarians we=
re
  informed of the clinical conditions that might be seen after arbovirus
  infection, and were requested to report any suspicious cases to the neare=
st MAF
  Animal Health Laboratory. In May 1990 a blood sample was taken from all
  sentinel cattle. Group specific agar gel immunodiffusion tests were carri=
ed out
  for the detection of antibodies to bluetongue (serotype 20), epizootic
  haemorrhagic disease (serotype 2) and Palyam (D'Aguilar) viruses. Serum
  neutralization tests were carried out for the detection of antibodies to
  Akabane and Douglas viruses. During April 1990, light traps were set up o=
n each
  of the properties where the cattle were to be tested and run for 3 nights=
 on 2
  different occasions. 25 suspect arbovirus cases were reported (in 10 catt=
le, 9
  goats and 6 sheep); arbovirus infection was eliminated in each on the bas=
is of
  serology. A total of 2027 serum samples was tested; all were negative for
  antibodies against the 5 arboviruses tested. The total number of insects
  collected and identified to family level was 15 019. No Culicoides specim=
ens
  were recorded. Large numbers of Psychodidae and a very small number of
  mosquitoes were collected. It was concluded that New Zealand was free of =
both
  arboviruses and their vectors, but the surveillance programme was continu=
ed.
DE: Disease-vectors; Disease-surveys; Sentinel-animals; Light-traps; monito=
ring-
OD: Diptera-; Ceratopogonidae-; Bunyavirus-; Bunyaviridae-; Reoviridae-;
  Orbivirus-; Cattle-; Culicoides-; arboviruses-; Bluetongue-virus; Epizoot=
ic
  -haemorrhagic-disease-of-deer-virus; Akabane-virus
GE: New-Zealand
ID: Palyam-virus; Douglas-virus
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; Dip=
tera;
  Bunyaviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Reoviridae; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants;
  Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; Ceratopogonidae; Orbivirus; Bunyavirus;
  Australasia; Oceania
CC: LL820; TT300
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Medical=
-and
  -Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0112-4927
UD: 950316
AN: 930511894

Record 640 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Suspect case of Akabane disease.
CA: Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, New Zealand.
AD: PO Box 2526, Wellington, New Zealand.
SO: Sentinel-Wellington. 1990, No. 8, 2.
PY: 1990
LA: English
AB: Two cases of birth abnormalities were referred to the Ruakura Animal He=
alth
  Laboratory, New Zealand, in 1990. On one farm, 5 calves born to heifers w=
ere
  delivered weak or stillborn. Two which were alive showed nervous signs
  associated with congenital internal hydrocephalus. Two of 5 heifers from
  another herd gave birth to live calves with stiff legs and neck. There ha=
d been
  a history of calves born with similar defects in the area for some 20 yea=
rs. No
  cause for any of the abnormalities was found, and arboviruses (Akabane,
  bluetongue and haemorrhagic disease of deer viruses) were checked out wit=
h
  negative results.

Record 642 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Black widow spiders.
CA: New Zealand, Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries.
AD: MAF, PO Box 2526, Wellington, New Zealand.
SO: Sentinel-Wellington. 1990, No. 10, 3; 1 ref.
PY: 1990
LA: English
AB: During 1 November-15 December 1990, 5 interceptions of Latrodectus spid=
ers
  were made on grapes imported into New Zealand from the USA. Four of these
  interceptions were made by members of the New Zealand public. Following a
  meeting of the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries and the =
USDA
  held on 10 November, it was decided that all imports of grapes from the U=
SA to
  New Zealand should be fumigated with methyl bromide until further notice.

Record 643 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Brown dog tick in Taradale.
CA: New Zealand, Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries.
AD: MAF, PO Box 2526, Wellington, New Zealand.
SO: Sentinel-Wellington. 1991, No. 14, 1; 1 ref.
PY: 1991
LA: English
AB: The finding of 2 gravid females of Rhipicephalus sanguineus in a dog's
  basket in Taradale, New Zealand, is noted. Thorough investigation of the =
2
  household dogs and cat revealed the presence of several more ixodid ticks=
 on
  one of the dogs. All the animals were treated and kept in isolation. The =
house
  was sprayed with insecticide and fumigated one week later. All dog owners
  within a 7-km radius were notified to watch for ticks and to submit them =
to
  their local veterinarian; by 15 June 1991 there had been no further
  submissions. This was the 2nd report of R. sanguineus in New Zealand duri=
ng
  1991 [see also Sentinel, No. 11 (1991)]; in both cases it is suspected th=
at the
  ticks entered the country in the baggage or possessions of people returni=
ng
  from Southeast Asia.
DE: Ectoparasites-; Introduced-species; introduction-; Case-reports
OD: Acari-; Ixodidae-; Dogs-; Rhipicephalus-sanguineus; Rhipicephalus-

Record 644 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Correlation of Aedes sierrensis captures at human sentinels with CO2-ba=
ited
  Fay-Prince and duplex cone traps.
AU: Washburn-JO; Woodward-DL; Colwell-AE; Anderson-JR
AD: Department of Entomological Sciences, University of California, Berkele=
y, CA
  94720, USA.
SO: Journal-of-the-American-Mosquito-Control-Association. 1992, 8: 4, 389-3=
93;
  13 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: The efficiency of the duplex cone and Fay-Prince traps for monitoring a=
dult
  males and females of A. sierrensis was evaluated at 3 field sites in
  California, USA. The numbers of females captured by both types of traps w=
ere
  significantly correlated with human sentinel collections. The Fay-Prince =
trap
  captured more A. sierrensis females than the duplex cone trap and was a b=
etter
  tool for estimating female activity levels. There was no significant
  correlation between the number of males captured in Fay-Prince traps and =
at
  humans. Male numbers in duplex cone trap collections explained only 27% o=
f the
  variation in the number of males collected at sentinels, suggesting that
  neither trap is a robust tool for estimating male activity around humans.
DE: Sampling-; Carbon-dioxide; Bait-traps; monitoring-; traps-
OD: Diptera-; Culicidae-; Aedes-sierrensis; man-
GE: USA-; California-; North-America

RN: 124-38-9

  America; Pacific-States-of-USA; Western-States-of-USA; USA

Record 645 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Mosquito and arbovirus ecology in southeastern California, 1986-1990.
AU: Reisen-WK; Hardy-JL; Presser-SB; Milby-MM; Meyer-RP; Durso-SL; Wargo-MJ=
;
  Gordon-E
AD: Arbovirus Research Program, Department of Biomedical and Environmental
  Health Sciences, School of Public Health, University of California, Berke=
ley,
  CA 94720, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Medical-Entomology. 1992, 29: 3, 512-524; 35 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Mosquito abundance and western equine encephalomyelitis (WEE) and St. L=
ouis
  encephalitis (SLE) virus activity were monitored in 5 valleys in southeas=
tern
  California, USA, from June 1986 to April 1990 to study virus overwinterin=
g and
  possible dissemination from south to north along geographically defined
  corridors. Culex tarsalis predominated in CO2 trap collections and was th=
e only
  species repeatedly infected with WEE and SLE viruses. Abundance peaked du=
ring
  April-May and August-October. WEE virus infections in C. tarsalis general=
ly
  were detected after the spring peak and were followed about 1 month later=
 by
  seroconversions in sentinel chickens. SLE virus infections occurred later=
 in
  the summer but before the autumn peak in C. tarsalis abundance. Peak C.
  tarsalis abundance occurred when monthly temperatures averaged 25=B0C, wh=
ereas
  virus infections generally were detected most frequently when temperature=
s
  exceeded 29=B0C. Although the spring increase in C. tarsalis abundance oc=
curred
  earlier in southern valleys, the onset of virus activity was variable amo=
ng
  valleys and did not follow a south to north progression.
DE: Disease-vectors; Ecology-; Population-ecology; Seasonality-; Sentinel
  -animals; Bait-traps; Mosquito-borne-diseases; epidemiology-
OD: Diptera-; Culicidae-; Alphavirus-; Flavivirus-; Fowls-; arboviruses-; C=
ulex
  -tarsalis; Western-equine-encephalitis-virus; St-Louis-encephalitis-virus
GE: USA-; California-; North-America
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; Dip=
tera;
  Togaviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Flaviviridae; Gallus-gallus; Gallus;
  Phasianidae; Galliformes; birds; Culex; Culicidae; equine-encephalomyelit=
is
  -virus; Alphavirus; Flavivirus; North-America; America; Pacific-States-of=
-USA;
  Western-States-of-USA; USA
CC: LL820; TT300

-and
  -Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued

Record 646 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Influenza in commercial broiler breeders.
AU: Halvorson-DA; Sivanandan-V; Lauer-D
AD: College of Veterinary Medicine, University of Minnesota, St. Paul, MN 5=
5108,
  USA.
SO: Avian-Diseases. 1992, 36: 1, 177-179; 5 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
LS: Spanish
AB: Influenza was detected in a flock of broiler breeders during routine
  serological monitoring. Although there were no clinical signs, egg produc=
tion
  may have been affected in hens in part of a breeder house. Intensive meas=
ures
  were taken to avoid transmission to other farms. Two months after the flo=
ck was
  found to be serologically positive, sentinel hens were placed in the floc=
k;
  they became serologically positive 1 month later. In spite of this eviden=
ce for
  virus being present in the flock, no detectable transmission to any other=
 farm
  occurred.

Record 647 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Five new isolates of the mosquito pathogenic fungus Lagenidium giganteu=
m
  (Oomycetes: Lagenidiales) from Colombia.
AU: Orduz-S; Zuluaga-JS; Diaz-T; Rojas-W
AD: Biological Control Unit, Corporacion para Investigaciones Biologicas,
  Apartado Aereo 7378, Medellin, Colombia.
SO: Memorias-do-Instituto-Oswaldo-Cruz. 1992, 87: 4, 597-599; 10 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: During 1988-91, five isolates of L. giganteum were found in 3 different
  mosquito habitats in Colombia. Two (CIB 79-MED and CIB 79-TDT) were isola=
ted in
  semi-permanent pools in the Uraba area, infecting larvae of Aedes sp. and=
 Culex
  quinquefasciatus, respectively. In Quibdo, CIB 163-PDH was isolated using
  sentinel cages baited with larvae of C. quinquefasciatus. During 1991, CI=
B 183
  -ARU was isolated from water and detritus collected from bromeliads in Ar=
usi,
  and CIB 183-NUQ from water samples from a permanent pool in Nuqui. In bot=
h
  cases, 1st-instar larvae of A. aegypti were exposed to the samples, and f=
ungi
  were isolated after 2 and 5 days, respectively. In all cases fungi infect=
ing
  the mosquito larvae were morphologically indistinguishable from L. gigant=
eum.
  The pathogenicities of these strains of L. giganteum were compared to tho=
se of
  strains from the USA (CA, NC and LA) and Australia (ARSEF 2532) using 3-d=
ay-old
  larvae of C. quinquefasciatus. Isolates ARSEF 2532, CIB 183-ARU and CIB 1=
63
  -PDCH did not cause mortality at any of the dosages tested. CIB 79-MED an=
d CIB
  79-TDT showed lower pathogenicity than the North American isolates at the=
 lower
  doses, but caused similar mortality at higher doses. CIB 183-NUQ caused
  comparable mortality to CA at all dosages.
DE: Entomopathogens-; Pathogenicity-; Aquatic-insects; entomogenous-fungi;
  pathogens-; hosts-
OD: Diptera-; Lagenidiales-; Aedes-; Culex-quinquefasciatus; Lagenidium
  -giganteum; Culicidae-
GE: Colombia-; South-America
ID: Oomycetes
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; aquatic-arthropods; aquati=
c
  -invertebrates; aquatic-animals; fungi; Mastigomycotina; Eumycota; Culici=
dae;
  Diptera; Culex; Lagenidium; Lagenidiales; South-America; America
CC: LL820; HH100; TT300; MM300; VV200
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Biologi=
cal
  -Control; Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Aquatic
  -Biology-and-Ecology; Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases=
-of
  -Humans
PT: Journal-article

Record 648 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Investigation into the use of Zostera muelleri (Irmische ex Aschers) as=
 a
  sentinel accumulator for copper.
AU: Carter-RJ; Eriksen-RS
AD: Centre for Aquatic Science, Deakin University, P.O. Box 423, Warrnamboo=
l,
  Vict. 3280, Australia.
SO: Science-of-the-Total-Environment. 1992, 125: 185-192; 12 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: The aquatic angiosperm Z. muelleri, which is the dominant macrophyte in=
 some
  Australian coastal waters and estuaries, was cultured in a controlled
  environment cabinet to assess its potential use as a sentinel accumulator=
 for
  copper. Copper concn ranging from those occurring naturally to those indi=
cative
  of severe pollution were supplied to the plants. Copper levels in the pla=
nts
  corresponded to ambient concn in the aquatic environment.

Record 649 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Identification of red maple cultivars by isozyme analysis.
AU: Tobolski-JJ; Kemery-RD
AD: Department of Biological Sciences, Indiana University-Purdue University=
,
  2101 Coliseum Boulevard, East Fort Wayne, IN 46805-1499, USA.
SO: HortScience. 1992, 27: 2, 169-171; 11 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Dormant bud tissue from two or more trees representing 18 red maple (Ac=
er
  rubrum) cultivars was subjected to isozyme analyses using starch-gel
  electrophoresis. Polymorphic enzymes resolved were alcohol dehydrogenase,
  peroxidase, phosphoglucose isomerase [glucose-6-phosphate isomerase], glu=
tamate
  oxaloacetate transaminase [aspartate aminotransferase], leucine [cytosol]
  aminopeptidase, acid phosphatase and malic dehydrogenase. An enzyme patte=
rn or
  combination of patterns was useful in identifying the following individua=
ls:
  Autumn Blaze, Autumn Flame, Bowhall, Celebration, Columnare, Curtis, Dori=
c,
  Firedance, Gerling, V. J. Drake, Morgan, Northwood, Scarlet Sentinel,
  Schlesingeri and Tilford. Armstrong, October Glory and Red Sunset could n=
ot be
  distinguished from each other on the basis of enzymes examined in this st=
udy.
DE: Biotechnology-; Electrophoresis-; Broadleaves-; Ornamental-woody-plants=
;
  variety-classification; isoenzymes-; Genetics-
OD: Acer-rubrum
BT: dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta; plants; ornamental-plants; Ac=
er;
  Aceraceae; Sapindales
CC: FF020; WW000; KK100; KK160
CD: Plant-Breeding-and-Genetics; Biotechnology; Forestry-General; Arboricul=
ture

Record 650 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Vector competence parameters of Culicoides variipennis (Diptera:
  Ceratopogonidae) for bluetongue virus serotype 2.
AU: Tanya-VN; Greiner-EC; Shroyer-DA; Gibbs-EPJ
AD: Department of Infectious Diseases, College of Veterinary Medicine, Box
  110880, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Medical-Entomology. 1993, 30: 1, 204-208; 22 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: Culicoides variipennis, the only proven vector of bluetongue virus (BLU=
) in
  the western hemisphere, was evaluated as a vector of bluetongue virus ser=
otype
  2 (BLU 2). This serotype was isolated from sentinel cattle in south Flori=
da at
  a site devoid of C. variipennis. C. variipennis readily fed on a mixture =
of
  defibrinated blood and BLU 2 through chicken skin membrane. An infection =
rate
  of 46.2% was obtained. A growth curve of virus titres recovered from oral=
ly
  infected flies showed a linear relationship between the virus titres and =
the
  period of extrinsic incubation. C. variipennis also became infected when
  inoculated intrathoracically with BLU 2. Peak titres were higher and more
  rapidly attained in inoculated flies when compared with orally infected f=
lies.
  Infected C. variipennis also transmitted BLU 2 to sheep via bite. These r=
esults
  demonstrate that C. variipennis is a potential biological vector of BLU 2=
 in
  the laboratory. The implication of this for epidemiology is that BLU 2 sh=
ould
  have become more widespread in ruminants in the USA. The fact that this h=
as not
  occurred during the past 10 years is discussed.
DE: Disease-vectors; Infection-; Transmission-; vector-competence; viral
  -diseases; disease-transmission; sheep-diseases
OD: Diptera-; Ceratopogonidae-; Arboviruses-; Orbivirus-; Reoviridae-; Shee=
p-;
  Culicoides-variipennis; bluetongue-virus; Culicoides-
GE: USA-; Florida-
ID: Vector-potential
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; Diptera; viruses; Reovirid=
ae;
  arboviruses; Ovis; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates=
;
  Chordata; ungulates; Culicoides; Ceratopogonidae; Orbivirus; North-Americ=
a;
  America; South-Atlantic-States-of-USA; Southern-States-of-USA; USA; Gulf-=
States
  -of-USA; Southeastern-States-of-USA
CC: LL820; TT300
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Medical=
-and
  -Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0022-2585

TI: Developments in fruit fly trapping.
CA: New Zealand, National Agriculture Security Service.
AD: Ministry of Agricuture and Fisheries, P.O. Box 2526, Wellington, New Ze=

LA: English
AB: The system of monitoring for tephritids in New Zealand was updated in 1=
989.
  Lure traps (containing a synthetic sex attractant) and bait traps (contai=
ning a
  food source) are used. The Lynfield lure traps is particularly sensitive =
to
  small populations of the pests.

Record 652 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Sentinel herd study of bluetongue virus in Puerto Rico.
AU: Shaw-J
AD: Veterinary Services, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, U.S.
  Department of Agriculture, Arecibo Station, P.O. Box 494, Arecibo, Puerto=
 Rico
  00613.
SO: Annals-of-the-New-York-Academy-of-Sciences. 1992, 653: 194-196; 1 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Three sentinel herds were monitored: a large Holstein dairy farm in May=
aguez
  on the river flood plain near the west coast, a Brown Swiss dairy herd at
  Sabana Grande in the south of the island (a tropical forest region), and =
a
  Holstein dairy farm in Naguabo, a lush area of foothills around the easte=
rn
  mountains of the Caribbean National Forest. From February 1990 a heparini=
zed
  and clotted blood sample were taken from 20-25 calves from each farm. If =
the
  clotted sample was positive for bluetongue antibodies by the agar gel
  immunodiffusion test (AGID) the heparinized tube from that month and the
  previous month were sent for virus isolation. 28 of 67 calves from Mayagu=
ez
  seroconverted, 17 of them had previously shown maternal antibodies. 11 of=
 the
  calves seroconverted at 7-8 months old. Bluetongue virus serotype 17 was
  isolated from 1 animal. At Sabana Grande 30 of 63 calves seroconverted, 1=
6
  having previously demonstrated maternal antibodies. 24 seroconverted in
  November. Serotype 17 was isolated from 3 animals. At Naguabo, 3 calves
  seroconverted at 5 months of age in June and 21 at 9 months of age in Aug=
ust at
  a time of increased rainfall. Bluetongue virus was isolated from 16 calve=
s
  (serotype 17 from 10 and serotype 6 from 4 animals). None of the cows in
  sentinel herds showed clinical signs of bluetongue. During August 1990
  bluetongue was diagnosed by AGID in 2 animals with clinical signs of the
  disease at a Holstein dairy farm in Isabela on the north shore of the isl=
and.
DE: Immunodiffusion-tests; Disease-control; Viral-diseases; Sentinel-animal=
s;
  epidemiology-; cattle-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: cattle-; Bluetongue-virus; Arboviruses-; Orbivirus-; Reoviridae-; sheep=
-
GE: Puerto-Rico
ID: sentinel-herds
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla;

Record 653 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Epidemiology of bluetongue viruses in the American tropics.
AU: Gibbs-EPJ; Homan-EJ; Mo-CL; Greiner-EC; Gonzalez-J; Thompson-LH; Oveido=
-MT;
  Walton-TE; Yuill-TM
AD: College of Veterinary Medicine, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL
  32610, USA.
SO: Annals-of-the-New-York-Academy-of-Sciences. 1992, 653: 243-250; 34 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: To date, over 200 bluetongue virus isolates have been obtained from cat=
tle
  and sheep in sentinel groups distributed in 11 Central American and Carib=
bean
  countries. Bluetongue serotypes identified include 1, 3, 6 and 12, virus =
types
  not previously recorded in the Western Hemisphere. Although the clinical =
impact
  of bluetongue virus infections in this hyperendemic environment appears t=
o be
  minimal, the ubiquity of infection causes restrictions on the export of
  ruminant livestock and germ plasm. The stability of the Caribbean region
  ecosystem and the long-range implications of the interface with the north=
ern
  temperate bluetongue virus ecosystem are reviewed.
DE: Viral-diseases; Epidemiology-; Reviews-; livestock-
OD: Bluetongue-virus; Cattle-; Sheep-; Orbivirus-; Arboviruses-; Culicoides=
-

  Ceratopogonidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; America

Record 654 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Report on the eradication of African swine fever in Belgium, 1985.
AU: Vermeersch-JP; Galo-A
AD: Ministry of Agriculture, Veterinary Service, Manhattan Office Tower, Av=
enue
  du Boulevard 21, 1210 Brussels, Belgium.
SO: Agriculture: Coordination of agricultural research: African swine fever=
:
  proceedings of a workshop within the Community programme for coordination=
 of
  agricultural research, Lisbon, Portugal, 7, 8 and 9 October, 1991. 1993, =
237
  -245.
PB: Commission of the European Communities; Luxembourg
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: African swine fever appeared for the first time in Belgium on March 8th
  1985. In the course of 3 months 12 outbreaks were recorded. The disease
  occurred in one of the most dense pig populations in the world. Neverthel=
ess
  its spread was confined to a small region. Thorough epidemiological inqui=
ries
  revealed the source of infection. The virus was believed to have been
  introduced into the country by feeding a boar with a meat product brought=
 home
  from abroad by a tourist. Further spread of the disease was caused by dir=
ect
  contact, i.e. the transport of infected piglets or indirect personal cont=
act.
  All pigs (a total of 35 000) on farms with outbreaks and on 48 high risk =
farms
  were destroyed. After disinfection and before repopulating, "sentinel" pi=
glets
  were placed on the farms. Some 500 pig-farms were kept under close survei=
llance
  as a result of the epidemiological research. Restrictions were also place=
d on
  moving of pigs in the surrounding area. The measures were gradually allev=
iated
  or abolished after a massive serological screening of all 3813 farms in t=
he
  infected area. All measures, except the export of fresh pig-meat produced
  during a certain period in the infected area, were abolished on September=
 23rd
  1985.
DE: Viral-diseases; African-swine-fever; disease-control; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-
GE: Belgium-
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; Western-Europe; Europe
CC: LL820; HH000
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Pathoge=
n,
  -Pest-and-Parasite-Management-General
PT: Miscellaneous
AV: ECU 30
IB: 92-826-5148-7
UD: 950316
AN: 932282829

TI: Natural infection in vertebrate hosts other than man.

  Health, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA.

943
  -1987. 1990, 26-65; many ref.

  California; USA
PY: 1990
LA: English
AB: This chapter reviews studies on vertebrate reservoirs of mosquito-borne
  arboviruses, particularly St. Louis encephalitis and western equine
  encephalitis virus, but also Turlock, Hart Park and other viruses, in
  California, USA, with emphasis on findings from 1953 to 1987 resulting fr=
om
  serological surveys or virus isolations in equines and other domestic mam=
mals
  (cattle, sheep, pigs, dogs and goats), domestic fowl (including use as se=
ntinel
  hosts), wild birds, wild mammals, caged primates, amphibians and reptiles=
.

Record 656 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Development of a statewise arbovirus surveillance program and models of
  vector populations and virus transmission.
AU: Reeves-WC; Milby-MM; Reisen-WK; Reeves-WC
AD: Department of Biomedical and Environmental Health Sciences, School of P=
ublic
  Health, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA.
SO: Epidemiology-and-control-of-mosquito-borne-arboviruses-in-California,-1=
943
  -1987. 1990, 431-459; many ref.
PB: California Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc.; Sacramento,
  California; USA
PY: 1990
LA: English
AB: This chapter illustrates how the research programme on western equine
  encephalitis (WEE) and St. Louis encephalitis (SLE), primarily in Kern Co=
unty,
  California, USA, led to the development of a statewise arbovirus surveill=
ance
  programme of the activity of these viruses in vectors and sentinel birds =
which
  has been in effect since 1953 to provide an early warning system to allow
  mosquito control agencies to intensify their work effectively. In the 197=
0s
  several research groups began constructing models on the biology of Culex
  tarsalis populations to facilitate understanding of how biological and ph=
ysical
  factors interact to influence arbovirus transmission and control. Progres=
s was
  slow, but simulation and time series models have since been developed tow=
ards
  these ends.
DE: Control-programmes; Models-; Mosquito-borne-diseases; Viral-diseases;
  Sentinel-animals; DISEASE-SURVEYS; Disease-control; Monitoring-; control-=

s;
  Culex-tarsalis; arboviruses-

ID: Vector-control

Record 657 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Japanese encephalitis in Sri Lanka - the study of an epidemic: vector
  incrimination, porcine infection and human diseases.
AU: Peiris-JSM; Amerasinghe-FP; Amerasinghe-PH; Ratnayake-CB; Karunaratne-S=
HPP;
  Tsai-TF
AD: Department of Microbiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Peradeni=
ya,
  Sri Lanka.
SO: Transactions-of-the-Royal-Society-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 199=
2,
  86: 3, 307-313; 24 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: A prospective study of mosquito vectors, porcine infection and human di=
sease
  was carried out during a Japanese encephalitis (JE) epidemic in the North
  Central province of Sri Lanka (in November-December 1987) and a subsequen=
t non
  -epidemic year (1988). The epidemic involved 361 cases of human encephali=
tis
  virologically confirmed by IgM ELISA, and was preceded 2-3 weeks earlier =
by
  sentinel pig seroconversion. Virus isolation and viral antigen detection
  (ELISA) in field-caught mosquitoes incriminated Culex tritaeniorhynchus a=
nd C.
  gelidus as the major vectors of virus transmission during the porcine
  amplification and human 'spill-over' phases of the epidemic. Virus was al=
so
  demonstrated in C. fuscocephala, C. whitmorei and Mansonia uniformis duri=
ng the
  epidemic. The major difference between the epidemic (1987) and non-epidem=
ic
  (1988) years was a lower vector biomass and lower rates of virus carriage=
 in
  the mosquito population.
DE: Sentinel-animals; Viral-diseases; Disease-vectors; Mosquito-borne-disea=
ses;
  Human-diseases; Japanese-encephalitis; epidemiology-
OD: Diptera-; Pigs-; Man-; Arboviruses-; Flavivirus-; Culex-tritaeniorhynch=
us;
  Japanese-encephalitis-virus; Culex-gelidus; Mansonia-uniformis; Culicidae=
-
GE: Sri-Lanka; Asia-
ID: Culex-fuscocephala; Culex-whitmorei
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; Sus=

Record 658 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Comparison of sentinel and naturally occurring fly pupae to measure fie=
ld
  parasitism by pteromalid parasitoids (Hymenoptera).
AU: Petersen-JJ; Watson-DW
AD: Midwest Livestock Insects Research Unit, Agricultural Research Service,=
 US
  Department of Agriculture, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE 68583-0938=
, USA.
SO: Biological-Control. 1992, 2: 3, 244-248; 17 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: In a series of studies conducted over a 4-year period in Nebraska, USA,=
 the
  effectiveness of releases of pteromalid wasps for the control of Musca
  domestica and Stomoxys calcitrans in beef cattle confinements was evaluat=
ed
  using sentinel house fly pupae (artificially reared and placed in the
  environment) and naturally occurring house fly and stable fly pupae. The =
2
  methods were compared using percentage parasitoid emergence and species
  composition. At confinements where no parasitoid releases occurred, paras=
itoid
  emergence was significantly higher from naturally occurring hosts. Muscid=
ifurax
  zaraptor comprised 97 and 76% of the parasitoids recovered from sentinel =
and
  naturally occurring hosts, respectively. Spalangia spp. made up 16% of th=
e
  parasitoids from naturally occurring hosts. Few Spalangia spp. were recov=
ered
  from sentinel hosts. Similar results were obtained from locations where M=
.
  zaraptor was released, except that M. zaraptor comprised a greater propor=
tion
  of the parasitoids recovered by both methods. At locations where S. camer=
oni
  was released, 76% of the parasitoids recovered from sentinel hosts were M=
.
  zaraptor, and 21% were S. cameroni, compared with 62% M. zaraptor and 34%=
 S.
  cameroni from naturally occurring hosts. At locations where Pachycrepoide=
us
  vindemmiae was released, this species was recovered significantly more of=
ten
  from sentinel hosts. Naturally occurring pupal methods appears to be more
  reliable and sensitive to the entire parasitoid species complex. However,
  because of the difficulty in obtaining adequate samples, it is recommende=
d that
  both methods be employed.
DE: Parasitoids-; Parasitism-; control-; biological-control; Cattle-housing=
;
  sampling-; biological-control-agents; evaluation-
OD: Diptera-; Hymenoptera-; Musca-domestica; Stomoxys-calcitrans; Muscidifu=
rax
  -zaraptor; Muscidae-; Spalangia-cameroni; Pachycrepoideus-vindemmiae;
  Pteromalidae-; arthropods-
GE: USA-; Nebraska-; North-America
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; Musca; Muscidae; Diptera;
  Stomoxys; Muscidifurax; Pteromalidae; Hymenoptera; Spalangia; Pachycrepoi=
deus;
  North-America; America; Great-Plains-States-of-USA; USA; Northern-Plains-=
States
  -of-USA; West-North-Central-States-of-USA; North-Central-States-of-USA
CC: VV300; LL820; TT300; HH000; HH100; LL100

Record 659 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Suppression of house flies (Diptera: Muscidae) on New York and Maryland
  dairies using releases of Muscidifurax raptor (Hymenoptera: Pteromalidae)=
 in an
  integrated management program.
AU: Geden-CJ; Rutz-DA; Miller-RW; Steinkraus-DC
AD: Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853-0999, US=
A.
SO: Environmental-Entomology. 1992, 21: 6, 1419-1426; 26 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: Releases of M. raptor were integrated with weekly removal of calf beddi=
ng
  and infrequent use of pyrethrins space sprays for management of Musca dom=
estica
  on 7 dairy farms in New York State and Maryland, USA; 6 other farms were =
used
  as controls. Baited traps were used for supplemental outdoor fly control =
on
  release farms in Maryland. Parasitoid releases were made by weekly placem=
ent of
  either 25 000 (in New York) or 20 000 (in Maryland) parasitized housefly =
pupae
  in screen bags on each farm, resulting in weekly release rates of 12 000 =
and
  9600 female parasitoids per farm per week, respectively. Overall season-l=
ong
  fly pupal mortality (as measured by sentinel fly pupae) was 65 and 38% on
  release farms in New York and Maryland, respectively, compared with 30 an=
d 26%
  on control farms. Overall parasitism was 36 and 18% on release farms in N=
ew
  York and Maryland, respectively, compared with 5 and 3% on control farms.=
 Fly
  populations on control farms in both states were approximately twice as l=
arge
  as on release farms based on spot card and resting fly counts inside the =
barns.
  Producers on control farms in New York made an average of 14.7 insecticid=
e
  applications (space sprays, baits and residual premise treatments) for ho=
usefly
  control compared with 2.7 insecticide applications (pyrethrins space spra=
ys) on
  release farms.
DE: Parasitoids-; Insecticides-; Chemical-control; Pest-control; Bait-traps=
;
  control-; biological-control; Pyrethrins-; dairies-; Integrated-control
OD: Hymenoptera-; Pteromalidae-; Diptera-; Muscidae-; Musca-domestica;
  Muscidifurax-raptor; arthropods-
GE: USA-; New-York; Maryland-; North-America
ID: Manure-management
BT: pesticides; botanical-insecticides; insecticides; insects; arthropods;
  invertebrates; animals; Hymenoptera; Diptera; Musca; Muscidae; Muscidifur=
ax;
  Pteromalidae; North-America; America; Middle-Atlantic-States-of-USA;
  Northeastern-States-of-USA; USA; South-Atlantic-States-of-USA; Southern-S=
tates
  -of-USA

Record 660 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Subclinical infectious bursal disease in an integrated broiler producti=
on
  operation.
AU: Homer-BL; Butcher-GD; Miles-RD; Rossi-AF
AD: Department of Comparative and Experimental Pathology, University of Flo=
rida,
  Gainesville, FL 32610, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Veterinary-Diagnostic-Investigation. 1992, 4: 4, 406-411; 20=
 ref.
PY: 1992
LA: English
AB: A field study was designed to determine the prevalence of subclinical
  infectious bursal disease (IBD) in broiler chickens from a commercial pou=
ltry
  company. Bursa of fabricii (BF) from 2 vaccinated and 3 nonvaccinated bro=
iler
  flocks were evaluated histologically, and antibody profiles of these broi=
ler
  and matched parent breeder flocks were established. Lesions of IBD, inclu=
ding
  lymphoid necrosis, stromal oedema, and infiltrates of heterophils and
  macrophages, were first detected in BF at 24 days of age in both vaccinat=
ed and
  nonvaccinated chickens. At 41 days, all BF had lesions characteristic of =
IBD,
  including severe lymphoid depletion, proliferation of epithelial cells, a=
nd
  mild fibroplasia. Although mean maternal antibody levels (measured by enz=
yme
  -linked immunosorbent assay) in broilers were apparently protective until=
 day
  12, IBD antibodies decreased to nonprotective levels (below 1000) by day =
16 or
  20. Titres began to increase by day 28 or 32 because of field exposure.
  Sentinel birds, placed with broiler flocks, also developed IBD antibody t=
itres.
  Broiler breeders had low and nonuniform antibody titres. Prevalence of fi=
eld
  IBD exposure was high, and existing vaccination programmes were not effec=
tive.
DE: poultry-; Viral-diseases; Immunization-; Pathology-; Disease-prevalence=
;
  broilers-; poultry-diseases
OD: Fowls-; Infectious-bursal-disease-virus
BT: birds; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; fowls; Gallus-gallus; Gallus;
  Phasianidae; Galliformes; Birnavirus; Birnaviridae; viruses
CC: LL820; HH600
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Host
  -Resistance-and-Immunity
PT: Journal-article
IS: 1040-6387
UD: 950316
AN: 932282022

Record 661 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: Dispersal behavior of two pteromalid parasitoids of house fly pupae in =
a
  dairy environment (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea).
AU: Smith-L; Gupta-VK
AD: Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, USA.
SO: Advances in parasitic Hymenoptera research. Proceedings of the II Confe=
rence
  on the Taxonomy and Biology of Parasitic Hymenoptera held at the Universi=
ty of
  Florida, Gainesville, Florida, November 19-21, 1987.  1988, 333-344; 24 r=
ef.
PB: E.J. Brill; Leiden; Netherlands
PY: 1988
LA: English
AB: A study was conducted during an inundative release programme at a comme=
rcial
  dairy farm in central New York state, USA. Local strains of Muscidifurax =
raptor
  and Urolepis rufipes were released weekly for 7 weeks. Dispersal behaviou=
r was
  monitored by parasitism rates of lab-reared housefly (Musca domestica) pu=
pae
  exposed in sentinel bags placed in a variety of locations. Muscidifurax r=
aptor,
  which was released inside the barn, parasitized housefly pupae both insid=
e and
  outside, and it achieved highest rates of parasitism in indoor straw calf
  -bedding and in outdoor manure and silage. U. rufipes, which was released
  outside the barn, did not attack pupae inside tha barn, and its highest r=
ates
  of parasitism occurred in outdoor silage and manure. Interspecific compet=
ition
  did not appear to explain these distribution patterns. Warm weather coinc=
ided
  with a peak in parasitism rate at samples located on walls, suggesting a =
higher
  flight activity. Cool weather interrupted parasitism at the sites on wall=
s but
  not in the various fly-breeding substrates. M. raptor appear to be more
  effective than U. rufipes in parasitizing pupae located at sites where na=
tural
  fly-breeding occurred. High rates of parasitism by M. raptor near open do=
orways
  and at outdoor sites 30 m away suggests that they were dispersing through=
out
  the barn and its immediate surroundings.
DE: Dispersal-; Behaviour-; Cattle-housing; Dairies-; Cattle-manure; parasi=
toids
  -; parasitism-; Biological-control; control-; evaluation-; biology-; biol=
ogical
  -control-agents
OD: Hymenoptera-; Diptera-; Muscidae-; Musca-domestica; Muscidifurax-raptor=
;
  Pteromalidae-; arthropods-
GE: USA-; New-York
ID: Urolepis-rufipes; Taxonomy-and-Biology-of-Parasitic-Hymenoptera
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; Diptera; Musca; Muscidae;
  Muscidifurax; Pteromalidae; Hymenoptera; North-America; America; Middle
  -Atlantic-States-of-USA; Northeastern-States-of-USA; USA
CC: LL820; HH100; TT300; LL100; HH000; VV300; LL300
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Biologi=
cal
  -Control; Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Animal
  -Husbandry-General; Pathogen,-Pest-and-Parasite-Management-General; Publi=
c
  -Health-and-Nuisance-Pests; Animal-Behaviour
PT: Conference-paper
IB: 0-916846-50-4
UD: 950316
AN: 930516669

Record 662 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: A compilation of data on arbovirus surveillance in Manitoba: 1975-1991.
AU: Sekla-L; Gadawski-R; Nayar-G; Brust-R
AD: Cadham Provincial Laboratory, 750 William Avenue, Winnipeg, Manitoba R3=
C
  3Y1, Canada.
SO: Proceedings-of-the-Entomological-Society-of-Manitoba. 1991, 47: 30-43; =
8 ref.
PY: 1991
LA: English
AB: Data on arboviruses in Manitoba, Canada, are compiled for a 17-year per=
iod,
  1975-91. Western equine encephalitis virus is endemic in Manitoba, yet
  epidemics/epizootics develop infrequently, with 4 epidemics recorded duri=
ng the
  study period: 1975, 1977, 1981 and 1983. A multi-disciplinary surveillanc=
e was
  started in 1975 and remained active for 10 years, during which mosquito
  populations, especially those of Culex tarsalis, mosquito arboviral infec=
tion
  rates and seroconversion in sentinel chicken flocks were monitored in a n=
umber
  of locations throughout Manitoba. In addition, serosurveys were done on
  potential reservoir hosts, and serologically confirmed equine and human c=
ases
  were recorded. After 1986, the surveillance was limited to the City of Wi=
nnipeg
  data on mosquito populations and seroconversion in chicken flocks. Crude
  criteria were developed to forecast epidemics and were successful in pred=
icting
  the 1977, 1981 and 1983 outbreaks. Experience has shown that multiple
  parameters are needed for monitoring arboviral outbreaks, and that the mo=
nth of
  July is critical in predicting epidemics. It is proposed that a multi
  -disciplinary surveillance be re-instituted, and that 1-2 locations be
  monitored for mosquito populations and infection rates, as well as for
  seroconversion in chickens. If funds are limited, the surveillance could =
be
  restricted to a 4-6 week period, including the month of July.
DE: Disease-vectors; Serological-surveys; Sentinel-animals; Monitoring-;
  Forecasting-; Mosquito-borne-diseases; epidemiology-
OD: Diptera-; Culicidae-; Alphavirus-; Togaviridae-; Fowls-; Horses-; Man-;
  arboviruses-; Western-equine-encephalitis-virus; Culex-tarsalis
GE: Canada-; Manitoba-; North-America
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; Dip=
tera;
  Togaviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Gallus-gallus; Gallus; Phasianidae;
  Galliformes; birds; Equus; Equidae; Perissodactyla; mammals; ungulates; H=
omo;
  Hominidae; Primates; equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Alphavirus; Culex;
  Culicidae; North-America; America; Canada
CC: VV200; LL820; TT300
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Parasite=
s,
  -Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Medical-and-Veterin=
ary
  -Entomology-Records-Discontinued
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0315-2146
UD: 950316
AN: 930516730

Record 663 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1993-1994

TI: A comparison of the efficacy of two commercial Aujeszky's disease vacci=
nes
  with glycoprotein-I deletion in pigs.
AU: Motha-MJX; Horner-GW; Tham-KM; Ralston-JC
AD: MAF Quality Management, Central Animal Health Laboratory, Wallaceville
  Animal Research Centre, P.O. Box 40-063, Upper Hutt, New Zealand.
SO: New-Zealand-Veterinary-Journal. 1993, 41: 1, 1-6; 17 ref.
PY: 1993
LA: English
AB: Two commercial Aujeszky's disease vaccines, a modified killed vaccine a=
nd a
  sub-unit vaccine, both carrying a deletion of glycoprotein-I, were evalua=
ted in
  pigs. Each vaccine was administered to 2 groups of 4 pigs, twice at 4-wee=
k
  intervals, with 2 pigs held as unvaccinated controls. All pigs were chall=
enged
  with a New Zealand field isolate of Aujeszky's disease virus 3 weeks afte=
r the
  second vaccination. The sub-unit vaccine was able to protect pigs against
  clinical Aujeszky's disease much better than the pigs vaccinated with the
  modified killed vaccine when challenged with a virulent virus. However, t=
he
  amount and the duration of virulent virus excretion following challenge w=
as
  greater with the sub-unit vaccine than the modified killed vaccine. Pigs
  vaccinated with the sub-unit vaccine were shown to be latently infected
  following challenge. Latent infection was demonstrated by excretion of
  Aujeszky's disease virus from the nasal cavity after dexamethasone treatm=
ent
  and seroconversion of a sentinel in-contact pigs to Aujeszky's disease vi=
rus.
DE: Viral-diseases; Immunization-; Experimental-infections; Immune-response=
;
  Biotechnology-; Aujeszky's-disease; vaccines-; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates
CC: LL820; HH600; WW000
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Host
  -Resistance-and-Immunity; Biotechnology
