Record 938 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: The isolation of a fourth bovine ephemeral fever group virus.
AU: Gard-GP; Cybinski-DH; Zakrzewski-H
AD: Dep. Primary Prod., PO Box 4160, Darwin, Northern Territory 5794, Austr=
alia.
SO: Australian-Veterinary-Journal. 1984, 61: 10, 332; 8 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: A virus designated DPP61 virus or Adelaide River virus, isolated from t=
he
  blood of a sentinel steer at Tortilla Flat, Northern Territory, in March =
1981,
  belonged to the bovine ephemeral fever (BEF) group of viruses but was
  serologically distinct from them. Antibody titres above 32 to this virus =
were
  found in cattle in Papua New Guinea, Northern Territory and Queensland, b=
ut not
  New South Wales. Also positive were 7 of 50 buffaloes and 4 of 96 pigs.
  Adelaide River virus is the fourth known member of the BEF group. CSIRO 3=
88
  virus or Tortilla Flat virus is now designated Kimberley virus.
DE: Viral-diseases; Epidemiological-surveys; cattle-diseases

Record 939 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Some evidence of mechanical transmission of reticuloendotheliosis virus=
 by
  mosquitoes.
AU: Motha-MXJ; Egerton-JR; Sweeney-AW
AD: Dep. Vet. Clin. Studies, Univ. Sydney, Camden, NSW 2570, Australia.
SO: Avian-Diseases. 1984, 28: 4, 858-867; 12 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
LS: Spanish
AB: Population peaks of mosquitoes in poultry pens, were seen in February,
  March, and April, and the dominant species, Culex quinqufasciatus was pre=
sent
  throughout the year. From the 39 batches of mosquitoes examined
  reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) was isolated on seven occasions: once i=
n
  summer and six times in autumn. Isolation of REV twice from unengorged
  mosquitoes from a pen with persistently viraemic chickens and once from
  engorged mosquitoes in a pen with sentinel chickens implied that feeding =
on the
  viraemic birds had been interrupted. Mechanical transmission of REV could=
 have
  occurred when unengorged mosquitoes contaminated with REV completed their
  feeding on sentinel chickens. The birds developed REV antibodies after RE=
V
  isolation from sentinel pens. REV was experimentally transmitted from
  persistently viraemic donor chickens to a recipient chicken using C.
  annulirostris.=20

Record 940 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Studies on the diagnosis and control of influenza virus infection of tu=
rkeys.
AU: Karunakaran-D
AD: Univ., Minneapolis, Minnesota 55455, USA.
SO: Dissertation-Abstracts-International,-B. 1985, 45: 7, 2068.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: In a two-year study the weekly influenzavirus isolation rate from cloac=
al
  swabs of sentinel ducks in turkey-rearing areas ranged from 0 to 24.4%. 2=
13
  influenzaviruses were isolated from the ducks and 26 subtypes were detect=
ed. 8
  influenzavirus subtypes were involved in 97 outbreaks of influenza in tur=
key
  flocks, and 7 were also detected in the sentinel ducks or in other birds.
  Electron microscopy of tracheal epithelium of turkeys infected with avian
  influenzavirus H7N3 and H5N2 showed disoriented cilia, deformed cilia and=
 areas
  of deciliation. Turkey breeder hens immunized with an inactivated oil emu=
lsion
  vaccine were protected against a severe drop in egg production. Immunizat=
ion of
  fattening turkeys (2 doses 4-5 weeks apart) reduced viral replication in =
the
  lung and trachea, and minimized the effect of challenge infection on the =
air
  sacs. Of three antiviral agents (ribavirin, amantadine and rimantadine)
  amantadine was the most effective when administered orally for at least t=
wo
  days after challenge.
DE: poultry-; Viral-diseases; Epidemiological-surveys; Immunization-;
  Inactivated-vaccines; Antiviral-agents; Drug-therapy; poultry-diseases
OD: Avian-influenzavirus; turkeys-

Record 941 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: The present status of schistosomiasis in the Philippines.
AU: Santos-AT
AD: Schistosomiasis Control & Res. Serv., Ministry of Health, Manila,
  Philippines.
SO: Southeast-Asian-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Public-Health. 1984, 1=
5: 4,
  439-445; 1 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: The schistosomiasis control programmes implemented in the Philippines, =
from
  1953 to present are briefly discussed. The effect of chemotherapy on the
  transmission of Schistosoma japonicum in 2 villages in Irosin, Philippine=
s, was
  determined. Persons positive for S. japonicum were treated with praziquan=
tel
  (60 mg/kg in 2 doses or 50 mg/kg single dose) in 3 succeeding years. The =
annual
  incidence dropped from 15.42% to 5.21% and 3.53% following the 1st and 2n=
d
  treatment but rose to 9.04% after the 3rd treatment because new cases had=
 been
  exposed to infection in endemic areas outside the study area. Chemotherap=
y of
  sentinel mice exposed to snail infested streams showed a drop in infectio=
n
  rates from 36% to 23/33% to 1.64% and to 1.66% after the 1st, 2nd and 3rd
  treatments respectively. Prevalence in the inhabitants of Irosin dropped =
from
  42.71% to 16.79%, 13.73% and 15.17% respectively after each consecutive
  treatment. A similar treatment programme in Leyte, Philippines, reduced t=
he
  prevalence of S. japonicum infection from 22.4% to 12.1%, 7.3% and 8.4% a=
fter
  the 1st, 2nd and 3rd treatments respectively.
DE: Anthelmintics-; control-; DRUG-THERAPY; Praziquantel-; parasites-; helm=
inths-
OD: Trematoda-; Digenea-; Schistosoma-japonicum; man-
GE: Philippines-; Asia-
RN: 55268-74-1
BT: invertebrates; animals; Platyhelminthes; Trematoda; Schistosoma;
  Schistosomatidae; Digenea; Homo; Hominidae; Primates; mammals; vertebrate=
s;
  Chordata; South-East-Asia; Asia
CC: VV200; HH400; TT100; HH000

Record 942 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Epizootiology of avian influenza: effect of season on incidence in sent=
inel
  ducks and domestic turkeys in Minnesota.
AU: Halvorson-DA; Kelleher-CJ; Senne-DA
AD: Coll. Vet. Med., Univ., St. Paul, Minnesota 55108, USA.
SO: Applied-and-Environmental-Microbiology. 1985, 49: 4, 914-919; 21 ref.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: Sentinel ducks and domestic turkey flocks were monitored for influenza =
over
  4 years. The onset of infection among ducks was similar each year, occurr=
ing in
  late July or early August. Influenza in turkeys was also seasonal, but th=
e
  usual onset was 6 to 8 weeks after the detection of influenza in ducks.
  Possible explanations for the delayed infection in turkeys are (i) increa=
sed
  waterfowl activity associated with fledging and congregating in late summ=
er and
  early autumn; (ii) vectors transmitting virus from the waterfowl habitat =
to
  poultry farms; (iii) cooler environmental temperature, allowing prolonged=
 virus
  viability; (iv) cooler surface water temperature, allowing prolonged viru=
s
  viability; (v) groundwater contamination from contaminated surface water;=
 and
  (vi) virus adaptation in domestic turkeys before infection is detected. I=
t was
  concluded that ducks are not only a natural reservoir of influenza but al=
so
  have a seasonal infection that appears to be related to seasonal influenz=
a
  outbreaks in domestic turkeys in Minnesota. However, only some influenza =
A
  virus isolates circulating among waterfowl at any given time appear capab=
le of
  causing infection in turkeys. It is suggested that the seasonal infection=
 in
  migratory waterfowl may also be related to seasonal influenza infections =
in
  other species including man.
DE: Epidemiological-surveys; Disease-transmission; viral-diseases
OD: Avian-influenzavirus; Turkeys-; Anseriformes-
GE: USA-; Minnesota-
BT: Influenzavirus; Orthomyxoviridae; viruses; Meleagris; Phasianidae;
  Galliformes; birds; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; North-America; Americ=
a;
  Lake-States-of-USA; North-Central-States-of-USA; USA; West-North-Central-=
States
  -of-USA

Record 943 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Serological and biochemical factors in bovine ephemeral fever.
AU: St-George-TD; Cybinski-DH; Murphy-GM; Dimmock-CK
AD: CSIRO, Long Pocket Lab., Private Bag No. 3, P.O., Indooroopilly, Queens=
land
  4068, Australia.
SO: Australian-Journal-of-Biological-Sciences. 1984, 37: 5-6, 341-349; 25 r=
ef.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: Clinical signs of ephemeral fever, observed in individual cattle during=
 two
  successive outbreaks in 1973 and 1976, were related to biochemical, cellu=
lar
  and serological changes in the blood. The rise in peripheral blood neutro=
phil
  counts in samples collected daily from 12 sentinel cattle before, during =
and
  after natural disease in the two outbreaks to mean peaks of 9.6-12.5 X 10=
9 per
  litre, and fall in counts of lymphocytes to a trough of 5-7 X 109 per lit=
re
  occurred on the same day as the fever peak. A fall in serum calcium level=
s from
  a normal mean of 2.55 to 2.0 mmol/l occurred on the day clinical signs we=
re
  most pronounced. Serum magnesium levels were affected to only a minor deg=
ree.
  Plasma fibrinogen rose from a normal mean of 5 to a peak of 18 g/l on the
  second day of disease and fell towards normal in the week after recovery.
  Neutralizing antibodies to bovine ephemeral fever virus were detected up =
to 63
  days prior to clinical disease, and the rise of antibody after recovery w=
as
  secondary in pattern. Serological evidence of a prior infection with an
  antigenically related virus, Kimberley virus, was found in these animals.=
 In
  more severe clinical cases of ephemeral fever serum calcium levels were a=
s low
  as 1.95 mmol/l. Treatment of cattle showing clinical signs of the disease=
 with
  phenylbutazone and calcium borogluconate was favourable.
DE: Viral-diseases; Haematology-; Drug-therapy; pathogenesis-; cattle-disea=
ses
OD: cattle-; Bovine-ephemeral-fever-virus
GE: Australia-
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Vesiculovirus; Rhabdoviridae; viruses; Australasia; Oc=
eania
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
UD: 950314
AN: 852262509

Record 944 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Two electropherotypes of bluetongue virus serotype 2 from naturally inf=
ected
  calves.
AU: Collisson-EW; Barber-TL; Gibbs-EPJ; Greiner-EC
AD: ARS, USDA, Arthropod-borne Anim. Dis. Res. Lab., PO Box 25327, Denver, =
CO
  80225, USA.
SO: Journal-of-General-Virology. 1985, 66: 6, 1279-1286; 32 ref.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: The first isolation of bluetongue virus (BTV) serotype 2 in the USA was=
 in
  1982 from a sentinel herd of cattle at Ona, Florida. Electrophoresis of g=
enome
  RNA showed that all 16 serotype 2 isolates from this focus of infection h=
ad one
  of two electropherotypes (Ona A and Ona B). All genome segments of Ona A =
and
  Ona B had detectable differences in electrophoretic mobility, with major
  differences noted for segments 1, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9 and 10. Electrophoretic
  comparison revealed that Ona A was indistinguishable from the African ser=
otype
  2 prototype isolated 23 years earlier. In 1983, Ona B, in the apparent ab=
sence
  of Ona A, was isolated from two additional cattle herds in Florida. These
  results suggest that Ona B may be a variant of Ona A that evolved as a re=
sult
  of mutation of reassortment with another BTV strain, and may be better ad=
apted
  to the selective pressures found in southern Florida. Comparison of the
  electropherotypes of Ona B with two Florida isolates of serotype 13 and 1=
7 and
  the prototypes of BTV 10, 11, 13 or 17 produced no evidence for reassortm=
ent
  between Ona A and any of these strains as the possible origin of Ona B.
DE: RNA-; Electrophoresis-; viral-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: Bluetongue-virus; cattle-; sheep-
GE: Florida-; USA-
ID: serotype-2
BT: Orbivirus; Reoviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants;
  Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Ovis; S=
outh
  -Atlantic-States-of-USA; Southern-States-of-USA; USA; North-America; Amer=
ica;
  Gulf-States-of-USA; Southeastern-States-of-USA

Record 945 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Growth of epizootic hemorrhagic disease, Akabane, and ephemeral fever
  viruses in Aedes albopictus cells maintained at various temperatures.
AU: Hoffmann-D; George-TD-St; St-George-TD
AD: Division of Tropical Animal Science, CSIRO, Long Pocket Laboratories,
  Private Bag No. 3, PO, Indooroopilly, Queensland 4068, Australia.
SO: Australian-Journal-of-Biological-Sciences. 1985, 38: 2, 183-188; 2 fig.=
; 24
  ref.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: Cell cultures of Aedes albopictus have been used for 4 years for the
  isolation of arboviruses in Australia. However, detailed information on t=
he
  growth of these viruses in the cells was lacking, so the effects of diffe=
rent
  incubation temperatures on the growth of 5 Australian arboviruses (one
  epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus serotype (Reoviridae), 2 Akabane vir=
us
  strains (Bunyaviridae) and 3 bovine ephemeral fever group viruses
  (Rhabdoviridae)) were investigated. A. albopictus cells supported the gro=
wth of
  all the viruses, but not necessarily at all the temperatures tested (15, =
20, 28
  and 33=B0C). It is not unusual to find 3 different arbovirus groups circu=
lating
  in an insect population and herd of sentinel cattle, and it is suggested =
that
  it may be possible to manipulate the isolation technique to favour the
  isolation of a particular virus.

dae;
  Orbivirus; Reoviridae

Record 946 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: The isolation from cattle of 2 bluetongue viruses new to Australia.
AU: Gard-GP; Shorthose-JE; Cybinski-DH; Zakrzewski-H
AD: Dep. Primary Prod., Box 4160, P.O., Darwin, N.T. 5794, Australia.
SO: Australian-Veterinary-Journal. 1985, 62: 6, 203; 7 ref.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: DPP90 and DPP192 viruses, isolated from the blood of sentinel steers at
  Tortilla Flat and at Coastal Plains Research Station in 1982, were identi=
fied
  by immunofluorescence as members of the bluetongue virus group. Compariso=
n of
  the five known Australian bluetongue group viruses in a microneutralizati=
on
  test showed them to be clearly distinguishable. Tests at a bank of frozen
  cattle serum revealed that DPP90 virus had been active in Northern Territ=
ory
  cattle since 1972, whereas antibody to DPP192 was first detected in sampl=
es
  collected in 1982. However, further investigations may show that these vi=
ruses
  existed in Australia before these dates.

Record 947 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: The coexistence of multiple bluetongue virus electropherotypes in indiv=
idual
  cattle during natural infection.
AU: Oberst-RD; Squire-KRE; Stott-JL; Chuang-RY; Osburn-BI
AD: Dep. Vet. Path., Sch. Vet. Med., Univ., Davis, CA 95616, USA.
SO: Journal-of-General-Virology. 1985, 66: 9, 1901-1909; 45 ref.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: Blood samples, collected weekly from 10 sentinel bull calves in Califor=
nia
  for 16 weeks (June-October), were examined for bluetongue virus (BTV) by
  culture in embryonated chicken eggs. Virus isolates were identified by pl=
aque
  inhibition-disc test against antisera of BTV serotypes 10, 11, 13 and 17 =
and
  epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus serotypes 1 and 2. dsRNAs were exami=
ned by
  polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE). BTV was recovered from all 10 =
calves
  during the trial, but no calf developed clinical signs. Serotypes 11 and =
17
  were isolated. Dual serotype infection was not indicated by plaque inhibi=
tion
  test but one calf did exhibit changes in serotype of virus isolated. PAGE
  identified genome segment diversity among serotype 11 isolates and also a=
n
  individual calf infected with multiple electropherotypes of this serotype=
. The
  results indicate that multiple plaque clonings and comparative electropho=
resis
  are required to identify BTV isolates in mixed infections.

OD: Bluetongue-virus; cattle-; sheep-

Record 949 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Arbovirus investigations in Argentina, 1977-1980. IV. Serologic surveys=
 and
  sentinel equine program.
AU: Monath-TP; Sabattini-MS; Pauli-R; Daffner-JF; Mitchell-CJ; Bowen-GS; Cr=
opp-CB
AD: Center Infectious Dis., PO Box 2087, Fort Collin, CO 80522, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1985, 34: 5, 966-975=
; 20
  ref.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: Serological surveys of wild birds, poultry, wild mammals and horses wer=
e
  conducted in Argentina between 1977 and 1980, while there was no epizooti=
c of
  equine encephalomyelitis. Neutralizing antibody to EEE (eastern equine
  encephalitis), which was present in 39 of 1309 wild birds, 6 of 245 domes=
tic
  birds and 99 of 892 horses, was more prevalent than that to WEE (western =
equine
  encephalitis) which was present in 9 of 1335 wild birds, 4 of 235 domesti=
c
  birds, 2 of 65 wild mammals and 18 of 892 horses. There was evidence of r=
ecent,
  endemic infection, particularly with a new subtype of WEE. Antibody to VE=
E
  (Venezuelan equine encephalitis) was also present in all areas (2 of 633 =
wild
  birds, 12 of 245 domestic birds, 18 of 892 horses and 20 of 65 mammals), =
with
  evidence of active transmission. Infection with St Louis encephalitis vir=
us was
  prevalent and widespread (41 of 1284 wild birds, 32 of 245 domestic birds=
, 517
  of 892 horses). A new, potential equine pathogen was Maguari bunyavirus w=
hich
  was present in 272 of 335 horses.
DE: horse-diseases; Viral-diseases; Zoonoses-
OD: Equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Togaviridae-; horses-
GE: Argentina-
BT: Alphavirus; Togaviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Equus; Equidae;
  Perissodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; ungulates; South
  -America; America
CC: LL820; VV200; LL800

Record 950 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Japanese encephalitis virus immunoglobulin M antibodies in porcine sera=
.
AU: Burke-DS; Tingpalapong-M; Elwell-MR; Paul-PS; Deusen-RA-van; Van-Deusen=
-RA
AD: Academic Affairs Branch, Walter Reed Army Inst. Res., Washington DC 203=
07
  -5100, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1985, 46: 10, 2054-2057; 13 re=
f.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: A solid-phase enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was developed t=
o
  detect porcine IgM antibodies to Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). Antib=
odies
  were captured on the solid phase of microtitre plates sensitized with mou=
se
  monoclonal antibodies to porcine mu heavy chain. Virus antigen binding to=
 the
  lawn of IgM was quantitated by subsequent binding of peroxidase-labelled =
human
  hyperimmune anti-JEV IgG which, in the final step, catalysed a substrate =
colour
  change. In sucrose density-gradient fractionated serum from recently infe=
cted
  pigs, the peak of ELISA JEV IgM activity corresponded to the peak of 18-S=
, 2
  -mercaptoethanol-sensitive haemagglutination-inhibiting (HAI) antibody
  activity. Within 2-3 days, JEV-infected sentinel pigs developed high JEV =
IgM
  activity; this activity decreased within 2 weeks. Among specimens collect=
ed at
  random from 99 swine at abattoirs in Thailand during a period of low JEV
  transmission, none of 25 JEV HAI-negative sera had JEV IgM activity, 7 of=
 74
  JEV HAI-positive sera had JEV IgM activity, and the remaining 67 sera had
  readily detectable JEV HAI antibodies, but lacked JEV IgM. The JEV IgM so=
lid
  -phase ELISA was useful for rapidly diagnosing active or recent JEV infec=
tions
  in swine.
DE: Epidemiological-surveys; Diagnosis-; ELISA-; detection-; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-; Japanese-encephalitis-virus
GE: Thailand-
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; Flavivirus; Flaviviridae; viruses; arbovi=
ruses;
  South-East-Asia; Asia
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article

Record 951 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Arbovirus investigations in Argentina, 1977-1980. IV. Serologic surveys=
 and
  sentinel equine program.
AU: Monath-TP; Sabattini-MS; Pauli-R; Daffner-JF; Mitchell-CJ; Bowen-GS; Cr=
opp-CB
AD: Division of Vector-Borne Viral Diseases, US Department of Health & Huma=
n
  Services, PO Box 2087, Fort Collins, Colorado 80522, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1985, 34: 5, 966-975=
; 2
  fig.; 20 ref.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: Serological surveys of wild and domestic birds, wild mammals and horses=
 were
  conducted during arbovirus field studies in Argentina in 1977-80, a non
  -epizootic interval. The presence of antibodies in short-lived bird speci=
es and
  in young unvaccinated horses and the demonstration of seroconversions in =
horses
  during the period, indicated that these viruses are either enzootic in, o=
r
  annually reintroduced into, Argentina. Antibodies to AG80-646, a new subt=
ype of
  western equine encephalitis (WEE) virus isolated in the subtropical north
  (Chaco Province) from species of Culex, were found in horses and rodents =
in
  that region. The demonstration of seroconversions in sentinel horses and =
of
  antibodies in birds and wild mammals indicates active transmission of
  Venezuelan equine encephalitis (VEE) virus. In 1980, a new enzootic subty=
pe of
  VEE virus (AG80-663) was isolated from mosquitoes in Chaco; neutralizing
  antibodies to this virus were prevalent in horses and rodents in this are=
a.
  Infections with Aura and Una viruses were most common in the subtropical
  northern provinces. Infection with St. Louis encephalitis (SLE) virus was
  prevalent and widespread, and birds, principally passerine and columbifor=
m
  species, appear to be the principal hosts. An interesting and unexplained
  finding was the absence of arbovirus antibodies, in particular SLE antibo=
dies
  in house sparrows (Passer domesticus). Antibodies to 2 new virues, Barran=
queras
  and Resistencia, which had been isolated from Culex spp. in Chaco Provinc=
e,
  were found in rodents there. Immunity to Gamboa group viruses was prevale=
nt,
  and birds were implicated as principal hosts.
DE: vectors-; disease-vectors; mosquito-nets
OD: Diptera-; Culex-; arboviruses-; Culicidae-; Western-equine-encephalitis
  -virus; Barranqueras-virus; Venezuelan-equine-encephalitis-virus
GE: Argentina-
ID: Resistencia-virus
BT: insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; Culicidae; Diptera; viruse=
s;
  equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Alphavirus; arboviruses; Togaviridae;
  Bunyavirus; Bunyaviridae; South-America; America
CC: TT300; HH700
CD: Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Other-Control
  -Measures
PT: Journal-article

Record 952 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Native fly dispersal in the field evaluation of a prospective factory s=
train
  of the screwworm, Cochliomyia hominivorax (Coquerel) (Diptera: Calliphori=
dae).
AU: McInnis-DO; Mackley-JW; Peterson-RD II
AD: Screwworm Research Laboratory, ARS, USDA, Southern Plains Area, Apartad=
o
  Postal 544, Tuxtla-Gutierrez, Chiapas, Mexico.
SO: Environmental-Entomology. 1985, 14: 2, 101-105; 2 fig.; 11 ref.
PY: 1985
LA: English
AB: Sterile flies from a prospective mass-production strain of Cochliomyia
  hominivorax were tested in the field on 2 occasions between August and No=
vember
  1981 in the Pacific coastal plain of Chiapas, Mexico. In Test I, flies we=
re
  released over a 30 X 120-km area where all 9 sentinel sheep sampling site=
s were
  located 5-23 km (including 5 sites at <10 km) from the nearest perimeter.=
 The
  maximum egg-mass sterility rate (25%) was obtained by the 3rd of 6 weeks =
of
  sterile fly releases. In Test II, flies were released over a 40 X 80-km a=
rea
  where all 8 sentinel sheep pens were located 18.5-34.5 km from the neares=
t
  perimeter. For all pens, the maximum egg-mass sterility rate (38%) was ob=
tained
  by the 4th week. Egg-mass sterility rates at sites considered well-insula=
ted
  from the perimeter were statistically higher than sterility rates at site=
s
  considered poorly insulated. In Test II, distance from the sentinel sheep
  sampling sites to the nearest perimeter of the fly release area and egg-m=
ass
  sterility rate were positively correlated, and a maximum sterility rate o=
f 60%
  was recorded. This relationship was attributed, at least in part, to the
  movement of native females of C. hominivorax into the test area from untr=
eated
  areas.
DE: control-; sterile-insect-release
OD: Cochliomyia-hominivorax; Diptera-
GE: Mexico-
BT: Cochliomyia; Calliphoridae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates=
;
  animals; North-America; America

Record 953 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Effects of chilling and photoperiod on forcing Astilbe.=20
AU: Beattie-DJ; Holcomb-EJ
AD: Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA.
SO: HortScience. 1983, 18: 4, 449-450; 5 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Astilbe X arendsii cvs Avalanche, Deutschland, Fanal and Red Sentinel w=
ere
  chilled for 0, 3, 6, 9 or 12 weeks at 5=B0C. Maximum number, height and f=
resh
  weight of inflorescence occurred when the plants were chilled for 12 week=
s. No
  flowering occurred when Avalanche or Deutschland were chilled for less th=
an 9
  weeks or when Fanal and Red Sentinel were chilled for less than 6 weeks. =
Fanal
  and Red Sentinel grew significantly taller when forced under a 14-h than =
under
  a 9-h photoperiod.

Record 954 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: A dual infection of a bull with Akabane and Aino viruses.
AU: Cybinski-DH; Zakrzewski-H
AD: CSIRO Division of Tropical Animal Science, Long Pocket Laboratories, PM=
B No.
  3, Indooroopilly, Queensland 4068, Australia.
SO: Australian-Veterinary-Journal. 1983, 60: 9, 283; 5 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: From observations on cattle in Queensland in December 1979, the 1st
  isolation of Aino virus from a vertebrate is reported. Both Aino and Akab=
ane
  viruses were isolated from a blood sample taken from a bull. That there w=
as
  active dissemination of both viruses was shown by the fact that 3 isolati=
ons of
  Akabane virus were made from the blood of sentinel cattle and 2 from Culi=
coides
  brevitarsis Kieff., while 14 isolations of Aino virus were made from C.
  brevitarsis collected in the previous 6 weeks. Evidence is presented that=
 the
  agent CSIRO 296 is a mixture of both viruses.
DE: distribution-; vectors-; hosts-; disease-vectors
OD: Culicoides-brevitarsis; viruses-; Akabane-virus; cattle-; Ceratopogonid=
ae-;
  Diptera-

end
  of April with chlorpyrifos at the rate of 0.48 kg/hectare had a greatly r=
educed
  I. ricinus population, as indicated by sentinel sheep, for at least two s=
easons.

Record 957 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Bovine ephemeral fever in North Queensland 1974-1977.
AU: St-George-TD; Standfast-HA
AD: CSIRO Div. Trop. Anim. Sci., Private Bag 3, Indooroopilly, Queensland 4=
068,
  Australia.
SO: 1983, 45pp.; Bulletin Series QB83001; 43 ref.
PB: Department of Primary Industries; Brisbane, Queensland; Australia
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: This paper describes an ingenious and unusual investigation. Designed t=
o
  test the hypothesis that bovine ephemeral fever (BEF) overwinters in the
  Flinders River area, the veterinary service combined with the microbiolog=
ical
  service of CSIRO in planning and execution, and medical research workers =
joined
  the team to investigate Murray Valley encephalitis. Difficulties encounte=
red
  were formidable: as an example, aircraft were sometimes the only way to r=
each
  farms during the monsoon season and, having reached the farm, the operato=
r had
  to leave soon enough to ensure his safe return, thus allowing little time=
 in
  which to do all the work. That such difficulties were surmounted speaks w=
ell
  for the staff. Results of the survey provided circumstantial evidence tha=
t BEF
  does overwinter in the area, but in which animal is unknown. Since the ag=
ent is
  probably an arbovirus, the reservoir may be insect, mammal or bird. Senti=
nel
  cattle, sheep, horses and fowls were kept in various herds and tested eac=
h
  month. Cattle developed antibodies to bovine ephemeral fever, Akabane, Ai=
no,
  Bunyip Ross River viruses. Horses developed antibodies to Ross River and
  Akabane viruses. Fowls developed antibodies to Murray Valley encephalitis=
,
  Kunjin and Sindbis viruses. No antibodies were detected in sheep.
DE: Viral-diseases; Disease-prevalence; Epidemiological-surveys; cattle-dis=
eases
OD: Flavivirus-; Alphavirus-; Bunyaviridae-; Bovine-ephemeral-fever-virus;
  cattle-
GE: Australia-
BT: arboviruses; viruses; Flaviviridae; Togaviridae; Vesiculovirus;
  Rhabdoviridae; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals;
  vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Australasia; Oceania
CC: LL820; LL800
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Animal
  -Health-and-Hygiene-General
PT: Miscellaneous
AV: free
UD: 950314
AN: 842232440

Record 958 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: The isolation of five different viruses of the epizootic haemorrhagic
  disease of deer serogroup.
AU: St-George-TD; Cybinski-DH; Standfast-HA; Gard-GP; Della-Porta-AJ
AD: CSIRO Div. Trop. Anim. Sci., Long Pocket Lab., Private Bag No. 3, PO,
  Indooroopilly, Queensland 4068, Australia.
SO: Australian-Veterinary-Journal. 1983, 60: 7, 216-217; 10 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Sentinel cattle in the Northern Territory and Queensland were bled on a
  weekly basis between January and May of each year from 1979 to 1982. Thir=
ty
  -five isolations of viruses which gave a slight reaction in an
  immunofluorescence test with an antiserum prepared against bluetongue vir=
us
  serotype 20 were made. Five isolates were shown to be distinct viruses wi=
th
  group relationships among themselves and with Ibaraki virus, indicating
  membership of the epizootic haemorrhagic disease of deer serogroup. Two
  isolates produced viraemias but no clinical signs on inoculation into cat=
tle;
  all five serotypes produced viraemias of 3-12 days' duration in sheep but=
 only
  three caused illness: fever, malaise and hyperaemia of skin and mucous
  membranes for 1-3 days followed by complete recovery. One isolate was
  indistinguishable from Ibaraki virus but four require more comprehensive
  classification and identification in a world reference laboratory.
DE: Viral-diseases; cattle-diseases
OD: Cattle-; Orbivirus-
GE: Australia-
ID: epizootic-haemorrhagic-disease-of-deer
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Reoviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Australasia; Oceania
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0005-0423
UD: 950314
AN: 842234729

Record 959 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: A project to determine the feasibility of utilizing cull breeding boars=
 as
  sentinel animals for swine brucellosis surveillance.
AU: Frye-GH; Pickerill-P; Rhodes-IT
SO: Proceedings-of-the-United-States-Animal-Health-Association. 1982, 86: 1=
78
  -180.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: The herd boar should be the animal with the greatest probability of rea=
cting
  to tests for brucellosis, as mating is one of the principal means of
  transmission. However, no body of data exists to support a conclusion tha=
t
  breeding boars would be good sentinel animals. In 1981, APHIS accepted a
  recommendation of the U.S. Animal Health Association that field trials sh=
ould
  be carried out. Data on the health status of boars in infected herds were
  accumulated from questionnaires completed on each herd found infected in =
the
  USA for the duration of the trial. Another trial was carried out on the
  traceability of boars to their herds of origin under current marketing me=
thods.
  Sufficient data on which to draw conclusions were expected to be availabl=
e in
  1983.
DE: brucellosis-; DISEASE-SURVEYS; boars-; bacterial-diseases; swine-diseas=
es
OD: pigs-; Brucella-suis; Brucella-
GE: USA-
ID: Health-control; health-status
BT: pigs; Sus-scrofa; Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mamm=
als;
  vertebrates; Chordata; animals; male-animals; Brucella; Brucellaceae;
  Gracilicutes; bacteria; prokaryotes; North-America; America
CC: LL820; LL860
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Animal
  -Disorders-Not-caused-by-Organisms
PT: Journal-article
UD: 950314
AN: 842236350

Record 960 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Eastern equine encephalomyelitis virus activity in South Carolina.
AU: Tidwell-MA; Forsythe-DM; Tidwell-MA; Parker-RL; Main-AJ
AD: Vector Biology Research Program, Department of Biology, The Citadel,
  Charleston, South Carolina 29409, USA.
SO: Journal-of-Agricultural-Entomology. 1984, 1: 1, 43-52; 2 fig.; 21 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: A review of South Carolina state records maintained since 1969 revealed=
 1
  case of eastern equine encephalitis in man, 4 cases in birds and 198 conf=
irmed
  cases in horses. A positive correlation was observed between the number o=
f
  cases and the mean annual rainfall. The highest incidence of reported cas=
es was
  in the Sandhill and Coastal Plain regions of the state. During 1981,
  haemagglutination-inhibition antibody titres of the virus of 1:20 or grea=
ter
  were detected in 4 of 39 sentinel chickens kept at a study site in Charle=
ston
  County. In 1981-82, 28 species of mosquitoes including 10 potential vecto=
rs of
  the virus (notably Culiseta melanura (Coq.)) were collected in the area u=
sing
  light and Malaise traps, but the virus was not detected in 40 pools of
  mosquitoes including the potential vectors. Seasonal distribution data ar=
e
  presented for the mosquitoes.
DE: hosts-; seasonal-fluctuations; distribution-; mosquito-nets
OD: Eastern-equine-encephalitis-virus; man-; birds-; horses-; fowls-; Culis=
eta
  -melanura; Culicidae-; Diptera-
GE: South-Carolina; USA-
BT: equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Alphavirus; Togaviridae; viruses;
  arboviruses; Homo; Hominidae; Primates; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Equus; Equidae; Perissodactyla; ungulates; Gallus-gallus; Gallus=
;
  Phasianidae; Galliformes; birds; Culiseta; Culicidae; Diptera; insects;
  arthropods; invertebrates; South-Atlantic-States-of-USA; Southern-States-=
of
  -USA; USA; North-America; America; Southeastern-States-of-USA
CC: VV200; LL820; TT300; HH700
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Parasite=
s,
  -Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Medical-and-Veterin=
ary
  -Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Other-Control-Measures
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0735-939X

Record 961 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Transmission dynamics of miracidia of Schistosoma haematobium in the Vo=
lta
  Lake.
AU: Chu-KY; Vanderburg-JA; Klumpp-RK
AD: WHO Schistosomiasis Res. Project, P.O. Box M190, Accra, Ghana.
SO: Bulletin-of-the-World-Health-Organization. 1981, 59: 4, 555-560; 13 ref=
.
PY: 1981
LA: English
LS: French
AB: S. haematobium miracidia were detected in sentinel snails (Bulinus rohl=
fsi)
  placed in 16 human water contact sites in the Volta Lake, each month from=
 March
  1973 to November 1977. The results showed that rates of infection were se=
asonal
  and that infected snails were more often found in water contact sites she=
ltered
  by emergent plant growth than in exposed open beach sites with no emergen=
t
  vegetation. Sentinel snail infection rates were correlated with natural s=
nail
  infection rates and with epidemiological levels of schistosomiasis in vil=
lage
  inhabitants. After 2 years of chemotherapy and molusciciding, levels of d=
isease
  and sentinel snail infection rates dropped in two-thirds of the villages.=
 In
  the remaining villages, however, the sentinel snail infection rates were =
not
  correlated with the fall in epidemiological level, because of ecological
  changes in the water contact sites. It is concluded that unless control
  measures are continued, the constant changes in the lake shore environmen=
t will
  lead to a rapid re-establishment of previous levels of disease transmissi=
on.
DE: miracidia-; control-; Epidemiology-; parasites-; helminths-
OD: Digenea-; Trematoda-; Mollusca-; Schistosoma-haematobium; Bulinus-rohlf=
si;
  man-
GE: Ghana-; Africa-
ID: transmission-dynamics
BT: digenean-larvae; helminth-larvae; larvae; animals; Digenea; Trematoda;
  Platyhelminthes; invertebrates; helminths; Schistosoma; Schistosomatidae;
  Bulinus; Bulinidae; Gastropoda; Mollusca; Homo; Hominidae; Primates; mamm=
als;
  vertebrates; Chordata; West-Africa; Africa-South-of-Sahara; Africa
CC: VV200; TT100; HH000
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Medical-=
and
  -Veterinary-Helminthology-Records-Discontinued; Pathogen,-Pest-and-Parasi=
te
  -Management-General
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0042-9686
UD: 950314

Record 962 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Microbiological safety and quality of foods in international trade - th=
e
  role of Codex, ISO, IDF and AOAC.
AU: Olson-JC Jr.; Kurata-H (ed.); Hesseltine-CW (ed.)
AD: 4982 Sentinel Drive, Bethesda, Md. 20816, USA.
SO: Control-of-the-microbial-contamination-of-foods-and-feeds-in-internatio=
nal
  -trade:-microbial-standards-and-specifications. 1982, 51-57; 14 ref.
PB: Saikon Publishing Co., Ltd.; Tokyo; Japan
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: The respective roles of the Joint FAO/WHO Codex Alimentarius Commission=
, the
  International Standards Organization (ISO), the International Dairy Feder=
ation
  (IDF) and the Association of Official Analytical Chemists (AOAC) in ensur=
ing
  the microbiological safety and quality of foods in international trade ar=
e
  discussed.

  -Dairy-Federation; biodeterioration-

Record 963 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Isolation of bluetongue virus serotype 2 from cattle in Florida: seroty=
pe of
  bluetongue virus hitherto unrecognized in the Western Hemisphere.
AU: Gibbs-EPJ; Greiner-EC; Taylor-WP; Barber-TL; House-JA; Pearson-JE
AD: Center Trop. Anim. Hlth, Coll. Vet. Med., Univ., Gainesville, Florida 3=
2610,
  USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1983, 44: 12, 2226-2228; 11 re=
f.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: In 1982 a serotype of bluetongue virus (BTV) previously unrecognized in=
 the
  Western Hemisphere was isolated from cattle in the USA. Clinical disease =
was
  not seen in the cattle which were part of a sentinel herd system in Flori=
da
  designed for studying the epidemiology of BTV. The isolation of serotype =
2 was
  the first recovery of a different serotype of BTV in the USA since 1967. =
At
  least 21 serotypes of BTV have been reported worldwide; the 5 serotypes o=
f BTV
  now recognized in the USA are 2, 10, 11, 13, and 17.
DE: DISEASE-SURVEYS; Viral-diseases; cattle-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: cattle-; Bluetongue-virus; sheep-
GE: USA-
ID: serotype-2
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Orbivirus; Reoviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Ovis; Nor=
th
  -America; America
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article

UD: 950314

Record 964 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Surveillance for respiratory disease in Louisiana beef herds.
AU: Hugh-Jones-ME
AD: Sch. Vet. Med., State Univ., Baton Rouge, Louisiana 70803, USA.
SO: Third International Symposium on Veterinary Epidemiology and Economics,
  Arlington, Virginia, USA, 6-10 September 1982. 1983, 604-611; 1 ref.
PB: Veterinary Medicine Publishing Co.; Edwardsville, Kansas; USA
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: A surveillance scheme in which beef farmers (about 40) throughout the s=
tate,
  sent in weekly forms indicating the numbers of animals bought, sold, kill=
ed,
  lost or stolen, born, died, immunized, or wormed, was set up. The early r=
eturns
  indicated brood cow mortality of 3% and nursing calf mortality of 10%;
  immunization and deworming appeared to be carried out at any time and sal=
es of
  animals preceded purchases by two weeks. In a number of the herds, design=
ated
  sentinel herds, groups of 15 cows and calves were examined regularly by
  veterinarians to determine the presence and distribution of pathogens. Th=
e
  objectives of this part of the programme were to provide accurate records=
 on
  prevalence of pathogens, particularly respiratory pathogens, to determine=
 the
  movement of infection within herds and between dams and their calves, to =
obtain
  complete case studies of normal herds and to develop the base-line data
  necessary for planning appropriate herd health programmes for beef herds =
in
  Louisiana. Preliminary data show Bacillus sp. and staphylococci were most
  frequently isolated from young (pre-weaning) calves and Pasteurella and
  Moraxella were more frequently isolated from weaned calves. Apart from Ba=
cillus
  there was no clear pattern of spread of pathogens from dam to calf. Altho=
ugh
  farmers claimed that parasites were a major problem in the sentinel herds=
, they
  were adequately controlled.
DE: DISEASE-SURVEYS; Beef-cattle; Pneumonia-; cattle-diseases; respiratory
  -diseases
OD: cattle-
GE: USA-
BT: cattle; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals;
  vertebrates; Chordata; animals; North-America; America
CC: LL860
CD: Animal-Disorders-Not-caused-by-Organisms
PT: Miscellaneous
IB: 0-935079-25-8
UD: 950314
AN: 842239124

Record 965 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Studies towards the management of arboviral epidemics. I. Operational
  aspects and insecticide susceptibility during 1982.
AU: Grant-CD; Combs-JC; Coykendall-RL; Lusk-EE; Washino-RK; Yoshimura-G; Re=
isen
  -WK; Milby-MM; Reeves-WC; Grant-CD (ed.); Combs-JC (ed.); Coykendall-RL (=
ed.);
  Lusk-EE (ed.); Washino-RK (ed.)
AD: Kern Mosquito Abatement District, PO Box 9428, Bakersfield, California
  93389, USA.
SO: Proceedings and Papers of the Fifty-first Annual Conference of the
  California Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc., January 23-26, =
1983,
  held at the Villa Hotel, San Mateo, California.  1983, 1-3; 10 ref.
PB: California Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc.; Sacramento,
  California; USA
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: The relative ineffectiveness of larval chemical control of mosquito vec=
tors
  of arboviruses in California led to tests of aerial sprays with chlorpyri=
fos,
  bendiocarb and resmethrin against the adults of Culex tarsalis Coq. at Po=
so
  West (in the Sierra Nevada foothills) and John Dale (in the San Joaquin
  Valley). At Poso West, no significant difference in mortality (over 90%) =
was
  observed between sentinel adults of the local target population and of th=
e
  laboratory strain Br80 treated with chlorpyrifos at 59 g toxicant/ha. At =
John
  Dale, mortality caused by all 3 insecticides declined considerably from t=
he
  first test to the last, especially in the local population. Susceptibilit=
y
  varied in the 2 areas. The ineffectiveness of the treatments appeared at =
least
  partly due to their early timing, which since the aircraft was not equipp=
ed for
  night flying took place before sunset and therefore before adult flight b=
egan
  at dusk.
DE: distribution-; control-; insecticides-; timing-; Chlorpyrifos-; Bendioc=
arb-;
  Resmethrin-; chemical-control; insect-control; mosquito-nets
OD: Culex-tarsalis; Culicidae-; Diptera-
GE: USA-; California-
RN: 2921-88-2; 22781-23-3; 10453-86-8
BT: pesticides; organothiophosphate-insecticides; organophosphorus-insectic=
ides;
  insecticides; carbamate-insecticides; carbamate-pesticides; pyrethroid
  -insecticides; Culex; Culicidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebra=
tes;
  animals; North-America; America; Pacific-States-of-USA; Western-States-of=
-USA;
  USA
CC: TT300; HH000; HH400; HH700
CD: Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Pathogen,-Pest-=
and
  -Parasite-Management-General; Control-by-Chemicals-and-Drugs; Other-Contr=
ol
  -Measures
PT: Miscellaneous
UD: 950314
AN: 840512297

Record 966 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Surveillance for arthropod-borne viral activity and disease in Californ=
ia
  during 1982.
AU: Grant-CD; Combs-JC; Coykendall-RL; Lusk-EE; Washino-RK; Emmons-RW; Milb=
y-MM;
  Gillies-PA; Reeves-WC; Bayer-EV; White-K; Woodie-JD; Grant-CD (ed.); Comb=
s-JC
  (ed.); Coykendall-RL (ed.); Lusk-EE (ed.); Washino-RK (ed.)
AD: Viral and Rickettsial Disease Laboratory Section, California Department=
 of
  Health Services, Berkeley, CA 94704, USA.
SO: Proceedings and Papers of the Fifty-first Annual Conference of the
  California Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc., January 23-26, =
1983,
  held at the Villa Hotel, San Mateo, California.  1983, 6-17.
PB: California Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc.; Sacramento,
  California; USA
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Surveys in California for arthropod-borne and especially mosquito-borne
  viruses were continued in 1982 [see RAE/B 71, 2224, etc.] by means both o=
f
  serological tests of human and equine cases of suspected encephalitis and=
 of
  tests of mosquito pools for viruses. One human and 4 equine cases of west=
ern
  equine encephalitis (WEE) were confirmed during the year. A total of 2592=
 pools
  of mosquitoes was collected, of which 98% consisted of Aedes melanimon Dy=
ar,
  Culex tarsalis Coq. and species of the complex of C. pipiens L.; 227 isol=
ations
  were made of WEE, 109 of Hart Park virus, 125 of Turlock virus and 16 of
  viruses of the California encephalitis group. Sentinel flocks of chickens=
 were
  exposed in 25 localities, and 11 developed antibodies to WEE. St. Louis
  encephalitis virus was not found in the mosquitoes, and the seroconversio=
n rate
  to this virus in sentinel chickens was very low.
DE: distribution-; vectors-; hosts-; disease-vectors; mosquito-nets
OD: Culex-tarsalis; Aedes-melanimon; viruses-; arboviruses-; Western-equine
  -encephalitis-virus; Culicidae-; Hart-Park-virus; Turlock-virus; man-; ho=
rses-;
  fowls-; St-Louis-encephalitis-virus; Diptera-
GE: USA-; California-
ID: Culex-pipiens-complex; California-encephalitis-virus-group
BT: Culex; Culicidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals;
  Aedes; viruses; equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Alphavirus; arboviruses;
  Togaviridae; Vesiculovirus; Rhabdoviridae; unclassified-viruses; Homo;
  Hominidae; Primates; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; Equus; Equidae;
  Perissodactyla; ungulates; Gallus-gallus; Gallus; Phasianidae; Galliforme=

Record 967 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Field evaluation of Bacillus thuringiensis var. israelensis, Lagenidium
  giganteum, and Romanomermis culicivorax in California rice fields.
AU: Grant-CD; Combs-JC; Coykendall-RL; Lusk-EE; Kerwin-JL; Washino-RK; Gran=
t-CD
  (ed.); Combs-JC (ed.); Coykendall-RL (ed.); Lusk-EE (ed.); Washino-RK (ed=
.)
AD: Department of Entomology, California University, Davis, CA 95616, USA.
SO: Proceedings and Papers of the Fifty-first Annual Conference of the
  California Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc., January 23-26, =
1983,
  held at the Villa Hotel, San Mateo, California.  1983, 19-25; 2 fig.; 3 r=
ef.
PB: California Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc.; Sacramento,
  California; USA
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: In rice fields in the Central Valley of California, the bacterium Bacil=
lus
  thuringiensis subsp. israelensis, the mermithid Romanomermis culicivorax =
and
  the fungus Lagenidium giganteum were compared as biological control agent=
s
  against Anopheles freeborni Aitken and Culex tarsalis Coq., of which sent=
inel
  larvae were introduced into rice fields and associated seepage ditches.
  Application of B. t. israelensis by aircraft, mist-blower or aerosol gene=
rator
  gave similar control of both mosquito species, but the effectiveness of t=
he
  ground sprays depended on the distance of the larvae from the point of
  application. R. culicivorax gave up to 46% larval infection, and its incr=
eased
  numbers 3-4 weeks after introduction indicated that a single application =
of
  postparasites partially controlled mosquito larvae for the entire rice-gr=
owing
  season. The asexual stage of L. giganteum introduced into seepage ditches=
 was
  able to control Culex populations in rice fields, and continued to multip=
ly
  even at very low larval densities. However, the short duration of this st=
age
  limits its use to small mosquito breeding areas.
DE: distribution-; control-; microbial-pesticides; habitats-; fields-;
  biological-control; insect-control; mosquito-nets; rice-; pathogens-;
  biological-control-agents
OD: Bacillus-thuringiensis; Nematoda-; Romanomermis-culicivorax; fungi-;

Record 968 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Overview of a longitudinal field study of bluetongue virus infection in
  resident populations of Culicoides variipennis and a multispecies sentine=
l herd.
AU: Compans-RW; Bishop-DHL; Stott-JL; Bushnell-RB; Loomis-EC; Jessup-D; O'
  -Rourke-M; Oliver-MN; Osburn-BI; Walton-TE; Compans-RW (ed.); Bishop-DHL =
(ed.)
AD: School of Veterinary Medicine, California University, Davis, USA.
SO: Double-stranded RNA viruses. Proceedings of the First International
  Symposium on Double-Stranded RNA Viruses, held October 5-10, 1982, at
  Frenchman's Reef, St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands.  1983, 367-374; 1 fig.=
; 16
  ref.
PB: Elsevier Biomedical; New York; USA
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: In a longitudinal study of bluetongue virus (BTV) and related viruses i=
n an
  area of California known to be endemic for BTV and epizootic haemorrhagic
  disease virus (EHDV), the order of decreasing susceptibility of different
  sentinel animals to BTV (as determined by virus isolation) was dairy calv=
es,
  sheep, deer, goats and beef cows. However, using seroconversion, the bovi=
ne and
  ovine species appeared to be equally susceptible to infection, followed b=
y
  goats and deer. The study confirmed earlier reports of herds, as well as
  individual animals, becoming infected with multiple serotypes of BTV. The
  predominant serotype isolated from all species, including pools of Culico=
ides
  variipennis (Coq.), was BTV-11. The single isolation of BTV-13 from C.
  variipennis late in the autumn was probably due to its late introduction =
into
  the area. No overwintering mechanism for BTV was identified. The possible=
 part
  played by vectors in the initial source of BTV in the area is discussed.
  Serological tests demonstrated that 6 of 8 dairy calves tested had been
  infected with EHDV.
DE: distribution-; vectors-; hosts-; Disease-transmission; Carrier-state;
  disease-vectors
OD: Culicoides-variipennis; viruses-; bluetongue-virus; cattle-; deer-; goa=
ts-;
  sheep-; Cervidae-; Odocoileus-; Culicoides-; Ceratopogonidae-; Diptera-
GE: USA-; California-
BT: Culicoides; Ceratopogonidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrate=
s;
  animals; Orbivirus; Reoviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Bos; Bovidae; rumin=
ants;
  Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; Cervidae; Capra;=
 Ovis;
  North-America; America; Pacific-States-of-USA; Western-States-of-USA; USA
CC: LL820; TT300
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Medical=
-and
  -Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued
PT: Miscellaneous

Record 969 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Bluetongue infections and Culicoides species associated with livestock =
in
  Florida and the Caribbean Region.
AU: Compans-RW; Bishop-DHL; Gibbs-EPJ; Greiner-EC; Compans-RW (ed.); Bishop=
-DHL
  (ed.)
AD: Department of Preventive Medicine, College of Veterinary Medicine, Flor=
ida
  University, Gainesville, FL 32610, USA.
SO: Double-stranded RNA viruses. Proceedings of the First International
  Symposium on Double-Stranded RNA Viruses, held October 5-10, 1982, at
  Frenchman's Reef, St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands.  1983, 375-382; 22 ref=
.
PB: Elsevier Biomedical; New York; USA
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Research in progress in Florida since 1979 and the Caribbean Region sin=
ce
  1981 on bluetongue virus in cattle, sheep and goats is described. Twenty-=
two
  species of Culicoides that were taken in light traps located near ruminan=
t
  herds in Florida, Puerto Rico, St. Croix and Barbados are listed, with an
  indication of their distribution and relative abundance. There was an ove=
rall
  high prevalence of antibodies to the bluetongue virus group, suggesting a=
 high
  degree of endemicity, but studies with sentinel animals indicated that
  continuous transmission of the virus did not occur. There was an apparent=
 lack
  of clinical disease in resident stock and imported animals. Ceratopogonid=
s
  suspected of being vectors in the region are C. insignis Lutz, C. pusillu=
s Lutz
  and C. jamaicensis Edw.

Record 971 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Preliminary studies on the Culicoides spp. as potential vectors of
  bluetongue in the Caribbean region.
AU: Greiner-EC; Garris-GI; Rollo-RT; Knausenberger-WI; Jones-JE; Gibbs-EPJ
AD: Department of Preventive Medicine, College of Veterinary Medicine, Flor=
ida
  University, Gainesville, FL 32610, USA.
SO: Preventive-Veterinary-Medicine. 1984, 2: 389-399; 3 fig.; 10 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: Culicoides insignis Lutz and C. pusillus Lutz were the most abundant (a=
bout
  95 and 73% of the totals, respectively) of the 10 species of Culicoides t=
aken
  in light-traps operated near cattle on the islands of Puerto Rico, St. Cr=
oix
  and Barbados during a survey in the Caribbean for possible vectors of
  bluetongue virus; a recent serological survey on goats, sheep and cattle =
in the
  Caribbean had shown that infection with bluetongue virus was common there=
. Peak
  numbers of C. insignis and of C. pusillus were taken at the time that mos=
t
  sentinel calves seroconverted to bluetongue virus in Puerto Rico. The evi=
dence
  therefore strongly suggests that these species are implicated in the
  transmission of the virus in the region.

Record 973 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Seasonal transmission of Fasciola hepatica to cattle in northwestern Un=
ited
  States.
AU: Hoover-RC; Lincoln-SD; Hall-RF; Wescott-R
AD: Vet. Teaching Center, Univ., Caldwell, Idaho 83605, USA.
SO: Journal-of-the-American-Veterinary-Medical-Association. 1984, 184: 6, 6=
95
  -698; 11 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: Sentinel steers were placed with 3 beef herds on irrigated pastures in
  southern Idaho for one month periods from May until November 1982 to dete=
rmine
  the transmission pattern of F. hepatica. Transmission increased during th=
e
  pasture season, reaching a peak in November. Overwintering of metacercari=
ae or
  snail-borne stages did not contribute to infections in the year under stu=
dy. A
  variety of species of Lymnaea were available in southern Idaho as potenti=
al
  intermediate hosts. The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay was a good
  serological indicator of light infections with F. hepatica. Serum gamma
  -glutamyltransferase activity was not diagnostically significant when the
  degree of fluke infection was low.

Record 974 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Forcing astilbe - how long to chill.
AU: Holcomb-EJ; Beattie-DJ
AD: Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA.
SO: Bulletin,-Pennsylvania-Flower-Growers. 1983, No. 348, 1-2; 2 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Potted astilbe plants (red cultivars Fanal and Red Sentinel and white
  cultivars Avalanche and Deutschland) were grown outdoors for the summer a=
nd
  brought into a 60=B0F greenhouse in early September. On 2 October the pla=
nts were
  moved to 40=B0 for 0, 3, 6, 9 or 12 weeks, after which they were moved ba=
ck to
  60=B0 and forced under short day or long day (4 h night break) conditions=
. White
  flowered cultivars flowered only when chilled for at least 9 weeks, with =
an
  increasing number of inflorescences with increased chilling time. The red
  cultivars required a minimum of 6 weeks, with inflorescence fresh weight =
and
  height increasing with chilling time. All cultivars produced more
  inflorescences when forced under long days, but this effect was only
  significant for Avalanche and Fanal.
DE: forcing-; cold-zones; treatment-; ornamental-plants; ornamental-herbace=
ous
  -plants
OD: Astilbe-
BT: plants; ornamental-plants; Spermatophyta; Saxifragaceae; Rosales;
  dicotyledons; angiosperms
CC: FF000
CD: Plants-of-Economic-Importance-General
PT: Journal-article
UD: 950314

Record 975 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Lipase activity in oats during grain maturation and germination.
AU: Urquhart-AA; Brumell-CA; Altosaar-I; Matlashewski-GJ; Sahasrabudhe-MR
AD: Dep. Biochem., Univ. Ottawa, Ottawa, K1N 9B4, Canada.
SO: Cereal-Chemistry. 1984, 61: 2, 105-108; 27 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: Lipase activity (glycerol tri[1-14C]oleate hydrolysis) was assayed in g=
rains
  of three cultivars, two to 44 days after anthesis. The first peak of lipa=
se
  activity occurred during the first nine days in all cultivars. A second p=
eak
  occurred at 23 days in Hinoat and 30 days in Sentinel and OA424-1. Peaks =
of
  activity coincided with maximum fresh and dry weights. Activity declined
  towards harvest maturity and was significantly lowest in OA424-1.

s-;
  oats-

Record 976 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: In vivo and in vitro reactivation of latent pseudorabies virus in pigs =
born
  to vaccinated sows.
AU: Oirschot-JT-van; Gielkens-ALJ; Van-Oirschot-JT
AD: Central Vet. Inst., Dep. Virol., Houtribweg 39, 8221 RA Lelystad,
  Netherlands.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1984, 45: 3, 567-571; 25 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: Latency of pseudorabies [Aujeszky's] virus (PRV) was established in 8 o=
f 9
  pigs born to 2 vaccinated sows. Pigs had high, low, or no maternal antibo=
dy
  titres at the time of the initial inoculation. At 3 to 4 months after
  inoculation, latent PRV could be reactivated in vivo by the administratio=
n of
  large doses of corticosteroids. In most pigs, the stress-simulating treat=
ment
  resulted in recrudescence of virus shedding after lag periods of 4 to 11 =
days.
  In 3 pigs, virus shedding was without clinical signs of disease, whereas
  clinical signs that developed in 4 pigs appeared to be due to the
  corticosteroid treatment, rather than to the reactivation of PRV. Pigs wi=
th a
  log10 neutralizing antibody titre of _ 2.55 at the onset of corticosteroi=
d
  treatment had a booster response. Reactivated PRV spread to sentinel pigs
  housed with the inoculated pigs. Reactivation of PRV was also demonstrate=
d in
  vitro. Explant cultures of trigeminal ganglia from pigs killed between 4 =
to 5
  months after inoculation produced infectious virus. Restriction endonucle=
ase
  analysis indicated that the reactivated PRV was indistinguishable from vi=
rus
  isolated shortly after the primary infection. Seemingly, pigs with matern=
al
  antibodies can become latently infected and therefore may be regarded as
  potential sources of dissemination of PRV.
DE: Glucocorticoids-; Viral-diseases; Aujeszky's-disease; latent-infections=
;
  vaccination-; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-; Aujeszky-virus
ID: latency
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; porcine-herpesvirus; Herpesviridae; virus=
es
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0002-9645
UD: 950314
AN: 842243113

  http://sladmin.silverplatter.com:4416/lpascripts/holdlink.pl?lpa.holdlink=

  tp://orbexpress.library.yale.edu/cgi

Record 977 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: The isolation of a bluetongue virus from Culicoides brevitarsis.
AU: St-George-TD; Muller-MJ
AD: CSIRO Div. Trop. Anim. Sci., Long Pocket Lab., Private Bag No.3, PO,
  Indooroopilly, Queensland 4068, Australia.
SO: Australian-Veterinary-Journal. 1984, 61: 3, 95; 14 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: Bluetongue virus serotype 1 was isolated from C. brevitarsis collected =
near
  sentinel cattle in February 1983 at Peachester 100 km north of Brisbane. =
Six of
  the 12 sentinel cattle seroconverted to the virus. This culicoid species =
has
  now yielded 13 viruses associated with livestock in Australia.

  -diseases

TI: Isolation of influenza A virus and paramyxoviruses from sentinel domest=

  ducks.

  virus and one strain of paramyxovirus type 4 were isolated in Czechoslova=

  amniotic and allantoic cavities of chick embryos.

Record 979 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: African swine fever in the Dominican Republic.
AU: Rivera-EM
AD: Edificio Banco Agricola, Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic.
SO: African-swine-fever. 1983, 17-24; Report EUR 8466 EN.
PB: Commission of the European Communities; Luxembourg
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: African swine fever was diagnosed in the Dominican Republic in July 197=
8.
  There have been 374 outbreaks up to the end of 1980 and the last outbreak=
 was
  diagnosed in August 1980. The disease rapidly became widespread and the
  Government decided on the total eradication of the pig population to be c=
arried
  out in three phases: depopulation and decontamination, surveillance and
  sentinel groups. Over 190 000 pigs were slaughtered and $8.5 million paid=
 in
  compensation. At present a regional restocking programme is being carried=
 out.
DE: Disease-prevalence; Economics-; Disease-control; incidence-; control-; =
swine
  -diseases
OD: pigs-; African-swine-fever-virus; Swine-fever-virus
GE: Dominican-Republic
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; arboviruses; viruses; Iridoviridae; Pesti=
virus;
  Togaviridae; Greater-Antilles; Caribbean; America
CC: EE100; HH000; LL820
CD: Economics-General; Pathogen,-Pest-and-Parasite-Management-General;
  Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Miscellaneous
UD: 950314
AN: 842243814

Record 980 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Development in Cuba of a programme for the eradication of African swine
  fever in 1980.
AU: Negrin-RES
AD: Nat. Centre Anim. Hlth, Havana, Cuba.
SO: African-swine-fever. 1983, 36-41; Report EUR 8466 EN.
PB: Commission of the European Communities; Luxembourg
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: African swine fever (ASF) was detected for the first time in Cuba in Ja=
nuary
  1980. 56 outbreaks were reported in 3 eastern provinces. Diagnosis was ca=
rried
  out by direct immunofluorescence, the inoculation of bone marrow cultures=
 and
  biological tests. A state of emergency was declared in the eastern provin=
ces
  and a state of alert in the rest of the country. Slaughter of pigs in the=
 areas
  affected by the disease was carried out, as well as systematic disinfecti=
on of
  farms, properties and installations. Epidemiological vigilance permitted =
the
  examination of all the animals, their revaccination against classical swi=
ne
  fever and the submission of samples to special laboratories. Strict quara=
ntine
  was established. The programme of eradication included the introduction o=
f
  sentinel pigs into the outbreak sites to confirm the absence of the virus=
 and
  allow the gradual repopulation of the affected provinces. No further case=
s were
  observed after 2nd March.
DE: Disease-control; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-; African-swine-fever-virus; Swine-fever-virus
GE: Cuba-
ID: eradication
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; arboviruses; viruses; Iridoviridae; Pesti=
virus;
  Togaviridae; Greater-Antilles; Caribbean; America
CC: HH000; LL820
CD: Pathogen,-Pest-and-Parasite-Management-General; Parasites,-Vectors,
  -Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Miscellaneous
UD: 950314
AN: 842243855

Record 981 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: The use of ELISA in the diagnosis of African swine fever in the Dominic=
an
  Republic.
AU: Rodriguez-EMR; Rivera-Rodriguez-EM
AD: Comision para la Erradicacion de la Fiebre Porcina Africana, Banca
  Agricoltura, Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic.
SO: African-swine-fever. 1983, 292; Report EUR 8466 EN.
PB: Commission of the European Communities; Luxembourg
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Serum samples were collected from 10 901 pigs in 1979 and 1980 during t=
he
  depopulation phase of the African swine fever (ASF) eradication programme=
. The
  samples were tested by ELISA but only those which were also positive by
  indirect immunofluorescence (IF) were considered to contain ASF antibodie=
s.
  1211 (11.1%) samples were ELISA-positive and 59 (0.54%) were IF-positive.=
 In
  1980 and 1981, 276 (6.5%) of 4216 serum samples collected from sentinel p=
igs
  during the restocking programme were ELISA-positive but they were all IF
  negative.
DE: Laboratory-diagnosis; Immunofluorescence-; ELISA-; Diagnosis-; swine-di=
seases
OD: pigs-; African-swine-fever-virus; swine-fever-virus
GE: Dominican-Republic
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; arboviruses; viruses; Iridoviridae; Pesti=
virus;
  Togaviridae; Greater-Antilles; Caribbean; America
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Miscellaneous
UD: 950314
AN: 842243950

Record 982 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Persistence of Aujeszky's virus on fattening and breeding premises for =
pigs
  after an outbreak of the disease.
OT: Onderzoek naar de viruspersistentie op mestvarkensbedrijven en fokbedri=
jven
  na een uitbraak van de ziekte van Aujeszky.
AU: Maes-L; Pensaert-M
AD: Faculteit Diergeneeskunde, Casinoplein 24, B-9000 Gent, Belgium.
SO: Tijdschrift-voor-Diergeneeskunde. 1984, 109: 11, 439-445; 20 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: Dutch
LS: English
AB: On seven fattening premises in Belgium, the herpesvirus persisted
  temporarily (6-8 weeks) as newly-arrived piglets became infected. This cy=
cle of
  infection was interrupted about 3 months after the outbreak, resulting in=
 a
  gradual return to another fully-susceptible pig population. On seven bree=
ding
  farms, none of 12 sentinel piglets became serologically positive during 1=
6
  months after an outbreak, demonstrating that the virus failed to persist.=
 There
  was a greater probability of new outbreaks being due to re-introduction o=
f the
  virus rather than activation of latent infection.
DE: Viral-diseases; Aujeszky's-disease; epidemiology-; persistence-; infect=
ion-;
  swine-diseases
OD: pigs-; Aujeszky-virus
GE: Belgium-
ID: latency
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; porcine-herpesvirus; Herpesviridae; virus=
es;
  Western-Europe; Europe
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0040-7453
UD: 950314

Record 983 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Annual report 1982/1983.
CA: Indonesia, Research Institute for Animal Diseases.
SO: 1984?, iii + 43pp.; Director: P. Ronohardjo.
PB: PO Box 52; Bogor; Indonesia
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: This report covers the period April 1982-March 1983. Twelve current res=
earch
  projects (mainly epidemiological surveys of different diseases) are liste=
d, and
  aims and methods described. Preliminary results indicate that Trypanosoma
  evansi infection is present at all three locations sampled, but at low
  prevalence. Among animals slaughtered at Bogor, mouse inoculation yielded=
 T.
  evansi from two (0.8%) of 254 cattle and four (8%) of 50 buffaloes. T. th=
eileri
  was isolated from 33% of 128 cattle and 48% of 25 buffaloes. Fasciola hep=
atica
  was found in 17% of 161 cattle and 53% of 30 buffaloes at Bogor abattoir.=
 Of
  381 serum samples from slaughter cattle (mainly young males), 22.6% were
  positive for Leptospira, mainly L. hardjo and L. tarassovi, but all were
  negative for brucellosis. Among 524 dairy cattle (434 from East Java), 0.=
5%
  were positive reactors for brucellosis in East Java but none in Central a=
nd
  West Java. Of 1744 quarter milk samples from 31 dairy cattle farms in Eas=
t Java
  66.4% were positive to the Aulendorfer mastitis probe; pathogens isolated=
 were
  chiefly Staphylococcus aureus, S. epidermidis and streptococci. No isolat=
ion of
  Campylobacter fetus venerealis was made from 95 cows and 1000 bulls. A na=
tional
  sentinel herd scheme using cattle, buffaloes, sheep and goats has been se=
t up
  at seven locations throughout Java.
DE: Research-institutes; Animal-diseases; Tropical-diseases; poultry-; catt=
le
  -diseases; poultry-diseases
OD: cattle-; BUFFALOES-
GE: Indonesia-
BT: birds; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants;
  Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; Bubalus; South-East-Asia; Asia
CC: LL820; AA000; LL800
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Agricul=
ture
  -General; Animal-Health-and-Hygiene-General
PT: Annual-report
UD: 950314
AN: 842245333

Record 984 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Confirmation of pseudorabies [Aujeszky's] virus infection, using virus
  recrudescence by dexamethasone treatment and in vitro lymphocyte stimulat=
ion.
AU: Thawley-DG; Solorzano-RF; Johnson-ME
AD: Dep. Vet. Microbiol., Coll. Vet. Med., Univ., Columbia, Missouri 65211,=
 USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1984, 45: 5, 981-983; 10 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: After treatment with 160 mg of dexamethasone daily for 5 days, Aujeszky=
's
  virus was isolated from 2 of 3 adult littermate boars that carried antibo=
dies
  to the virus. These pigs also transferred infection to a SPF sentinel pen=
mate.
  After dexamethasone treatment, increased lymphocyte stimulation indices w=
ere
  detected in all virus seropositive pigs. Aujeszky's virus was not isolate=
d from
  a seronegative littermate gilt of the seropositive boars. The gilt also
  remained seronegative and negative for lymphocyte transformation. Before
  dexamethasone treatment, the 3 boars and 1 gilt were seronegative to the =
serum
  neutralization (SN) test at 11 weeks of age. At 13 weeks of age while sti=
ll SN
  negative, these pigs were moved to a building and randomly penned with 76=
 other
  SN-negative pigs. At 18 weeks of age, all pigs in the building were PR vi=
rus
  seronegative, but at 25 weeks of age, the 3 boars were seropositive and t=
he
  gilt was seronegative. There were no other pigs in the building that had
  antibodies to PR virus before the addition or after the removal of these =
pigs.
  Seemingly, the 3 boars were infected with Aujeszky's virus before 13 week=
s of
  age indicating that infection of swine may occur in the absence of detect=
able
  SN antibodies.
DE: Viral-diseases; Diagnostic-techniques; Aujeszky's-disease; latent
  -infections; detection-; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-; Aujeszky-virus
ID: latency
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; porcine-herpesvirus; Herpesviridae; virus=
es
CC: LL820; ZZ900
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Techniq=
ues
  -and-Methodology
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0002-9645
UD: 950314
AN: 842245416

Record 985 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: The use of sentinel birds for early warning of mosquito-borne encephali=
tis
  in Delaware in 1981 and 1982.
AU: New-Jersey-Mosquito-Control-Association; King-WM
AD: Delaware Mosquito Control Section, USA.
SO: Proceedings. Seventieth annual meeting. New Jersey Mosquito Control
  Association, Inc. Atlantic City, New Jersey, 16, 17, 18 March 1983. 1983?=
, 137
  -141.
PB: New Jersey Mosquito Control Association; New Jersey; USA

  -borne encephalitis viruses in the field (sampling natural mosquito

mals

Record 986 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Western equine encephalitis in Manitoba.
AU: Manitoba-Arbovirus-Surveillance-Committee; Sekla-L (ed.)
AD: Cadham Provincial Laboratory, Winnipeg, Manitoba R3C 3Y1, Canada.
SO: 1982, 296 pp.; many fig., 275 X 210 mm; many ref.
PB: Ministry of Health; Winnipeg, Manitoba; Canada
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Following an outbreak of western equine encephalitis (WEE) in Manitoba =
in
  1981, a WEE workshop was held in February 1982, at which technical papers=
 were
  presented by members of the Manitoba Arbovirus Surveillance Committee. A =
public
  hearing on mosquito control programmes in Manitoba was also held. The dat=
a
  presented at the two meetings are contained in this publication, which in=
cludes
  about 35 papers, together with recommendations for future surveillance an=
d
  control programmes. The papers are arranged as an introduction and furthe=
r
  chapters on mosquito data, equine data, sentinel chicken flocks data, vir=
ology,
  clinical and epidemiological data, vector control, the safety and evaluat=
ion of
  insecticides, and human protection. The relevant papers are noticed elsew=
here.

a;

Record 987 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Population dynamics of Culex tarsalis Coquillett in Manitoba.
AU: Sekla-L; Brust-RA; Sekla-L (ed.)
AD: Department of Entomology, Manitoba University, Winnipeg R3T 2N2, Canada=
.
SO: Western-equine-encephalitis-in-Manitoba. 1982, 21-30; 7 fig.; 7 ref.
PB: Ministry of Health; Winnipeg, Manitoba; Canada
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Sentinel chicken flock trap collections of mosquitoes in Manitoba in 19=
76-81
  indicated that the numbers and percentage (in comparison to other species=
) of
  Culex tarsalis Coq. were correlated with the 2 years (1977 and 1981) out =
of 6
  when human and equine outbreaks of western equine encephalitis (WEE) occu=
rred.
  The parameters more than 20 C. tarsalis females/trap per week in late Jun=
e or
  early July, and more than 25% C. tarsalis females in flock trap collectio=
ns in
  this period, are criteria which might be used in future to predict outbre=
ak
  population levels of C. tarsalis. Culiseta inornata (Will.) and Aedes vex=
ans
  (Mg.) are unlikely to be involved in the transmission of WEE virus to equ=
ines
  and humans in July or August, because females are infected at very low le=
vels,
  and their population peaks do not coincide with transmission peaks for WE=
E.
  They may be involved in amplifying the virus in spring.
DE: population-dynamics; distribution-; vectors-; hosts-; disease-vectors;
  mosquito-nets

Record 988 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Use of sentinel birds in evaluating effectiveness of aerial adulticidin=
g in
  Manitoba, 1977 and 1981.
AU: Sekla-L; Neufeld-JL; Wong-FC; Sekla-L (ed.)
AD: Veterinary Services Branch, Manitoba Department of Agriculture, Winnipe=
g R3T
  2N2, Canada.
SO: Western-equine-encephalitis-in-Manitoba. 1982, 98-101; 7 ref.
PB: Ministry of Health; Winnipeg, Manitoba; Canada
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: After the emergency vector control programmes of 1977 and 1981 in Manit=
oba
  against western equine encephalitis, sentinel chicken flocks were located=
 in
  sprayed and unsprayed areas in an attempt to assess the effectiveness of =
the
  application of insecticides against adult mosquitoes. Conclusive data wer=
e not
  obtained in 1977 because cool weather stopped vector [Culex tarsalis Coq.=
]
  activity. In 1981, equivocal results were obtained from 4 unsprayed and 1=
0
  sprayed sites, with minor indication that spraying was effective. Wide
  variations in results between sites were difficult to explain. However,
  sentinel flocks appeared to be an effective means of monitoring vector
  activity, even in late August.

Record 990 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Epizootiology, development and migration of Dirofilaria scapiceps (Nema=
toda:
  Filarioidea) of rabbits and hares. [Abstract].
AU: Bartlett-CM
AD: Department of Zoology, Guelph University, Ontario, Canada.
SO: Program and abstracts of American Society of Parasitologists Fifty-eigh=
th
  Annual Meeting, meeting in conjunction with the American Society of Tropi=
cal
  Medicine and Hygiene, San Antonio, Texas, 4-8, December 1983. 1984?, 56.
PB: American Society of Parasitologists; Lawrence, Kansas; USA
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: The incidence of Dirofilaria scapiceps in wild lagomorphs in various ar=
eas
  of North America was 62% in Lepus americanus, 27% in Sylvilagus floridanu=
s and
  4% in L. capensis. Transmission to sentinel rabbits in an enzootic area i=
n
  Ontario occurred in July and August. Development to the 3rd stage took pl=
ace in
  the abdominal fat-body of Aedes aegypti (L.), A. canadensis (Theo.), A. e=
uedes
  H., D. & K., A. excrucians (Wlk.), A. provocans (Wlk.), A. punctor (Kby.)=
, A.
  stimulans (Wlk.), A. fitchii (Felt & Young), A. vexans (Mg.) and Coquille=
ttidia
  perturbans (Wlk.). At 26=B0C, infective larvae were first found in the mo=
uthparts
  10 days after infection. In the most suitable intermediate hosts (A. eued=
es and
  A. excrucians), fat-body syncytia with hypertrophied adipocyte nuclei for=
med
  around larvae. Syncytia commonly did not form, or formed abnormally, arou=
nd
  larvae in less suitable hosts, such as A. aegypti, A. stimulans and A. fi=
tchii.
  D. scapiceps developed to the subadult stage in subcutaneous tissues in v=
arious
  regions of the body of experimentally infected rabbits (S. floridanus). T=
he 3rd
  and 4th moults occurred after 6 and 12 days, respectively. Subadults migr=
ated
  through subcutaneous tissues and arrived in the ankle as early as 16 days=
. The
  prepatent period was 137-240 days.
DE: hosts-; development-; vectors-; disease-vectors; mosquito-nets
OD: Nematoda-; Lepus-americanus; Sylvilagus-floridanus; Lepus-capensis;
  Coquillettidia-perturbans; Aedes-aegypti; Aedes-canadensis; Aedes-euedes;=
 Aedes
  -excrucians; Aedes-punctor; Aedes-stimulans; Aedes-fitchii; Aedes-vexans;=
 Aedes
  -; Culicidae-; Diptera-
GE: North-America; Canada-; Ontario-
ID: Dirofilaria-scapiceps; Aedes-provocans
BT: invertebrates; animals; Lepus; Leporidae; Lagomorpha; mammals; vertebra=
tes;
  Chordata; Sylvilagus; Coquillettidia; Culicidae; Diptera; insects; arthro=
pods;
  Aedes; America; North-America; Canada

Record 991 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Encephalitis surveillance in central Utah, 1983.
AU: Rosay-B; Collett-GC; Arnell-JH; Jackson-FC; Rosay-B (ed.); Collett-GC (=
ed.)
AD: Utah State Department of Health, Bureau of General Sanitation, Salt Lak=
e
  City, USA.
SO: Proceedings and papers of the Thirty-Sixth Annual Meeting of the Utah
  Mosquito Abatement Association held at Eccles Conference Center, Utah Sta=
te
  University, Logan, Utah, October 3-4, 1983.  1984, 7-13; 4 fig.
PB: Utah Mosquito Abatement Association; Salt Lake City, Utah; USA
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: A programme of surveillance for Culex tarsalis Coq., western equine
  encephalitis virus (WEE) and St. Louis encephalitis virus (SLE) was carri=
ed out
  in July-August 1983 in the Sevier River area of Utah, since many parts of=
 the
  region had been flooded owing to unusually heavy rainfall in the previous
  autumn, winter and spring. Mosquitoes were collected by means of New Jers=
ey
  light traps and traps baited with carbon dioxide and New Jersey light tra=
ps. A
  total of 12 mosquito species was caught (22 094 individuals), of which th=
e
  commonest was C. tarsalis. Mosquito pools, and also sentinel chickens and=
 a
  duck at Richfield and Deseret, all proved negative for WEE and SLE; the
  continuance of the encephalitis surveillance programme is however recomme=
nded
  in view of the high mosquito density and the prediction of further abnorm=
ally
  wet years in the immediate future.
DE: distribution-; mosquito-nets
OD: Culex-tarsalis; Culicidae-; Diptera-
GE: USA-; Utah-
BT: Culex; Culicidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals;
  North-America; America; Mountain-States-of-USA; Western-States-of-USA; US=
A
CC: TT300; HH700
CD: Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Other-Control
  -Measures
PT: Miscellaneous
