Record 992 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: A study of health and productivity of traditionally managed cattle in Z=
ambia.
AU: Perry-BD; Mwanaumo-B; Schels-HF; Eicher-E; Zaman-MR
AD: FAO Anim. Dis. Control Project, Central Vet. Res. Inst., PO Box 30563,
  Lusaka, Zambia.
SO: Preventive-Veterinary-Medicine. 1984, 2: 5, 633-653; 11 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: A three-tiered survey was devised comprising a detailed questionnaire, =
a
  serological survey and a sentinel herd scheme for disease surveillance. T=
he
  survey was carried out in the traditional farming sector in 7 districts o=
f
  Zambia to obtain background information on cattle management and producti=
vity,
  data on the prevalence of tickborne and other disease problems in these a=
reas
  and to monitor changes in individual herds. In the questionnaire survey, =
288
  farmers were interviewed. They owned a total of 15 360 head of cattle,
  representing approximately one percent of the national herd. Mean herd si=
zes
  ranged from 31 to 114 for each district. Mean calving percentages were 44=
-80%.
  Average national offtake from these herds was 10%. Calf mortality rates r=
anged
  from 4 to 32%, while adult yearly mortality rates ranged from 4 to 16%. F=
armers
  considered unthriftiness to be the most important health problem, followe=
d by
  subcutaneous oedema, sudden death and lameness. The importance of these
  conditions varied with region. Factors affecting the regional variation o=
f
  these figures are discussed.
DE: Epidemiological-surveys; Animal-production; cattle-diseases
OD: cattle-
GE: Zambia-
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Southern-Africa; Africa-South-of-Sahara; Africa
CC: LL860; LL100
CD: Animal-Disorders-Not-caused-by-Organisms; Animal-Husbandry-General
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0167-5877
UD: 950314

Record 993 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Western equine encephalitis in Manitoba-equine cases 1975-1981.
AU: Neufeld-JL; Nayar-GPS; L-Sekla (ed.)
SO: Western-equine-encephalitis-in-Manitoba. 1982, 62-79; Library: CIE.
PB: Department of Health; Winnipeg, Manitoba; Canada
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: From 1975-1981 a total of 332 cases (128 in 1981) of Western equine
  encephalitis (WEE) were confirmed in horses. There were 37 deaths (27 in =
1981)
  due to WEE. Vaccinated horses suffer less severe manifestations of diseas=
e and
  recover more rapidly than unvaccinated horses. The possibilities of using=
 the
  horse as a sentinel species to detect WEE virus are discussed.

Record 995 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1984-1986

TI: Arbovirus studies in the Guajira region of Venezuela: activities of eas=
tern
  equine encephalitis and Venezuelan equine encephalitis viruses during an
  interepizootic period.
AU: Walder-R; Suarez-OM; Calisher-CH
AD: Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cientificas, Centro de Microbio=
logia
  y Biologia Celular, Laboratorio de Virus Animales, Caracas 1010 A, Venezu=
ela.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1984, 33: 4, 699-707=
; 6
  fig.; 19 ref.
PY: 1984
LA: English
AB: Repeated outbreaks of Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus in man and
  equines in the Guajira region of Venezuela indicated the possible existen=
ce of
  a sylvatic focus of an epizootic subtype of the virus. A surveillance sys=
tem
  was established, and attempts were made to isolate the virus from 67 760
  mosquitoes of 18 species and from sentinel hamsters. Sixteen isolates of
  eastern equine encephalitis virus were recovered from Culex dunni and C.
  panocossa [C. aikenii] and a strain of Itaqui virus was recovered from Ae=
des
  taeniorhynchus, while 60 isolates of eastern equine encephalitis, 2 of
  Venezuelan equine encephalitis and 2 of Itaqui viruses were recovered fro=
m
  hamster tissues. Evidence for the presence of both viruses in small wild
  vertebrates was obtained as a result of serological testing. The study sh=
owed,
  for the first time, the enzootic presence of both Venezuelan equine
  encephalitis (prototype ID) and eastern equine encephalitis viruses durin=
g a
  non-epizoodemic period in the Guajira region.
DE: distribution-; vectors-; disease-vectors; mosquito-nets
OD: Aedes-taeniorhynchus; viruses-; eastern-equine-encephalitis-virus; Culi=
cidae
  -; Diptera-
GE: Venezuela-
ID: Culex-dunni; Culex-aikenii; Itaqui-virus
BT: Aedes; Culicidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals;
  equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Alphavirus; Togaviridae; viruses; arbovir=
uses;

Record 997 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Performance tests on vacuum regulators.
AU: O'-Callaghan-E; O'-Shea-J
AD: An Foras Taluntais, Moorepark Res. Cent., Fermoy, Co. Cork, Irish Repub=
lic.
SO: Milking-machine-research-at-Moorepark-1978-82. 1983, 183-191; 8 ref.
PB: An Foras Taluntais; Dublin; Irish Republic
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: 3 Vacuumaster (type 23.020), 3 Sentinel (types X, 50 and 75 resp.) and =
1
  Gascoigne Isovac (type 2000) regulators were tested for capacity, leakage
  airflow and operating vacuum. Measurements were made on new unused sample=
s and
  again on the same regulators after they had completed 2.5 X 105 cycles of
  operation. The Sentinel X and the Gascoigne Isovac broadly conformed to t=
he
  Irish Standard. The other 2 Sentinels had leakage problems which were
  attributed to their design. Vacummaster regulators showed a large decreas=
e in
  capacity (from 1032 to 828 l/min) after use.

Record 999 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Surveillance for arthropod-borne viral activity and disease in Californ=
ia
  during 1981.
AU: Grant-CD; Washino-RK; Lusk-EE; Coykendall-RL; Emmons-RW; Milby-MM; Gill=
ies
  -PA; Reeves-WC; Bayer-EV; Grant-CD (ed.); Washino-RK (ed.); Lusk-EE (ed.)=
;
  Coykendall-RL (ed.)
AD: Viral and Rickettsial Disease Laboratory Section, California Department=
 of
  Health Services, Berkeley, CA 94704, USA.
SO: Proceedings and Papers of the Fiftieth Annual Conference of the Califor=
nia
  Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc. and the Thirty-eighth Annua=
l
  Meeting of the American Mosquito Control Association, Inc. April 18-22, 1=
982,
  held at Capitol Plaza Holiday Inn, Sacramento, California.  1983, 29-38.
PB: CMVCA Press; Sacramento, California
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Surveys in California for arthropod-borne and especially mosquito-borne
  viruses were continued in 1981 [see RAE/B 70, 3255] by means both of
  serological tests of human and equine cases of suspected encephalitis and=
 of
  tests of mosquito pools for viruses. No human cases of western equine
  encephalitis (WEE) or of St. Louis encephalitis (SLE) were confirmed duri=
ng the
  year, and only 1 equine case of WEE. A total of 2205 pools of mosquitoes =
(104
  439 individuals) was collected, of which 92.3% consisted of Culex tarsali=
s Coq.
  and members of the species-complex of C. pipiens L.; 48 isolations were m=
ade of
  WEE, 2 of SLE, 100 of Hart Park virus, 65 of Turlock virus and 8 of the
  California encephalitis group. Sentinel flocks of domestic fowls were exp=
osed
  in 22 localities; 11 flocks developed antibodies to WEE and 3 to SLE. The
  prospects for 1982 were that high run-off resulting from heavy rainfall a=
nd
  snowfall during the winter of 1981-82 would give conditions favourable to
  excessive mosquito breeding, and that extensive surveillance and control
  measures would be necessary to prevent epidemics of encephalitis in Calif=
ornia.

Record 1000 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Identification of New Guama and Group C serogroup bunyaviruses and an
  ungrouped virus from southern Brazil.
AU: Calisher-CH; Coimbra-TLM; Lopes-O-de-Souza; Muth-DJ; Sacchetta-L-de-Abr=
eu;
  Francy-DB; Lazuick-JS; Cropp-CB; Souza-Lopes-O-de; De-Souza-Lopes-O; Abre=
u
  -Sacchetta-L-de; De-Abreu-Sacchetta-L
AD: Division of Vector-Borne Viral Diseases, Center for Infectious Diseases=
,
  Centers for Disease Control, Public Health Service, US Department of Heal=
th and
  Human Services, Fort Collins, Colorado 80522, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1983, 32: 2, 424-431=
; 1
  fig.; 15 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: From 1975 to 1978, 36 viruses were recovered from man, bats, birds, sen=
tinel
  mice and hamsters, and from Culex sacchettae Sirivanakarn & Jakob, C. tae=
niopus
  D. & K. and C. epanastasis Dyar, all of the subgenus Melanoconion, collec=
ted in
  coastal Brazil in the State of Sao Paulo. Identifications of 22 of these =
36
  viruses have been reported. Six of the remaining 14 isolates were shown t=
o be
  Guama serogroup bunyaviruses. Two of these 6were strains of a newly recog=
nised
  virus for which the name Cananeia virus is proposed; another is a second =
newly
  recognised Guama serogroup virus for which the name Itimirim virus is pro=
posed;
  a fourth is a strain of Bertioga virus and the other 2 are strains of Gua=
ratuba
  virus. Before these studies Guaratuba virus was considered an ungrouped
  bunyavirus, but cross-testing by complement-fixation demonstrated that th=
is
  virus, and Mirim virus as well, should be considered members of the Guama
  serogroup. Another 6 viruses were shown to be strains of a single, newly
  recognised Group C bunyavirus for which the name Bruconha virus is propos=
ed.
  Two strains of a single virus were shown by electron microscopy to belong=
 to
  the family Bunyaviridae, but serological relationships with other members=
 of
  this family of viruses were not found; the name Enseada virus is proposed=
 for
  this newly recognised agent.
DE: distribution-; vectors-; hosts-; disease-vectors; mosquito-nets
OD: Culex-taeniopus; viruses-; Oryzomys-; Culicidae-; Diptera-
GE: Brazil-
ID: Culex-sachettae; Culex-epanastasis; Bruconha-virus; Enseada-virus; Cana=
neia
  -virus; Bertioga-virus; Guaratuba-virus; Itimirim-virus
BT: Culex; Culicidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals;
  Hesperomyinae; Muridae; rodents; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; South-Am=
erica;
  America
CC: TT300; HH700
CD: Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Other-Control
  -Measures

Record 1001 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Sampling stable fly and house fly pupal parasites on beef feedlots and
  dairies in eastern Nebraska.
AU: Meyer-JA; Petersen-JJ
AD: Department of Entomology, Nebraska University, Lincoln, NE 68583, USA.
SO: Southwestern-Entomologist. 1982, 7: 3, 119-124; 1 fig.; 11 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: In studies on 2 cattle feedlots and a dairy in eastern Nebraska in 1981=
, the
  percentage parasitism by hymenopterous parasites of sentinel pupae (labor=
atory
  -reared pupae exposed to field parasites), field pupae (wild pupae collec=
ted
  from breeding sites) and pupae collected in pupal traps was 1.6-1.8, 12.1=
-18.3
  and 22.8-34.9, respectively, in the case of Musca domestica L., and that =
of
  field pupae and pupae collected in pupal traps 8.4-16.4 and 8.8 for Stomo=
xys
  calcitrans (L.). The commonest parasites were Muscidifurax spp., Spalangi=
a
  nigroaenea Curt. and S. endius Wlk. The data indicated that weekly collec=
tions
  of field pupae from various breeding sites on both feedlots and dairies o=
ffered
  the most consistent estimates of the rates of parasitism of the 2 species=
 of
  flies. The pupal trap effectively sampled parasites of Musca domestica bu=
t not
  those of Stomoxys calcitrans.
DE: natural-enemies; distribution-; parasites-; SAMPLING-; hosts-
OD: arthropods-; Musca-domestica; Stomoxys-calcitrans; Spalangia-endius;

Record 1002 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Evaluation of the entomogenous fungi Culicinomyces clavosporus and
  Lagenidium giganteum for control of the salt marsh mosquito, Aedes
  taeniorhynchus.
AU: Merriam-TL; Axtell-RC
AD: Department of Entomology, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC
  27650, USA.
SO: Mosquito-News. 1982, 42: 4, 594-602; 21 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: When applied at 1 X 105 conidia/ml in the laboratory in North Carolina,
  Culicinomyces clavosporus afforded about 55% control after 3 days of larv=
ae of
  Aedes taeniorhynchus (Wied.) in small containers partly filled with eithe=
r
  dredged spoil (water salinity 1.8 p.p.t.) or soil from an upland site (sa=
linity
  0 p.p.t.). At 5 X 104 conidia/ml in 5 litres of distilled water in large
  containers filled with either soil type, C. clavosporus caused about 45%
  control after 1 day and 86% after 5. The mortality of larvae in sentinel =
cages
  in the large containers of both soil types was 93% 5 days after treatment=
. In
  field tests, conidia and hyphae applied at 1 X 1010 conidia/m2 to the sur=
face
  of saltmarsh pools (salinities 10.0-13.2 p.p.t.) caused 100% mortality of=
 field
  -collected 2nd-instar larvae in sentinel cages in 3 of 5 pools within 24 =
h of
  application, and 98% mortality in the remaining pools in 72 h. Dissection=
 of
  larvae in laboratory and field tests confirmed infection, but in the fiel=
d most
  larvae died before there was extensive fungal growth in the haemocoel.
  Lagenidium giganteum failed to infect mosquito larvae in the laboratory o=
r
  field.
DE: control-; biological-control; salt-marshes; hosts-; insect-control; mos=
quito
  -nets
OD: fungi-; Lagenidium-giganteum; Aedes-taeniorhynchus; Culicidae-; Diptera=
-;
  CULICINOMYCES-CLAVISPORUS
GE: North-Carolina; USA-
ID: Culicinomyces-clavosporus; not-infective
BT: Lagenidium; Lagenidiales; Mastigomycotina; Eumycota; fungi; Aedes;
  Culicidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals; Culicino=
myces;
  Deuteromycotina; Appalachian-States-of-USA; Southern-States-of-USA; USA; =
North
  -America; America; South-Atlantic-States-of-USA
CC: TT300; HH000; HH100; HH700; LL820
CD: Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Pathogen,-Pest-=
and
  -Parasite-Management-General; Biological-Control; Other-Control-Measures;
  Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
UD: 950203
AN: 830599913

Record 1003 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Diagnosis of ambient air pollution injury to red maple leaves.
AU: Krause-CR
AD: USDA Crops Res. Lab., PO Box 365, Delaware, OH 43015, USA.
SO: Scanning-Electron-Microscopy. 1981, No. III, 202-206; 2 pl.; 10 ref.
PY: 1981
LA: English
AB: Ramets of Acer rubrum 'Scarlet Sentinel' were grown under ambient field
  conditions in Ohio for 5 months (May-Sept.) in either clean (i.e. minimal=
 03
  and SO2 concn.) or polluted air with phytotoxic combinations of O3 and SO=
2
  concn. Neither site produced macroscopic symptoms of air pollution damage=
, but
  SEM studies showed significant differences in leaf surfaces. Leaves from =
plants
  grown in clean air had uniformly turgid epidermal cells and fluffy epicut=
icular
  wax, whereas those from polluted air had collapsed epidermal cells and la=
cked
  fluffy epicuticular wax. Cross-sections revealed increased vesicular acti=
vity
  in the mesophyll cells of leaves exposed to polluted air compared with th=
ose of
  leaves growing in clean air, which appeared normal. From author's summary=
.
DE: foliage-; damage-; air-pollution; microscopy-; fumes-; sulfur-dioxide;
  broadleaves-
OD: Acer-rubrum; Acer-
GE: Ohio-; USA-
ID: O3
RN: 7446-09-5
BT: dicotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta; plants; Acer; Aceraceae;
  Sapindales; Corn-Belt-States-of-USA; North-Central-States-of-USA; USA; No=
rth
  -America; America; East-North-Central-States-of-USA
CC: KK100; PP600; FF030
CD: Forestry-General; Pollution-and-Degradation; Plant-Morphology-and-Struc=
ture
PT: Journal-article
UD: 950203
AN: 830685179

Record 1004 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Routine focal mollusciciding after chemotherapy to control Schistosoma
  mansoni in Cul de Sac valley, Saint Lucia.
AU: Barnish-G; Jordan-P; Bartholomew-RK; Grist-E
AD: Res. & Control Dep., Castries, St. Lucia, West Indies.
SO: Transactions-of-the-Royal-Society-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 198=
2,
  76: 5, 602-609; 12 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Concluding results of a 10-year schistosomiasis control programme in Cu=
l de
  Sac valley, Saint Lucia, are described. After an area-wide mollusciciding
  campaign (1970 to 1975), and a surveillance/treatment programme supplemen=
ted
  with selective population chemotherapy in 1975 and 1976, prevalence rates=
 of S.
  mansoni were reduced to low levels. To prevent a resurgence of transmissi=
on a
  cost-effective routine focal mollusciciding programme, suitable for publi=
c
  health implementation was evaluated from 1977 to 1981. Streams and main
  collector drains in banana fields, considered to be potential S. mansoni
  transmission sites, were treated every 4 weeks with Bayluscide 6076
  emulsifiable concentrate (Clonitralide). Snail populations were controlle=
d in
  the treated areas but large numbers were present where no treatment was g=
iven.
  Only 0.06% of sentinel snails became infected. Prevalence of infection in=
 the
  human population remained low (over-all 5%) and intensity of infection at=
 a
  level not normally associated with schistosomal disease. Since control st=
arted
  10 years earlier the level of potential contamination has fallen by 92% i=
n high
  transmission areas. The 4 year programme cost US$12 909, of which 54% was=
 for
  molluscicide, 27% for labour and 19% for transport, equipment and sundrie=
s. The
  average annual cost per head of population was US$0.46. [AS]
DE: Molluscicides-; control-programmes; parasites-; helminths-
OD: Trematoda-; Digenea-; Schistosoma-mansoni
GE: St-Lucia; Caribbean-
BT: pesticides; invertebrates; animals; Platyhelminthes; Trematoda; Schisto=
soma;
  Schistosomatidae; Digenea; Windward-Islands; Lesser-Antilles; Caribbean; =
America
CC: VV200; HH400; TT100
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Control-=
by
  -Chemicals-and-Drugs; Medical-and-Veterinary-Helminthology-Records-Discon=
tinued
PT: Journal-article

UD: 950203
AN: 820801968

Record 1005 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Seasonality of Diplostomum spathaceum (Trematoda: Strigeidae) transmiss=
ion
  to brook trout (Salvelinus fontinalis) in northern Quebec, Canada.
AU: Brassard-P; Curtis-MA; Rau-ME
AD: Inst. of Parasit., McGill Univ., Macdonald Coll., Campus, 21 111 Lakesh=
ore
  Rd., Ste. Anne de Bellevue, PQ, Canada H9X 1C0.
SO: Canadian-Journal-of-Zoology. 1982, 60: 10, 2258-2263; 29 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
LS: French
AB: Lymnaea arctica collected from a pond near Schefferville in the Quebec
  subarctic (Canada) first shed Diplostomum spathaceum cercariae in mid-Jun=
e. The
  prevalence of infection rose to a peak of 7.5% during the first week of A=
ugust
  and then declined to 1.7% in mid-September. Cercarial output by 10 infect=
ed
  snails (monitored from 6 July to 18 September) varied markedly and was a
  function of water temperature. It rose rapidly in early July to a maximum=
 near
  the end of the month, after which a precipitous decline occurred. A 2nd m=
inor
  peak occurred during the first half of September. Sentinel fish (Salvelin=
us
  fontinalis) were put in the pond from 20-30 July, 30 July to 20 August an=
d 21
  August-15 September. The numbers of metacercariae acquired per 48 h by th=
e fish
  in these 3 periods were 2.3, 7.0 and 2.5, respectively. This pattern of
  cercarial acquisition corresponded with cercarial availability which was
  calculated as the product of the rate of cercarial release, the expected
  cercarial life-span and the prevalence of infected snails.
DE: Freshwater-fishes; epizootiology-; parasites-; helminths-
OD: Mollusca-; Digenea-; Trematoda-; Diplostomum-spathaceum; Salvelinus
  -fontinalis
GE: Canada-; North-America
ID: Lymnaea-arctica; seasonal-dynamics
BT: fishes; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; aquatic-animals; invertebrates;
  Trematoda; Platyhelminthes; Diplostomum; Diplostomidae; Digenea; Salvelin=
us;
  Salmonidae; Salmoniformes; Osteichthyes; North-America; America
CC: TT100; MM300
CD: Medical-and-Veterinary-Helminthology-Records-Discontinued; Aquatic-Biol=
ogy
  -and-Ecology

Record 1006 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: The use of golden hamsters as sentinel animals in the localities where =
uta
  is endemic (cutaneous leishmaniasis).
OT: Empleo del hamster dorado como animal centinela en las localidades dond=
e es
  endemica la uta (leishmaniasis tegumentaria).
AU: Herrer-A
AD: Inst. de Salud Publica, Apart. Correo No.451, Lima, Peru.
SO: Revista-do-Instituto-de-Medicina-Tropical-de-Sao-Paulo. 1982, 24: 3, 16=
2
  -167; 6 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: Portuguese
LS: English
AB: During 2 years 47 golden hamsters were exposed in a tunnel near a roadw=
ay in
  the S. Eulalia valley in Peru for periods of up to 8 weeks. 21 (44.7%) be=
came
  infected with leishmaniasis. Infection was more common in summer and autu=
mn.
  Infection occurred mostly on the ears, less on the feet and only twice on=
 the
  nose. Frequently 2 sites were involved.

Record 1008 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: A comparison of the amino acid composition of two commercial oat groats=
.
AU: Zarkadas-CG; Hulan-HW; Proudfoot-FG
AD: Dep. Chemistry and Physics, McGill Univ., MacDonald Campus, Que. H9X 1C=
0,
  Canada.
SO: Cereal-Chemistry. 1982, 59: 5, 323-327; 55 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: The average crude protein content in DM of dehusked oats was 15.0% for =
cv.
  Oxford, grown in eastern Canada and 13.3% for cv. Sentinel, grown in west=
ern
  Canada. Total lipid was 3.7 and 6.6%, metabolizable energy 17.7 and 16.9 =
MJ/kg
  and crude fibre 3.4 and 3.7%. Both groats had good quality protein, with =
an
  amino acid composition better than that of other cereals and an excellent
  balance of essential amino acids limited only in lysine. The values obtai=
ned
  for methionine and cystine far exceeded those previously reported for oth=
er oat
  varieties, and the present values were 10 to 15% higher for the sum of ly=
sine,
  threonine and methionine. Excellent recovery of tryptophan in oat groat
  proteins was achieved for the first time. 4-Hydorxyproline, which occurs =
in
  collagens and elastin, was also found in both oat groats at 0.22 and 0.14=
 g/kg,
  respectively.
DE: oats-; amino-acids; plant-composition; proteins-; lysine-; methionine-;
  cysteine-; hydroxyproline-; threonine-; cereals-
OD: Avena-sativa
RN: 56-87-1; 63-68-3; 52-90-4; 51-35-4; 72-19-5
BT: Avena; Gramineae; Cyperales; monocotyledons; angiosperms; Spermatophyta=
;
  plants
CC: QQ500; QQ050; FF040; RR300; FF020
CD: Food-Composition-and-Quality; Crop-Produce; Plant-Composition; Feed

Record 1009 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: OAC Woodstock oats.
AU: Reinbergs-E
AD: Dep. Crop Sci., Univ. Guelph, Ont., Canada.
SO: Canadian-Journal-of-Plant-Science. 1983, 63: 2, 543-545; 2 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
LS: French
AB: OAC Woodstock was derived from the F6 of OA187-1 (an interspecific comp=
osite
  cross involving Avena strigosa) X OA186-2 (a complex cross involving Clin=
tland,
  Garry and Stormont) by pedigree selection. It is a midseason variety havi=
ng a
  panicle with medium to long branches, moderately long grains mainly witho=
ut
  awns, a 1000-grain weight of 32.9 g, resistance to Ustilago avenae, U. ko=
lleri
  [U. hordei] and races CR13 and CR36 of Puccinia coronata and tolerance to
  Septoria avenae [Leptosphaeria avenaria]. OAC Woodstock gives greater yie=
lds
  than Elgin, Scott and Sentinel.

TI: Study of winter wheat varieties from Canada and the USA in the forest s=
teppe
  of the Ukraine.
AU: Dvornik-NE; Mel'-nikov-AF
AD: VIR, Leningrad, USSR.
SO: Trudy-po-Prikladnoi-Botanike,-Genetike-i-Selektsii. 1980, 68: 1, 69-72.
PY: 1980
LA: Russian
LS: English
AB: Of 65 varieties studied during 1976-77, the most winter hardy were Wina=
lta,
  Frederik, Riley 67, Palo Duro and Laporte, the most lodging resistant wer=
e
  Nugaines, Hyslop, Gaines and Satanta and the highest yielding were Freder=
ick,
  Centurk and Scout. Frederick, Palo Duro and Laporte had the largest grain=
,
  Atlas 66, Sentinel and Scout the highest protein content and Yucon and Sa=
tanta
  the highest flour swelling power in acetic acid. The best for a combinati=
on of
  characters were Frederik, Palo Duro and Satanta.

Record 1011 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Preliminary characterization of D'Aguilar virus and three Palyam group
  viruses new to Australia.
AU: Cybinski-DH; St-George-TD
AD: CSIRO Div. Anim. Hlth, Long Pocket Lab., Indooroopilly, Queensland 4068=
, USA.
SO: Australian-Journal-of-Biological-Sciences. 1982, 35: 3, 343-351; 20 ref=
.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Between 1974 and 1980, 424 viruses were isolated at the Long Pocket
  Laboratories of the Division of Animal Health, CSIRO, either from insects=
 or
  from the blood of sentinel cattle, and of these, 165 cross-reacted with
  D'Aguilar virus (an Australian Palyam group orbivirus) in a complement fi=
xation
  test. Neutralization tests were used to classify these viruses into four
  serotypes with the isolates D'Aguilar B8112, CSIRO 11, CSIRO 58 and CSIRO=
 82 as
  the type strains. The latter three were new to Australia. Like other
  orbiviruses, these four serotypes were partly sensitive to treatment with=
 ether
  or chloroform. Neutralizing antibodies against D'Aguilar, CSIRO 11 and CS=
IRO 58
  viruses were detected in sera from cattle, buffalo, deer and sheep but no=
t in
  sera from humans, horses, pigs or marsupials. Antibodies against CSIRO 82=
 virus
  were detected in 85% of 26 buffalo, and 0.4% of 495 cattle sera tested. T=
he
  antibody distribution in Australia for D'Aguilar, CSIRO 11 and CSIRO 58 v=
iruses
  fell within the distribution limits of Culicoides brevitarsis, the insect=
 from
  which these viruses were most commonly recovered. The antibody distributi=
on for
  CSIRO 82 virus, which was isolated from a pool containing C. schultzei an=
d C.
  peregrinus, fell within the much more restricted distribution limits of t=
hese
  species. None of these viruses has been associated with disease.
DE: Antibodies-; viral-diseases
OD: Cattle-; arboviruses-; Culicoides-; orbivirus-
GE: Australia-
ID: Australian-strains
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; viruses; Ceratopogonidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods=
;
  invertebrates; Reoviridae; arboviruses; Australasia; Oceania
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
UD: 950203
AN: 822211897

Record 1012 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Arbovirus serology and isolations from sentinel cattle in the Northern
  Territory of Australia, 1981.
AU: Gard-GP; Bainbridge-MH; TD-St-George (ed.); BH-Kay (ed.)
AD: Dep. Primary Prod., PO Box 4160, Darwin, Northern Territory 5794, Austr=
alia.
SO: Arbovirus Research in Australia. Proceedings of the 3rd Symposium, 15-1=
7
  Feb. 1982.  1982, 183-188; 4 ref.
PB: CSIRO; Brisbane; Australia
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Seven sentinel cattle herds in different locations in Northern Territor=
y
  were monitored for arbovirus during the first 7 months of 1981. Antibodie=
s
  against bluetongue virus were detected in 100 of 125 cattle in six of the=
 herds
  but not in 12 cattle in the other herd. Antibodies to Murray Valley
  encephalitis virus occurred in 44 of 54 cattle in 3 herds and in all catt=
le
  tested from the other 4 herds. Twenty-one viruses were isolated from bloo=
d
  samples in BHK21 tube monolayers--4 bluetongue viruses, 6 haemorrhagic di=
sease
  of deer viruses, 7 Palyam group viruses and 3 bovine ephemeral fever viru=
ses.
  All viruses were isolated from healthy cattle.

  -virus

rus;

Record 1013 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Canine mesothelioma and asbestos: a case-control study
AU: Domanski-L; Dubielzig-R; Glickman-L
AD: Univ., Vet. Sch. Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19104, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Epidemiology. 1982, 116: 3, 586; abstract.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Eighteen histologically confirmed canine mesotheliomas were diagnosed a=
t the
  University of Pennsylvania from January 1977 to December 1981. The mean a=
ge for
  cases was 8.0 years (range 4-12 years); there were 17 males and one femal=
e.
  Fifteen were pure bred and 3 were mixed. This age, sex, and breed distrib=
ution
  was different from the total canine hospital population. A cancer and non
  -cancer control, each matched to a case by age at diagnosis, year of admi=
ssion,
  sex and breed, were selected. Sixteen owners of cases and 32 controls wer=
e
  interviewed to determine their occupation and smoking habits, and their d=
og's
  medical history, lifestyle, diet and exposure to asbestos. Results were
  analyzed using a matched technique for each control separately and combin=
ed
  controls. A significant odds ratio was found with an asbestos-related
  occupation. Analysis of lung tissue from two cases revealed prominent
  accumulations of asbestos fibres. Implications of this sentinel model are
  discussed.
DE: Pets-; POLLUTION-; Public-health; lungs-; carcinogens-; neoplasms-
OD: Man-; dogs-
ID: mesothelioma; asbestos-in-dog
BT: animals; Homo; Hominidae; Primates; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; Can=
is;
  Canidae; Fissipeda; carnivores
CC: LL860; LL070; PP600; UU350; VV000
CD: Animal-Disorders-Not-caused-by-Organisms; Pets-and-Companion-Animals;
  Pollution-and-Degradation; Health-Services; Human-Health-and-Hygiene-Gene=
ral
PT: Abstract-only

Record 1014 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Transmission of feline viral rhinotracheitis.
AU: Gaskell-RM; Povey-RC
AD: Dep. Vet. Med., Langford House, Langford, Bristol, UK.
SO: Veterinary-Record. 1982, 111: 16, 359-362; 22 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Feline viral rhinotracheitis (FVR) virus could be successfully transmit=
ted
  between shedding carrier cats and unrelated susceptible kittens, but only=
 if
  there was intimate contact between them. Studies on the transmission of F=
VR
  virus from carrier queens to their kittens showed that although four of 1=
0
  queens shed virus in the post partum period, a total of only four kittens=
 from
  three litters developed a contact infection. All four kittens remained
  asymptomatic. Two shed for one day only and did not become carriers (as
  evidenced by corticosteroid treatment) and two shed for 15 days and 25 da=
ys and
  were subsequently shown to have become carriers. None of the remaining ki=
ttens
  tested shed virus. There was no evidence of in utero transmission between=
 FVR
  -recovered queens and kittens. Passive antibody titres in kittens born to=
 FVR
  -recovered queens declined to less than 1 in 4 in individual animals by t=
wo to
  10 weeks of age. Mean titres calculated from a linear regression equation
  reached less than 1 in 4 and less than 1 in 2 by six and nine weeks of ag=
e,
  respectively. Experiments using a multistage liquid impinger demonstrated=
 that
  FVR virus was unlikely to be transmitted between cats by aerosol and this=
 was
  confirmed by the ability of a sentinel cat to withstand virus shedding fr=
om
  carriers over a six month period, although housed in the same air space.
DE: Carrier-state; Disease-transmission; cat-diseases; Viral-diseases; Mate=
rnal
  -immunity; Epidemiology-; transmission-
OD: feline-rhinotracheitis-virus; cats-
BT: feline-herpesvirus; Herpesviridae; viruses; Felis; Felidae; Fissipeda;
  carnivores; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article
IS: 0042-4900
UD: 950203
AN: 822215000

Record 1015 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Susceptibility of South American non-human primates to foot-and-mouth
  disease virus.
AU: Schudel-AA; Sadir-AM; Etcheverrigaray-ME; Samus-S; Colilla-O; Rivenson-=
S
AD: Dep. Virol., CICV-INTA, Castelar, Argentina.
SO: Bulletin-de-l'Office-International-des-Epizooties. 1981, 93: 11-12, 134=
5
  -1350; 11 ref.
PY: 1981
LA: English
AB: Primates of the Cebidae family (Saimiri sciureus and Cebus capucinus) w=
ere
  susceptible to experimental infection with FMDV, types O, A and C. Viraem=
ia, as
  well as specific seroconversion for the infecting virus, were detected, b=
ut
  there were no observable abnormalities. Excretion of the virus at the
  oropharynx took place up to the 11th day after infection, but no horizont=
al
  transmission to sentinel primates could be shown.

Record 1016 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Neutralising antibodies to rinderpest virus in sheep and goats in weste=
rn
  Kenya.
AU: Rossiterm-PB; Jessett-DM; Taylor-WP
AD: Vet. Res. Dep., Agric. Res. Inst., Muguga, PO Box 32, Kikuyu, Kenya.
SO: Veterinary-Record. 1982, 111: 22, 504-505; 13 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: After reports had been received of the temporary occurrence of a rinder=
pest
  -like disease among possibly unvaccinated cattle belonging to nomadic
  pastoralists in northwestern Kenya, serum samples were collected from 66 =
goats
  and 34 sheep selected as sentinel animals in ten flocks in the Turkana
  district; 34% of animals of all ages in nine flocks contained neutralizin=
g
  antibody to rinderpest virus at titres of 0.3-2.25 log10 VN50, and a furt=
her
  24% had trace amounts. A few of the positive animals also had titres to p=
est of
  small ruminants virus, but at much lower titres. Of 103 control sheep and=
 goats
  in southwestern Kenya, where rinderpest had not been diagnosed for 15 yea=
rs,
  one goat ahd a titre of 1.73 log10 VN50, and another goat (in a different=
 herd)
  had trace antibody. It is suggested that (a) sheep and goats in Turkana a=
re
  harbouring rinderpest virus virulent for cattle, or (b) rinderpest virus =
may be
  circulating among sheep and goats, independently of cattle, in western Ke=
nya.
DE: Epidemiological-surveys; viral-diseases; cattle-diseases
OD: cattle-; rinderpest-virus
GE: Kenya-
ID: sheep-and-goat-in-Kenya
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Morbillivirus; Paramyxoviridae; viruses; East-Africa; =
Africa
  -South-of-Sahara; Africa

Record 1017 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Hierarchy of disease problems found in Limousin dairy cows.
OT: Hierarchie des problemes pathologiques rencontres sur des vaches allait=
antes
  limousines.
AU: Barnouin-J; Brochart-M
AD: Laboratoire d'ecopathologie, INRA de Theix, 63110 Beaumont, France.
SO: Bulletin-des-Groupements-Techniques-Veterinaires. 1982, No. 5, 3-10.
PY: 1982
LA: French
AB: A detailed survey of pathological conditions in cattle and sheep in 126
  farms has been undertaken since 1977 in seven Departments of France. The =
flow
  of information from veterinarians and farmers in the field, to and from t=
he
  various official laboratories, is described. Records provide statistics o=
n
  numbers, symptoms, diagnosis, mortality, composition of rations, details =
of
  calvings and insemination, milk-production records, leukocyte counts in m=
ilk,
  and many other factors. A comparison of disease conditions observed in su=
ckling
  cows and milking cows is presented. Statistics of serological diagnoses a=
re
  given. The important condition of infertility and its causes are discusse=
d.
  Available statistics suggested that cows in loose housing had better fert=
ility
  than cows in tethered housing, but under loose housing respiratory affect=
ions
  in young animals were more frequent. Between November 1977 and January 19=
79, in
  "sentinel" herds in two Departments, the commonest condition in suckling =
cows
  was non-haemorrhagic diarrhoea (8.1%), but in milking cows clinical masti=
tis
  (25.2%) was the commonest, followed by endometritis (13.7%) and lameness
  (13.4%).
DE: Disease-prevalence; DISEASE-SURVEYS; Epidemiological-surveys; Breeds-;
  Bovine-mastitis; animal-husbandry; cattle-diseases
OD: cattle-
GE: France-
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla;
  ungulates; mammals; Western-Europe; Europe; Mediterranean-Countries
CC: LL860; LL820; LL800
CD: Animal-Disorders-Not-caused-by-Organisms; Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens=
-and
  -Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Animal-Health-and-Hygiene-General

Record 1018 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Detection of influenza A viruses and influenza epidemics in wild pelagi=
c
  birds by sentinels and population studies.
AU: Sinnecker-H; Sinnecker-R; Zilske-E; Koehler-D
AD: Epidemiological Centre, Tornowstrasse 21, DDR-1500 Potsdam, German
  Democratic Republic.
SO: Zentralblatt-fur-Bakteriologie-Mikrobiologie-und-Hygiene,-I.-Abt.-Origi=
nale,
  -A. 1982, 253: 3, 297-304; 12 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
LS: German
AB: Field experiments with domestic ducks as sentinels and virological and
  serological population observations on wild pelagic birds on a seabird-br=
eeding
  island in the Baltic sea and on rivers and lakes near Berlin were conduct=
ed to
  detect the influenza A virus circulation and epidemics in wild pelagic bi=
rd
  populations. Influenza A virus isolates were detected in tracheal and clo=
acal
  swabs from sentinel ducks and from healthy pelagic birds. Influenza A vir=
us
  epidemics with different subtypes in an influenza season beginning in
  July/August occurred approximately monthly. According to serological popu=
lation
  studies in wild pelagic birds there were some epidemics with influenza A
  viruses, also related to Fowl Plague Virus (Hav1) and Swine influenza vir=
us
  (Hsw1). It is possible to recognize epidemics among wild birds by sentine=
ls and
  by periodic serological observations of wild pelagic bird populations. On=
e
  isolate from sentinel ducks--A/duck/Potsdam/81 (Hav8 Nav5)--had an hither=
to
  undescribed combination of the surface antigens.
DE: Wild-animals; Epidemiological-surveys; wild-birds; viral-diseases
OD: Anseriformes-; avian-influenzavirus; birds-
GE: German-Democratic-Republic; Germany-
BT: vertebrates; Chordata; animals; birds; Influenzavirus; Orthomyxoviridae=
;
  viruses; Central-Europe; Europe; Western-Europe
CC: LL820; PP710
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Biologi=
cal
  -Resources-Animal

Record 1019 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Ecological survey on Getah virus among swine in Japan.
AU: Kumanomido-T; Fakunaga-Y; Ando-Y; Kamada-M; Imagawa-H; Wada-R; Akiyama-=
Y;
  Tanaka-T
AD: Equine Res. Inst., Racing Ass., 1400-4 Shiba, Kokubunji-machi, Shimotsu=
ga
  -gun, Tochigi 329-04, Japan.
SO: Bulletin-of-Equine-Research-Institute,-Japan. 1982, No.19, 89-92; 14 re=
f.
PY: 1982
LA: English
LS: Japanese
AB: Eleven sentinel pigs were placed in a pen located 1.5 km northeast of t=
he
  Miho Training Center, where an outbreak of Getah virus infection had occu=
rred
  among racehorses the previous year. Plasma samples from these pigs yielde=
d
  three viruses--two Japanese encephalitis (JE) viruses and one Getah virus=
.
  Neutralizing antibody against JE virus appeared in all pigs and against G=
etah
  virus in all but two. Eighteen isolates of Getah virus were obtained from
  mosquitoes (Aedes vexans amd Culex tritaeniorhynchus) captured in the pig=
 pen.
  It is suggested that pigs may serve as an amplifying host for Getah virus=
.
DE: Epidemiological-surveys; horse-diseases; Host-range; vectors-; viral-di=
seases
OD: alphavirus-; Getah-virus; flavivirus-; Japanese-encephalitis-virus; hor=
ses-

Record 1020 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Marker characteristics of Venezuelan encephalitis virus strains isolate=
d
  before and after epidemics and equine epizootics in Middle America.
AU: Wiebe-ME; Scherer-WF; Peick-WJ
AD: Dep. Microbiol., Cornell Univ. Med. Coll., 1300 York Ave., New York 100=
21,
  USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Epidemiology. 1983, 117: 2, 201-212; 23 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Ninety-four strains of Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis (VE) virus
  isolated from sentinel hamsters exposed in the Central American countries=
 of
  Mexico, Guatemala, Belize and Honduras were examined for virions with mar=
ker
  characteristics of strains that cause large epidemics and equine outbreak=
s.
  Thirty-four strains came from before, and 60 strains came from after the
  Central American epidemics and equine outbreaks of 1966 and 1969-1972. Tw=
enty
  -three virion clones that resembled epizootic strains by hydroxylapatite
  chromatography and Vero monkey kidney cell plaque size measurements were
  characterized further. However, the predominant virions in these clones w=
ere
  like enzootic strains from Central America north of the Panama Canal regi=
on,
  and not like Central American epizootic VE strains, since they belonged t=
o
  haemagglutination-inhibition antigenic subtype IE, usually had optimal pH=
 of
  haemagglutination at 6.2, and were avirulent for English shorthair guinea=
 pigs
  inoculated s/c. These results controvert the theory that epizootic virion=
s
  emerge in Central America from strains containing mixtures of enzootic an=
d
  epizootic virions in enzootic habitats.
DE: Epidemiology-; Virulence-; horse-diseases; Viral-diseases
OD: hamsters-; equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; horses-
GE: Mexico-; Honduras-; Belize-; Central-America
ID: Central-American-strains
BT: Cricetinae; Muridae; rodents; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; animals;
  Alphavirus; Togaviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Equus; Equidae; Perissodac=
tyla;
  ungulates; North-America; America; Central-America
CC: LL820

Record 1021 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Studies on Haemophilus infection in chickens.
AU: Namgoong-S; An-SH; Kim-KS; Mo-IP; Park-KS
AD: Vet. Res. Inst., Anyang, Korea.
SO: Research-Reports-of-the-Office-of-Rural-Development,-Korea-Livestock-an=
d
  -Veterinary. 1982, 24: 119-123; 13 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: Korean
LS: English
AB: In serological tests in four areas of Korea the overall incidence of H.
  gallinarum infection was 14.1% (179 of 1270 serum samples from 103 flocks=
).
  Haemagglutination-inhibition antibody titres > 8 were regarded as positiv=
e. The
  incidence ranged from 17.3% (96 of 556 birds in 42 flocks) in Seoul and
  Gyeonggi to 6.8% (13 of 190 in 14 flocks) in Chungham. Overall incidence =
was
  highest (19.4%) in birds > 300 days old, whereas in those 60-100 and 150-=
200
  days old it was 9.5 and 9.9% respectively. Transmission of H. gallinarum
  infection to SPF sentinel birds after exposure to commercial birds was ob=
served
  on 4 of 10 farms after 15 weeks. Symptoms in birds infected experimentall=
y
  (intranasal inoculation) were oculonasal discharge, facial swelling, depr=
ession
  and diarrhoea, which contrasted with those in naturally infected birds
  (reduction in egg production, respiratory noises).
DE: poultry-; Bacterial-diseases; Epidemiological-surveys; Disease-transmis=
sion;
  Experimental-infection; poultry-diseases
OD: HAEMOPHILUS-PARAGALLINARUM
ID: Haemophilus-gallinarum; Korea
BT: birds; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Haemophilus; Pasteurellaceae;
  Gracilicutes; bacteria; prokaryotes
CC: LL820; HH600; LL860
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Host
  -Resistance-and-Immunity; Animal-Disorders-Not-caused-by-Organisms
PT: Journal-article

AN: 832221591

Record 1022 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Response of weanling random-bred mice to inoculation with minute virus =
of
  mice.
AU: Smith-AL
AD: Sect. Comp. Med., Yale Univ. Sch. Med., New Haven, Connecticut 06510, U=
SA.
SO: Laboratory-Animal-Science. 1983, 33: 1, 37-39; 7 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Several methods (haemagglutination inhibition, immunofluorescence, ELIS=
A and
  serum neutralization) for detection of serum antibody to minute virus of =
mice
  were compared using serum sample from random-bred, weanling mice experime=
ntally
  inoculated by either the intraperitoneal or oral route. Antibody was dete=
cted
  by all methods in serum from intraperitoneally inoculated mice by 4 days =
post
  -inoculation, while serum from orally infected mice contained detectable
  antibody on day 7 by all methods except neutralization. Serum neutralizin=
g
  antibody was detected much later and at lower levels in serum of orally
  infected mice than in serum of intraperitoneally inoculated mice. Virus w=
as
  recovered from the intestines of both inoculation groups and from the kid=
neys
  of intraperitoneally inoculated mice. Among the latter animals, virus was=
 still
  detectable 10 days post-inoculation, several days after serum neutralizin=
g
  antibody had developed. Sentinel dams with litters placed in cages with
  intraperitoneally inoculated mice 10 days after the inoculation were
  seropositive by immunofluorescence and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay =
when
  tested 3 weeks after contact.
DE: animal-diseases; Viral-diseases; Diagnosis-; Haemagglutination-inhibiti=
on
  -test; Immunofluorescence-; ELISA-; Neutralization-tests; laboratory-anim=
als
OD: MICE-; Parvoviridae-
ID: minute-virus; mouse-minute-virus
BT: animals; Muridae; rodents; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; viruses
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals

Record 1023 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Experimental latent and recrudescent bovine herpesvirus-1 infections in
  calves.
AU: Homan-EJ; Easterday-BC
AD: Dep. Vet. Sci., Univ., Madison, Wisconsin 53706, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1983, 44: 2, 309-313; 21 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Six calves (1-4 weeks old) were inoculated with IBR IPV virus (Omro str=
ain;
  105 PFU intranasally). Virus shedding in nasal secretions was monitored d=
aily.
  At 21-23 days after cessation of virus shedding the calves were injected =
with
  dexamethasone (0.1 mg/kg/day i/v for 5 days). Nasal swabs were examined f=
or
  recrudescent virus shedding. Seven to 10 days after virus shedding had ce=
ased
  these calves were housed with 6 sentinel calves for 4 weeks. Nasal swabs =
and
  blood samples from all calves were examined weekly for virus and antibody=
 resp.
  Two infected calves were examined PM during latent infection. The remaini=
ng 4
  infected calves were given a second dexamethasone treatment and examined =
PM in
  early (48 or 96 h) recrudescence, or 2 or 5 days after virus shedding had
  ceased while in contact with sentinel calves. All inoculated calves shed =
virus
  in nasal secretions during acute infection (8-14 days) and for 1-7 days
  starting at 5-7 days after dexamethasone treatment. After the second
  dexamethasone treatment 2 calves shed virus from day 6 to 8 or 9. There w=
as no
  spontaneous virus shedding. No sentinel calf became infected during the
  experiment. Viral DNA was demonstrated intranuclearly in trigeminal gangl=
ion
  neurons (TGN). Electron microscopy showed changes in the appearance of Ni=
ssl
  bodies and a high frequency of nuclear bodies in TGN. Antibody was demons=
trated
  by immunofluorescence in TGN during recrudescence.
DE: CALVES-; Experimental-infection; Dexamethasone-; Immunofluorescence-;
  Electron-microscopy; Disease-transmission; Carrier-state; Viral-diseases;
  latent-infections; cattle-diseases
OD: cattle-; Bovine-herpesvirus; IBR-IPV-virus
RN: 50-02-2; 55812-90-3; 2265-67-7; 1879-72-7; 312-93-6; 1926-94-9; 16978-5=
7-7;

Record 1024 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Epizootiology of avian influenza--simultaneous monitoring of sentinel d=
ucks
  and turkeys in Minnesota.
AU: Halvorson-D; Karunakaran-D; Senne-D; Kelleher-C; Bailey-C; Abraham-A;
  Hinshaw-V; Newman-J
AD: Coll. Vet. Med., Univ., St Paul, Minnesota 55108, USA.
SO: Avian-Diseases. 1983, 27: 1, 77-85; 11 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Isolation-reared mallards (Anas platyrhynchos) were placed on ponds in
  turkey-rearing areas in Minnesota, and their cloacae were periodically sw=
abbed
  to attempt isolating virus from embryonated chicken eggs. Nearby turkeys =
were
  sampled by taking cloacal and tracheal swabs as well as blood samples.
  Haemagglutinating viruses were identified at the National Veterinary Serv=
ices
  Laboratory, Ames, Iowa. During this two-year study (1980-81), the weekly
  influenzavirus isolation rate from ducks varied from 0 to 24.4%. A total =
of 213
  influenzaviruses were isolated from the ducks. Twenty-six influenzavirus
  subtypes were detected. Ninety-seven flocks of turkeys were diagnosed as =
having
  influenza by virus isolation and/or serology. Eight influenzavirus subtyp=
es
  were involved in the turkey outbreaks, and seven of these were also detec=
ted in
  the ducks and/or other avian species. The weekly infection rate of the se=
ntinel
  ducks correlated directly with observations of wild ducks at the monitori=
ng
  sites. Influenzavirus was isolated from water samples collected near the
  sentinel duck sites during the study.
DE: DISEASE-SURVEYS; Viral-diseases; poultry-; poultry-diseases
OD: avian-influenzavirus; turkeys-; influenzavirus-; Anseriformes-
GE: USA-
ID: avian-species
BT: birds; vertebrates; Chordata; animals; Influenzavirus; Orthomyxoviridae=

  viruses; Meleagris; Phasianidae; Galliformes; North-America; America

Record 1025 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Bovine fascioliasis: economic impact and control in Gulf Coast cattle b=
ased
  on seasonal transmission.
AU: Malone-JB; Loyacano-A; Armstrong-DA; Archbald-LF
AD: Dep. Vet. Microbiol. Parasitol., State Univ., Baton Rouge, Louisiana 70=
803,
  USA.
SO: Bovine-Practitioner. 1982, No.17, 126-133; 30 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: In the United States, Fasciola hepatica is found primarily in Gulf Coas=
t and
  western states with evidence of increasing prevalence associated with irr=
igated
  pastures. Direct loss from the condemnation of livers in 1981 was $7.2 mi=
llion.
  Losses from lowered weight gain in subclinical infections were not estima=
ted.
  Epidemiological studies in Louisiana revealed that most transmission to c=
attle
  occurred in the spring and early summer. Annual variation in the number o=
f
  flukes transmitted was correlated with climatic variables determining the
  number of snail intermediate hosts available for infection. Herd prevalen=
ce and
  sentinel calf data suggest that annual autumnal treatment with albendazol=
e was
  effective for sustained reduction of fluke burdens in low risk years, but=
 at
  least two treatments are required in high risk years. Feedlot studies ind=
icate
  that albendazole treatment may improve average daily gain and feed effici=
ency
  in infected feeder calves. Beef herd performance was improved by treatmen=
t
  directed at reducing loss of cow condition during winter. Further studies=
 to
  develop more cost effective strategic control measures are recommended.
DE: Climatic-factors; seasons-; intermediate-hosts; Disease-transmission;
  Disease-control; anthelmintics-; albendazole-
OD: Fasciola-hepatica; cattle-
GE: USA-; Louisiana-
ID: cattle-in-USA; Fasciola-hepatica-in-cattle
RN: 54965-21-8
BT: Fasciola; Fasciolidae; Digenea; Trematoda; Platyhelminthes; invertebrat=
es;
  animals; Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals;
  vertebrates; Chordata; North-America; America; West-South-Central-States-=
of
  -USA; Southern-States-of-USA; USA; Delta-States-of-USA; Gulf-States-of-US=
A

Record 1026 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: The isolation in Australia of a new virus related to bovine ephemeral f=
ever
  virus.
AU: Gard-GP; Cybinski-DH; St-George-TD
AD: Dep. Primary Prod., PO Box 4160, Darwin, Northern Territory 5794, Austr=
alia.
SO: Australian-Veterinary-Journal. 1983, 60: 3, 89-90; 7 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: A new virus designated DPP63 or Berrimah virus was isolated in April, 1=
981,
  from the blood of a healthy sentinel steer on Berrimah Research Farm, Dar=
win.
  Immunofluorescence tests showed that it was related to both bovine epheme=
ral
  fever (BEF) and Tortilla Flat viruses, though more strongly to the former=
. The
  steer had neutralizing antibody to all three viruses at the time of isola=
tion.
  Of 478 serum samples from cattle in different parts of Australia, 20% had
  neutralizing antibodies to both BEF and DPP63 viruses. However, a serolog=
ical
  survey would not give meaningful results because of the antigenic overlap=
.
DE: Viral-diseases; cattle-diseases
OD: cattle-; Rhabdoviridae-; bovine-ephemeral-fever-virus
GE: Australia-
ID: related-virus
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; viruses; Vesiculovirus; Rhabdoviridae; Australasia; Oc=
eania

Record 1027 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Persistence of field strains of Aujeszky's virus in vaccinated swine he=
rds.
OT: Badania nad okresem utrzymywania sie szczepow terenowych wirusa choroby
  Aujeszky'ego (chA) w stadach swin swoiscie szczepionych.
AU: Szweda-W; Janowski-H
AD: Wydzial Wet. AR-T, 10-957 Olsztyn-Kortowo, Poland.
SO: Medycyna-Weterynaryjna. 1983, 39: 3, 163-167; 19 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: Polish
LS: English, Russian
AB: Systematic vaccination of an entire pig herd with "Suivac A" was carrie=
d out
  after an outbreak of Aujeszky's disease. Two and three years later 15 and=
 14
  young unvaccinated pigs with no history of the disease were introduced to=
 test
  for the presence of field virus. Blood samples were collected from the se=
ntinel
  pigs at monthly intervals and examined by serum neutralization. In anothe=
r pig
  herd, vaccinated for two years after one outbreak of Aujeszky's disease, =
20
  healthy unvaccinated boars were introduced for breeding purposes for 6.5 =
months
  and studied serologically. In the first herd the two groups of introduced=
 pigs
  showed after 3.5 months geometric mean titres of 5.2 and 1.4, reaching af=
ter 5
  months respective peaks of 29.3 and 44. The boars introduced into the sec=
ond
  herd, through close contact with the sows, developed specific antibodies =
after
  a month, with a peak after 5 months.

Record 1028 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Distribution of abscesses and shedder state in swine inoculated with gr=
oup E
  streptococci via routes other than oral.
AU: Miller-RB; Olson-LD
AD: Dep. Vet. Med. Surg., Coll. Vet. Med., Univ., Columbia, Missouri 65211,=
 USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1983, 44: 6, 937-944; 16 ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: The pathogenesis of group E streptococcal abscesses of swine which occu=
r at
  sites other than the head and neck (atypical sites) was studied after gro=
ups of
  swine were each inoculated by 1 of 4 routes (intragastric, intraenteric,
  footpad, or intratracheal). Abscesses were observed in the head and neck =
of all
  swine and at atypical sites in 3 of the 5 swine inoculated by the intraga=
stric
  route. In 20 swine inoculated by the intraenteric route, head and neck
  abscesses were recognized in 7 and abscesses at atypical sites occurred i=
n 11.
  Inoculation by footpad scarification induced head and neck abscesses in 1=
 of 5
  swine and atypical sites abscesses in 2 of 5 swine. Intratracheal inocula=
tion
  produced head and neck abscesses in 3 of 5 swine and an abscess at an aty=
pical
  site (lung parenchyma) in 1 of the 3 with head and neck abscesses. Four o=
f 5
  noninoculated swine had abscesses in the mandibular lymph nodes 55 days a=
fter
  they had access to a manure pit used also by swine inoculated by foodpad
  scarification. Abscesses in atypical sites were not recognized in 29 sent=
inel
  swine with abscesses exposed by nose and/or oral contact. In transmission
  studies, all principal swine were inoculated with group E streptococcus b=
y the
  intraenteric route. A group of 5 principals transmitted the organism to 1=
 of 2
  susceptible penmates. Each of another 5 principals transmitted group E
  streptococcus to 4 of 5, 4 of 4, 3 of 4, 3 of 4, and 2 of 4 of their resp=
ective
  contact sentinels. In the last experiment, when 5 swine were inoculated a=
nd
  penned separately, 2 of 2 transmitted group E streptococcus by drinking w=
ater,
  2 of 3 transmitted group E streptococcus by drinking water and/or nose co=
ntact,
  and 2 of 5 transmitted group E streptococcus by their faeces. Transmissio=
n was
  determined by isolation of group E streptococcus from sentinel abscess ex=
udate.
  In the last experiment, transmission also was determined by a microtitrat=
ion
  agglutination test.
DE: Disease-transmission; Bacterial-diseases; Experimental-infection; absce=
sses
  -; swine-diseases
OD: pigs-; Streptococcus-
ID: group-E; Streptococcus-group-E
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; Streptococcaceae; Firmicutes; bacteria;
  prokaryotes
CC: LL820; LL860
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Animal

Record 1029 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Identification of hitherto unrecognized arboviruses from Ecuador member=
s of
  serogroups B, C, Bunyamwera, patois, and Minatitlan.
AU: Calisher-CH; Gutierrez-V-E; Francy-DB; Alava-A-A; Muth-DJ; Lazuick-JS
AD: Div. Vector-Borne Viral Dis., Centers Dis. Control, Fort Collins, Color=
ado
  80522, USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1983, 32: 4, 877-885=
; 19
  ref.
PY: 1983
LA: English
AB: Three hundred seventy-nine virus isolates were obtained from mosquitoes
  collected and sentinel hamsters in coastal Ecuador from 1974 to 1978. The=
se
  included four alphaviruses [Venezuelan equine encephalitis 1B (1), Venezu=
elan
  equine encephalitis 1D (35), western equine encephalitis (1) and eastern =
equine
  encephalitis (4)]; two flaviviruses [St. Louis encephalitis (3) and Naran=
jal
  (6)]; 11 bunyaviruses [Maguari (243), Playas (3), Vinces (33), Turlock (2=
),
  Abras (5), Babahoyo (3), Acara (2), Guajara (3), San Juan (6), Pueblo Vie=
jo
  (3), 18 unspecified Gamboa serogroup viruses, Palestina (7)]; and one
  vesiculovirus (vesicular stomatitis New Jersey). All but Venezuelan equin=
e
  encephalitis virus were new to Ecuador, and Naranjal (serogroup B), Playa=
s
  (Bunyamwera serogroup), Vinces (serogroup C), Abras and Babahoyo (Patois
  serogroup), San Juan and Pueblo Viejo (Gamboa serogroup) and Palestina
  (Minatitlan serogroup) are newly recognized viruses. These isolates have
  increased the knowledge of the geographic distribution of recognized viru=
ses,
  and of the members of certain serogroups and established two new serogrou=
ps
  (Gamboa and Minatitlan).
DE: Epidemiological-surveys; viral-diseases
OD: Equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Flavivirus-; Bunyaviridae-; Vesicular

Record 1031 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Performance test on vacuum regulators used with milking machines.
SO: 21-26; 9 ref.
LA: English
AB: 14 types of regulator were assessed when new and after 2.5 X 105 cycles=
 of
  operation for capacity, leakage and sensitivity [DSA 39, 1145]. Alfa-Lava=
l (2),
  Manus (2) and Westfalia (3) and 2 out of 5 Simplex regulators conformed t=
o the
  Irish Standard I.S. 187 (1974), AHI (3) and Waikato (3) had lower than ra=
ted
  capacity. Strangko (4) regulators had higher than rated capacity, 1 out o=
f 3
  Melotte regulators nearly met the Standard. 3 Melotte and 3 Simplex regul=
ators
  were sticking and the results were unreliable, Boumatic (3) and Sentinel =
(1)
  regulators deviated substantially from the Standard even when new.

Record 1032 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Tick-borne meningo-encephalitis (TBE) in Italy.
OT: Meningoencefaliti da zecche (TBE) in Italia.
AU: Paci-P; Leoncini-F; Mazzotta-F; Milo-D; Amaducci-L; Fratiglioni-L; Bald=
ucci
  -M; Verani-P
AD: Sezione Malattie Infettive, Arcispedale S. Maria Nuova di Firenze, Flor=
ence,
  Italy.
SO: Annali-Sclavo. 1980, 22: 3, 404-416; 19 ref.
PY: 1980
LA: Italian
LS: English
AB: The history and epidemiology of tick-borne encephalitis (TBE), which in
  Europe was first observed in the USSR, is briefly reviewed. Although the
  disease was not certainly known in Italy, some human individuals in north=
ern
  Italy and some goats in central Italy were found in serological studies t=
o
  contain antibodies to TBE, and in 1975 2 patients in hospital in Florence=
 had
  acute symptoms of meningoencephalitis typical of TBE. Investigations were
  therefore begun in the Province of Firenze into the fauna, flora and clim=
ate of
  the region and into the possibility of isolating the virus from vectors o=
r
  reservoirs present there. The fauna consisted mainly of wild rodents but =
also
  included foxes (Vulpes vulpes) in both northern and southern sections of =
the
  study region. Ticks collected from both sections consisted of Rhipicephal=
us
  sanguineus (Latr.) R. bursa C. & F. and Ixodes ricinus (L.); the developm=
ent of
  the last species was favoured by the climate. In the northern section onl=
y, 2
  women and a fox were found positive for TBE, and antibodies were found in=
 20%
  of 1 of 3 flocks of sheep examined and also in a sentinel flock sent into=
 the
  same locality. In the southern section, antibodies to Bhanja virus (norma=
lly
  transmitted by Haemaphysalis punctata C. & F.) were found in indigenous s=
heep,
  but neither this virus nor TBE was found in sentinel sheep, wild animals =
or
  man. Examination of ticks from both sections showed that I. ricinus from =
the
  southern section contained Tribec virus (which had been isolated twice be=
fore
  in Italy and was also known in Romania and Slovakia). In the northern sec=
tion,
  females of I. ricinus from one locality contained TBE, the first strain t=
o be
  isolated from ticks in Italy, and 2 males of R. bursa in a different loca=
lity
  contained 2 strains of Bhanja virus. It is concluded that a natural focus=
 of
  TBE exists in the north of the Province of Firenze, with a second possibl=
e
  'risk' area, and that subclinical infections previously observed there we=
re
  probably due to TBE. The probable existence of foci of tick-borne Bhanja =
virus
  in the north and of Tribec virus in the south (although the indications a=
re not
  so definite) further demonstrate the necessity of continued surveillance =
and
  further investigation of tick-borne viruses in the Province of Firenze.
DE: transmission-; disease-transmission
OD: Rhipicephalus-sanguineus; Rhipicephalus-bursa; Ixodes-ricinus; Vulpes
  -vulpes; sheep-; viruses-; tickborne-encephalitis-virus; man-; Bhanja-vir=
us;
  Haemaphysalis-punctata; Acari-
GE: Italy-
ID: tick-borne-encephalitis; Tribec-virus
BT: Rhipicephalus; Ixodidae; Metastigmata; Acari; Arachnida; arthropods;
  invertebrates; animals; Ixodes; Vulpes; Canidae; Fissipeda; carnivores;
  mammals; vertebrates; Chordata; Ovis; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla;
  ungulates; Flavivirus; Flaviviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Homo; Hominida=
e;
  Primates; unclassified-viruses; Haemaphysalis; Southern-Europe; Europe;
  Mediterranean-Countries
CC: VV200; LL820; TT300; PP710
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Humans; Parasite=
s,
  -Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Medical-and-Veterin=
ary
  -Entomology-Records-Discontinued; Biological-Resources-Animal
PT: Journal-article
UD: 950203
AN: 810588253

Record 1033 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Emergence of a new arbovirus disease in Brazil. III. Isolation of Rocio
  virus from Psorophora ferox (Humboldt, 1819).
AU: Souza-Lopes-O-de; Abreu-Sacchetta-L-de; Francy-DB; Jakob-WL; Calisher-C=
H;
  Lopes-O-de-Souza; Sacchetta-L-de-Abreu; De-Souza-Lopes-O; De-Abreu-Sacche=
tta-L
AD: Secao de Virus Transmitidos por Artropodos, Instituto Adolfo Lutz, Caix=
a
  Postal 7027, Sao Paulo, Brazil.
SO: American-Journal-of-Epidemiology. 1981, 113: 2, 122-125; 13 ref.
PY: 1981
LA: English
AB: A newly described flavivirus was responsible for a large encephalitis
  epidemic in Sao Paulo State, Brazil, in 1975-76. The aetiological agent, =
Rocio
  virus, was isolated from human patients and sentinel mice. The natural hi=
story
  of the virus is unknown although presumed to be arthropod-borne. Rocio vi=
rus
  was isolated from a single pool containing 19 individuals of Psorophora f=
erox
  (Humb.) out of 47 pools (283 specimens) of this species tested. The posit=
ive
  pool contained 16 empty, 2 gravid and 2 engorged mosquitoes. No isolation=
s were
  made from 2183 pools of other species. The positive pool was collected du=
ring
  the year of the epidemic at the same approximate time and place where
  vertebrate isolations were made.

Record 1034 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Surveillance for arthropod-borne viral activity and disease in Californ=
ia
  during 1980.
AU: Emmons-RW; Milby-MM; Gillies-PA; Reeves-WC; Bayer-EV
AD: California Department of Health Services, Berkeley, CA 94704, USA.
SO: Proceedings and papers of the Forty-ninth Annual Conference of the
  California Mosquito and Vector Control Association, Inc. April 26-29, 198=
1. Red
  Lion Motor Inn, Redding, California. 1982, 1-4; 2 ref.
PB: CMVCA Press; Sacramento, California; USA
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Surveys in California for arthropod-borne and especially mosquito-bone
  arboviruses were continued in 1980 [see RAE/B 69, 2081] by means both of
  serological tests of human and equine cases of suspected encephalitis and=
 of
  tests of mosquito pools for viruses. No cases of western equine encephali=
tis
  (WEE) or St. Louis encephalitis (SLE) were found in man in California, bu=
t 1
  case of SLE was found in Nevada. Of 25 equines tested serologically for W=
EE,
  only 2 cases were confirmed. A total of 3760 pools of mosquitoes (177 839
  individuals) was collected, of which most consisted either of Culex tarsa=
lis
  Coq. or of members of the species-complex of C. pipiens L.; 73 isolations=
 were
  made of WEE, 13 of SLE, 77 of Hart Park virus, 48 of Turlock virus and 11=
 of
  the California encephalitis group. Sentinel flocks of domestic fowls were
  distributed to 31 localities; 15% developed antibodies to WEE in the Sacr=
amento
  Valley, the San Joaquin Valley and southern California. These results
  demonstrated a substantial fall in the rates of infection with these mosq=
uito
  -borne viruses since 1979.
DE: mosquito-nets
OD: Culex-tarsalis; arboviruses-; Culex-pipiens; western-equine-encephaliti=
s
  -virus; St-Louis-encephalitis-virus; California-encephalitis-virus; virus=
es-;
  Culex-; Hart-Park-virus; Turlock-virus; fowls-; man-; Culicidae-; Diptera=
-
GE: USA-; California-; Nevada-
ID: complex
BT: Culex; Culicidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrates; animals;
  viruses; equine-encephalomyelitis-virus; Alphavirus; arboviruses; Togavir=
idae;
  Flavivirus; Flaviviridae; Bunyavirus; Bunyaviridae; Vesiculovirus;
  Rhabdoviridae; unclassified-viruses; Gallus-gallus; Gallus; Phasianidae;
  Galliformes; birds; vertebrates; Chordata; Homo; Hominidae; Primates; mam=
mals;
  North-America; America; Pacific-States-of-USA; Western-States-of-USA; USA=
;
  Mountain-States-of-USA
CC: VV200; LL820; TT300; HH700; PP710; EE100

Record 1035 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Preliminary characterization of D'Aguilar virus and three Palyam group
  viruses new to Australia.
AU: Cybinski-DH; George-TD-St; St-George-TD
AD: Division of Animal Health, CSIRO, Long Pocket Laboratories, PB No. 3,
  Indooroopilly, Queensland 4068, Australia.
SO: Australian-Journal-of-Biological-Sciences. 1982, 35: 3, 343-351; 1 fig.=
; 20
  ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: In 1974-80, 424 viruses were isolated in Australia from insects or the =
blood
  of sentinel cattle; of these, 165 cross-reacted with D'Aguilar virus (an
  Australian Palyam group virus) in a complement fixation test. Neutralisat=
ion
  tests were used to classify these viruses into 4 serotypes with the isola=
tes
  D'Aguilar B8112, CSIRO 11, CSIRO 58 and CSIRO 82 as the type strains. The
  latter 3 were new to Australia. Like other orbiviruses, these 4 serotypes=
 were
  partially sensitive to treatment with ether or chloroform. Neutralising
  antibodies against D'Aguilar, CSIRO 11 and CSIRO 58 viruses were detected=
 in
  sera from cattle, buffalo, deer and sheep but not man, horses, pigs or
  marsupials. Antibodies against CSIRO 82 virus were detected in 85% of 26
  buffalo and 0.4% of 495 cattle sera. The antibody distribution in Austral=
ia for
  D'Aguilar, CSIRO 11 and CSIRO 58 fell within the distribution limits of
  Culicoides brevitarsis Kieff., the insect from which these viruses were m=
ost
  commonly recovered. The antibody distribution for CSIRO 82 virus, which w=
as
  isolated from a pool containing C. schultzei (End.) and C. peregrinus Kie=
ff.,
  fell within the much more restricted distribution limits of these species=
.
OD: Culicoides-brevitarsis; Culicoides-schultzei; Culicoides-; Ceratopogoni=
dae-;
  Diptera-
GE: Australia-
ID: Culicoides-peregrinus; Palyam-viruses; D'Aguilar-virus
BT: Culicoides; Ceratopogonidae; Diptera; insects; arthropods; invertebrate=
s;
  animals; Australasia; Oceania
CC: TT300
CD: Medical-and-Veterinary-Entomology-Records-Discontinued
PT: Journal-article
UD: 950203
AN: 820596111

TI: Superior spring grain cultivars for coastal British Columbia.
AU: Fushtey-SG
AD: Res. Sta., Agric. Canada, Agassiz, B.C., Canada V0M 1A0.
SO: Research-Review,-Research-Station,-Agassiz,-B.C. 1981, November, 5-7.
PY: 1981
LA: English
AB: Spring wheat cv. Opal and Dundas outyielded Glenlea (3.19 t/ha) by 34 a=
nd
  20%, resp. in 1978-81. Vernon outyielded Glenlea (2.67 t/ha) by 13% in 19=
80-l.
  Oats cv. Sentinel and Cascade yielded 3.59 and 4.03 t/ha, resp., in 1980-=
1,
  compared with 3.05 t from Fraser. Barley cv. Klages, Lud, Steptoe and Fai=
rfield
  outyielded Galt (3.67 t/ha) by 24, 14, 17 and 11%, resp., in 1978-9 and y=
ielded
  3.43, 3.03, 3.26 and 2.89 t/ha, resp., in 1980-1 when cv. Volla yielded 3=
.31 t
  and Galt 2.5 t.

Record 1037 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: A miracidium trap for use in flowing water.
AU: Prentice-MA; Christie-JD; Barnish-G
AD: Res. and Control Dep., PO Box 93, Castries, St. Lucia, West Indies.
SO: Annals-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Parasitology. 1981, 75: 4, 407-413; 7 r=
ef.
PY: 1981
LA: English
AB: In field trials, Biomphalaria glabrata were exposed in specially design=
ed
  traps (20 snails/trap) to running water contaminated (naturally or
  artificially) with Schistosoma miracidia. Snails in the traps had an infe=
ction
  rate of 3.7%, compared with 0.5% for snails exposed in standard mosquito =
gauze
  bags (10/bag). Irrespective of the type of cage used (trap or bag), a 3-f=
old
  improvement in infection rate resulted when the same total number of snai=
ls was
  exposed in groups of only 5/unit. The 3 kinds of trap used (round, tube a=
nd
  spiral) are briefly described. Requirements for a cage which increases th=
e
  opportunities for miracidium/snail contact are summarized.
DE: miracidia-; parasites-; helminths-
OD: Schistosoma-
ID: technique-for-trapping; using-sentinel-snails
BT: digenean-larvae; helminth-larvae; larvae; animals; Digenea; Trematoda;
  Platyhelminthes; invertebrates; helminths; Schistosomatidae
CC: TT100
CD: Medical-and-Veterinary-Helminthology-Records-Discontinued
PT: Journal-article

Record 1038 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Evaluation of chemotherapy in the control of Schistosoma mansoni in Mar=
quis
  Valley, Sain Lucia. II. Biological results.
AU: Barnish-G
AD: Res. & Control Dep., P.O. Box 93, Castries, Saint Lucia, West Indies.
SO: American-Journal-of-Tropical-Medicine-and-Hygiene. 1982, 31: 1, 111-115=
; 8
  ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Following the final chemotherapy campaign of a 4-year programme, the
  biological assessment of transmission of S. mansoni was evaluated for 5 y=
ears.
  No infected Biomphalaria glabrata were found amongst 28 791 and 13 550 sn=
ails
  examined from flowing and static index sites, respectively. However, 89
  infected snails among 16 602 examined (0.54%) were found from additional =
sites.
  Sentinel snails examined between March 1974 and October 1977 revealed no
  infection and their use was discontinued. Following an increase in
  intransmission routine focal mollusciciding at 4-week intervals was intro=
duced
  in March 1980. The cost for 8 applications was US$641, representing a
  cost/caput of $0.21. These figures, extrapolated to a full year's control=
,
  become $1,042 and $0.35, respectively. The maximum cost was for the
  molluscicide, which absorbed 71.5% of the total. The data suggest that th=
e main
  transmission of S. mansoni occurs in the dry season, in flowing habitats,=
 as it
  does elsewhere in St. Lucia. [AS]
DE: control-programmes; control-; molluscicides-; parasites-; helminths-
OD: Schistosoma-mansoni; Biomphalaria-glabrata; MOLLUSCA-
GE: St-Lucia
ID: Molluscs
BT: pesticides; invertebrates; animals; Schistosoma; Schistosomatidae; Dige=

  Trematoda; Platyhelminthes; Biomphalaria; Planorbidae; Gastropoda; Mollus=
ca;
  Windward-Islands; Lesser-Antilles; Caribbean; America

Record 1039 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Influence of control of leaf blotch on the yield and grain characterist=
ics
  of oats produced under intensive management.
AU: Johnston-HW; MacLeod-JA; Sterling-JDE
AD: Res. Sta., Agric. Canada, Charlottetown, PEI, Canada.
SO: Canadian-Journal-of-Plant-Pathology. 1981, 3: 4, 215-218; 3 fig.; 15 re=
f.
PY: 1981
LA: English
LS: French
AB: When cvs. Garry and Sentinel were grown in the field with 50, 80 and 11=
0 kg
  N/ha, and the growth regulator Cycocel to control lodging, the applicatio=
n of
  Bayleton-CF (triadimefon + captafol) gave good control of Septoria avenae=
 f.sp.
  avenae [Leptosphaeria avenaria] and produced improvements in kernel wt.,
  percentage hull protein and grain yield. Cycocel alone gave little benefi=
t but
  combined with Bayleton-CF its effects in reducing lodging were enhanced.
  Increased N levels corresponded to increased grain yield to the greatest =
extent
  when L. and lodging were controlled. A positive response of oats was more
  closely related to disease control than to reduced lodging.
ADDITIONAL
  ABSTRACT: In oats cv. Garry and Sentinel which received 50-110 kg N/ha an=
d
  chlormequat to control lodging, application of Bayleton-CF (250 g triadim=
efon
  a.i. + 1.3 kg captafol a.i./ha) gave good control of Septoria avenae f. s=
p.
  avenae and increased grain wt. and yield and hull protein content. Chlorm=
equat
  alone gave little benefit. Bayleton-CF enhanced the effect of chlormequat=
 in
  reducing lodging, especially in Sentinel. Increased N gave the greatest y=
ield
  increase when S. avenae and lodging were controlled. Yield response was m=
ore
  closely related to disease control than to reduced lodging.
DE: Fungicides-; oats-; control-; triadimefon-; captafol-; fertilizers-;

Record 1040 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: The continuous eco-pathological survey. I. A new surveillance method fo=
r
  diseases of ruminants.
OT: L'enquete Eco-Pathologique Continue: I. Une nouvelle methode de travail=
 en
  pathologie chez les ruminants.
AU: Barnouin-J; Brochart-M
SO: Bulletin-Technique-Centre-de-Recherches-Zootechniques-et-Veterinaires-d=
e
  -Theix. 1981, No.46, 11-14; 5 ref.
PY: 1981
LA: French
AB: A continuous disease surveillance system for cattle and sheep, based on=
 a
  network of sentinel farms, each observed by a veterinarian, at present
  comprises 120 sentinel farms in seven Departments. These supply a continu=
ous
  flow of information, to a data bank, on diseases, treatments, prophylaxis=
,
  blood chemistry, feeding systems, reproduction, milk production, manageme=
nt,
  weather and soil analysis. Preliminary disease statistics are reported.

Record 1041 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Bluetongue infections in Louisiana cattle.
AU: Fulton-RW; Nicholson-SS; Pearson-NJ; Potter-MT; Archbald-LF; Pearson-JE=
;
  Jochim-MM
AD: Agric. Exp. Sta., Sch. Vet. Med., State Univ., Baton Rouge, Louisiana 7=
0803,
  USA.
SO: American-Journal-of-Veterinary-Research. 1982, 43: 5, 887-891; 28 ref.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Bluetongue virus (BTV) serotype 17 was isolated from cattle with clinic=
al
  signs of bluetongue disease during the 1978 and 1979 epidemics in Louisia=
na.
  Bovine serum from 6 herds located in an epidemic region were examined in =
1979
  for antibodies, using an immunodiffusion (ID) test. Of 300 serum samples,=
 164
  (54.7%) were positive. Serum from surveys of cattle throughout Louisiana =
in
  July to August 1980 and December 1980 to January 1981 were tested for BTV
  antibodies, using the ID test. Fifty-eight of 70 herds (82.9%) and 164 of=
 597
  (27.5%) individual cattle tested in July to August 1980 were positive. Fi=
fty
  -four of 63 (85.7%) herds and 170 of 600 (28.3%) individual cattle tested=
 in
  December 1980 to January 1981 were positive. Significant differences were=
 found
  in the seropositive rates between the various geographic regions of the s=
tate
  during each survey. Adult breeding-age cattle in 3 sentinel herds were te=
sted
  for BTV antibodies beginning in 1976 and continuing through January 1981.
  During this interval, the seropositive rate in 2 of 3 herds was increased=
.
  Also, individual cattle in all 3 of these herds converted from seronegati=
ve to
  seropositive, indicating exposure during a particular interval for each h=
erd.
  The age distribution of seropositive cattle in a dairy indicated that 2-y=
ear
  -old cattle had a seropositive rate comparable with that of older animals=
 in
  the herd, suggesting that the 2-year-old animals had been exposed to a BT=
V
  before they entered the breeding herd.
DE: DISEASE-SURVEYS; Viral-diseases; Serological-surveys; Antibodies-; Dise=
ase
  -prevalence; Epidemiology-; cattle-diseases; sheep-diseases
OD: cattle-; bluetongue-virus; sheep-
GE: USA-
ID: bluetongue-in-cattle
BT: Bos; Bovidae; ruminants; Artiodactyla; ungulates; mammals; vertebrates;
  Chordata; animals; Orbivirus; Reoviridae; viruses; arboviruses; Ovis; Nor=
th
  -America; America
CC: LL820
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals
PT: Journal-article

UD: 950203

Record 1043 of 1202 in CAB Abstracts 1982-1983

TI: Epidemiological aspects of swine dysentery in the Midwestern United Sta=
tes.
AU: Egan-IHT
AD: State Univ., Ames, Iowa, USA.
SO: Dissertation-Abstracts-International,-B. 1982, 42: 11, 4320.
PY: 1982
LA: English
AB: Thirteen of 14 pig farms with a history of swine dysentery were detecte=
d
  with ELISA when serum samples were evaluated. None of eight herds free of=
 the
  disease was positive. Pigs recovered from swine dysentery caused by expos=
ure to
  Treponema hyodysenteriae serotype 1 were resistant to subsequent exposure=
 to
  the same isolate. Pigs recovered from serotype 2 were resistant to subseq=
uent
  exposure to 1, 2 and 4. The treponeme survived in experimentally inoculat=
ed
  soil for 41 days at -20 deg C, 18 days at 14 deg C, 2 days at 22 deg C an=
d <5 h
  at 37 deg C. It survived in faeces from dysenteric pig for 15 days at 22 =
deg C
  and 74 days at 4 deg C. The treponeme was not transmitted from soil to se=
ntinel
  pigs placed in pens from which infected pigs had been removed 4 h, 5 or 6=
 days
  previously.
DE: Bacterial-diseases; Epidemiology-; Diagnosis-; ELISA-; swine-dysentery;
  swine-diseases; immunity-
OD: pigs-; bacteria-; Treponema-hyodysenteriae
GE: USA-
ID: survival-in-soil; soil-microbiology
BT: Sus; Suidae; Suiformes; Artiodactyla; mammals; vertebrates; Chordata;
  animals; Sus-scrofa; ungulates; prokaryotes; Treponema; Treponemataceae;
  Spirochaetales; Gracilicutes; bacteria; North-America; America
CC: LL820; HH600; JJ100; LL860
CD: Parasites,-Vectors,-Pathogens-and-Biogenic-Diseases-of-Animals; Host
  -Resistance-and-Immunity; Soil-Biology; Animal-Disorders-Not-caused-by-Or=
ganisms
